description:
This show provides the very basic computer literacy skills by providing a comprehensive and full range of entry-level computing skills by Dr. Tonny Omwansa. It is foundational for anyone looking to move any profession using computers on a daily basis because entry-level computing skills have become a compulsory requirement in business today.
Dr. Omwansa helps the learner to come up to speed on computing basics, and helps them achieve competency and skills on a computer easily. The show  covers everything from computer hardware and software to the underlying functionality of a computer, and helps readers gain the skills and knowledge they need to move forward in their careers, or to successfully prepare for any of the IC3 Exams.  The show covers the following objectives
•              Learn about computer hardware, software and other basic functions
•              Get a full introduction to Windows and Microsoft Office
•              Create polished documents and presentations in Microsoft Excel, PowerPoint and Word 2010
Gain an understanding of web basics, connectivity, security and privacy
name: IC3-I Choose Life
subtitle: Computing Fundamentals

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa explain the concept and components of information systems and some of the computer basic people need to understand when working and living in computer technology based societies and companies, respectively.  They discuss the personal computer, servers, mainframes and super computers and when people normally encounter them and use them.  This episode with Dr. Omwansa sets the first steps for digital literacy.
episodes.title: Computing Basics

[MUSIC]

11

If we're actually trying to understand
this idea of getting into computing

14

as field.

15
00:00:47.800 --> 00:00:50.130
>> So the journey of computing is really,

really wide,
I mean you cover a lot of stuff.

17

But the good thing about
certifications and training programs

18

19

20

In today's session, we're gonna

21

The first one is we want to

22
00:01:10.320 --> 00:01:13.400
As you can hear, it talks about a system.

23
00:01:13.400 --> 00:01:15.840
So we'll spend some time

24
00:01:15.840 --> 00:01:18.520

25

the different strengths and

27

And then we also try to

28

29

31

That's basically what we're

32
00:01:40.529 --> 00:01:41.191
>> All right, so

33

when we start talking about the idea

34

35

36

The whole goal then for

83

88

00:21:50.140 --> 00:21:52.831
It can create the output
that we need to see.

393
00:21:52.831 --> 00:21:55.296
So that processing cycle is a part of it,
and

394
00:21:55.296 --> 00:21:59.710
you may even of course also need then data
input in there that can be processed.

395
00:21:59.710 --> 00:22:02.100
And then the output of
course will be data as well.

396
00:22:02.100 --> 00:22:05.710
In terms of output, remember that what Dr.
Tony told us here.

397
00:22:05.710 --> 00:22:09.730
Anything that gives us the result from
the computer and system that we need.

398
00:22:09.730 --> 00:22:12.120
A lot of times the most primary
output device that you and

399
00:22:12.120 --> 00:22:15.300
I are gonna run into is
a monitor of some sort.

Even on our small smart phones, the screen

00:22:20.950 --> 00:22:22.630

00:22:22.630 --> 00:22:24.754
But it is because we tend

00:22:24.754 --> 00:22:28.157
that we actually called an output device

404
00:22:28.157 --> 00:22:33.657
And storage is where the most of the

the very fact we can store a tremendous

a memory card today and even gigantic

00:22:44.770 --> 00:22:48.520
It just tends to let you know that this
particular idea that computing system

change as time goes on to smaller and

00:22:53.200 --> 00:22:55.440
faster components as we start seeing.

00:22:55.440 --> 00:22:57.170
So there's a lot more to go.

We just kind of gave you

So what else do we need to think about,

>> I think of these fundamental stage

00:23:09.380 --> 00:23:13.440
I think the other we need to think about

Or we could use Bluetooth which is

All right, but more important is that

you don't just get yourself to enable

We've got the Internet.

Internet is a world wide interconnection

Right now, we're not gonna going

But it is important to note that Internet

00:24:44.280 --> 00:24:47.710

444
00:24:55.811 --> 00:25:00.803
And someone, somewhere is paying for

445
00:25:00.803 --> 00:25:04.715
Now, it's now possible to
connect your personal computer,

446
00:25:04.715 --> 00:25:10.450
your laptop computer, your mobile device,
tablet, smartphone, you name it.

447
00:25:10.450 --> 00:25:12.910
And there you go, powered and connected.

448
00:25:14.020 --> 00:25:17.935
>> So, a lot of times what we see then is
the idea of those computers actually have

technology built into them.

Whether it's hardware and software,

00:25:22.110 --> 00:25:26.010
And some hardware component and then some
little bit of software that allows for

00:25:26.010 --> 00:25:28.662
the communication that we
were just talking about.

453
00:25:28.662 --> 00:25:31.160
And the idea of actually being
on connected to the ethernet,

454
00:25:31.160 --> 00:25:34.010
a lot of time or ethernet,
however you want to pronounce it.

455
00:25:34.010 --> 00:25:37.020
I don't know which one's proper
[LAUGH] and I say them both.

456
00:25:37.020 --> 00:25:41.260
So in this sense, right, that there's
actually gonna be a physical component

that allows us to directly cable in.

00:25:43.680 --> 00:25:47.370
So we normally talk about, of course,
those components in networking.

We talk about things like actual,

Now if that doesn't happen,

And so

a moment to show you what

00:26:11.200 --> 00:26:15.650
So on my computer, there is not one of
those physical ports on the computer

00:26:15.650 --> 00:26:17.380
to be able to connect in
this type of network.

00:26:17.380 --> 00:26:21.540
So I have to have a device like this, and

00:26:21.540 --> 00:26:25.890
But it plugs into, well, one of my

00:26:25.890 --> 00:26:28.570
And that allows me to get
that type of connection.

472
00:26:28.570 --> 00:26:30.290
But what if I don't have any of that?

00:26:30.290 --> 00:26:32.845
Well, even my laptop, and I'm assuming Dr.

00:26:32.845 --> 00:26:37.051
Tonny's laptop also, has what they

00:26:37.051 --> 00:26:40.150
That allows us to connect wirelessly

Tonny was talking about.

And usually we see there that idea of

00:26:45.459 --> 00:26:46.728

00:26:46.728 --> 00:26:51.560
Two different technologies that allow

00:26:51.560 --> 00:26:53.820
And then mentioning the idea

Internet service providers is also a key.

Networks by themselves,

You don't tend to see all

00:27:20.976 --> 00:27:21.800

So the Internet is a fascinating place for

00:27:33.288 --> 00:27:36.700
So Dr. Tonny, is there anything else that

00:27:42.460 --> 00:27:46.880
>> Well, I think we've covered

00:27:51.380 --> 00:27:54.570
It's just important to note that,

00:27:54.570 --> 00:27:56.970
I are users of the computer, all right.

00:27:56.970 --> 00:27:59.820

00:27:59.820 --> 00:28:03.360

But it's important to also to remember

00:28:47.420 --> 00:28:53.220

That those which we don't have

The third we try to understand software,

00:29:31.390 --> 00:29:35.670

526
00:29:35.670 --> 00:29:38.770
And finally, we thought about how

528
00:29:42.910 --> 00:29:46.140

529
00:29:46.140 --> 00:29:50.440
So roughly that's what we've done at the

530
00:29:50.440 --> 00:29:52.890
next episode we'll get into more details.

531
00:29:52.890 --> 00:29:53.744
>> So thank you Dr.

Tonny for really helping us to

And really taking look at it as

00:30:02.835 --> 00:30:06.700

536
00:30:06.700 --> 00:30:10.230
So it's a great place to also end this

00:30:10.230 --> 00:30:11.550
I've been your host Ronny Wong.

538
00:30:11.550 --> 00:30:13.750
>> And my name is Dr. Tonny Oswansa.

539
00:30:13.750 --> 00:30:17.578
It's been great interacting together,
thinking through the foundation and

00:30:17.578 --> 00:30:19.847

in the next sessions.

541
00:30:19.847 --> 00:30:23.619
>> Stay right here for
more computing fundamentals.

542
00:30:23.619 --> 00:30:30.730
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa introduce the system unit.  They describe not only its function but also basic hardware components found within the system unit:  CPU, Memory, Motherboard, Power Supply.  Each is brief described and shown.  They discuss each component’s role in the system unit and its necessity.  Dr. Omwansa discusses not only the components but also their interworking together to make a functional computing system.
episodes.title: The System Unit
episodes.transcript:

And so we have to understand what it

So it's important to understand

And then from there,

So, where we'll begin is we'll

Now, when we begin,

00:03:45.080 --> 00:03:48.530
So similarly, the central processing unit,
first of all,

And at the heart of all those things

It may have mechanical features
on there but it's an electrical,

739
00:45:36.840 --> 00:45:40.709
an electronic device, it's delicate
you're gonna take care of it.

740
00:45:42.020 --> 00:45:45.950
It can function with
basic instructions and

741

you can use a computer for many, many
years, it's never brought up any problem.

742

But it's always good to have
a technician within reach,

743
00:45:53.780 --> 00:45:57.060

more technical problems.

744

Whenever you need to make
a patches of a computer,

745

746

Talk to an expert, mention some of

747

are you going to use it for, so

748
00:46:10.750 --> 00:46:14.790

749
00:46:14.790 --> 00:46:18.870
So that you don't spend too much money for

750

the resources that it's got.

751
00:46:24.720 --> 00:46:28.110
So the solutions are out there,
there are technical experts but

752

it is important for you to have a rough
idea basically what is it that you want.

753
00:46:32.060 --> 00:46:33.770
When are you gonna use your computer for
and

754

also to maintain it because it's a
delicate device, it's an expensive device.

755
00:46:39.758 --> 00:46:44.150
But it's also powerful, so
you want to keep it working properly for

756
00:46:44.150 --> 00:46:46.560
a long time so that it serves you better.

757
00:46:46.560 --> 00:46:50.140
Of course we all know that
as a digital device or

758
00:46:50.140 --> 00:46:54.230

it has mechanical elements.

759
00:46:54.230 --> 00:46:58.770
After some time, it will not function

760

just like a car, just like a bicycle and

761
00:47:02.870 --> 00:47:05.480
So sometimes you have to
blow some dust out of it,

762
00:47:05.480 --> 00:47:08.040
sometimes you have to change a cord.

763
00:47:08.040 --> 00:47:11.910
But then as time goes by
it kind of depreciates, so

764
00:47:11.910 --> 00:47:16.090
you wouldn't have it with
the same capability over time.

765
00:47:16.090 --> 00:47:20.360
And it's important in time you know you
have to replace it, and that's expected.

766
00:47:20.360 --> 00:47:25.090
So I hope with this foundation
knowledge about the system

767

unit that has several components together.

768
00:47:27.580 --> 00:47:32.650
You feel a little more confident to
make a few decisions and also to engage

769
00:47:32.650 --> 00:47:37.180
with others about the computer, that you
either want or you want to get rid of.

770
00:47:38.250 --> 00:47:39.172
>> All right, well Dr.

771

Tonny, thank you again for introducing
us to the basics of that system unit and

772
00:47:43.510 --> 00:47:48.230
allowing us to take a look inside and
see the overall relationship of those

773

components and how they do begin
to at least set and work together.

774
00:47:53.080 --> 00:47:56.020
Now, this is also a great place for
us to also end this episode then,

775
00:47:56.020 --> 00:48:00.470
signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

776
00:48:00.470 --> 00:48:01.230
>> And my name is Dr.

777
00:48:01.230 --> 00:48:05.430
Tonny Omwansa, enjoying learning
together about the system unit.

778
00:48:05.430 --> 00:48:09.506
>> Stay tuned right here for
more computing fundamentals.

779
00:48:09.506 --> 00:48:16.598
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: in this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa discuss how to select  input and output devices.  They discuss the importance of choosing the right devices for the right context and settings and even the right software applications.  They show and discuss the function of the most common input and out devices.  They also discuss some of the useful criteria in selecting the devices that will be used in our computing environment.
episodes.title: Input, Output and Storage
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2

Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

Because we're gonna need them on a day to

14

>> There is no doubt that what we have

We actually have a lot of choices that
we can make in terms of input and

And each time that we

>> I think the best place to begin

So, our starting point is the QWERTY

You know, right up to the end

It's just a collection of the specific

00:02:58.180 --> 00:03:02.810
I don't know if it can be seen on

So over here we have Q W E R T Y so

And as my colleague Ronnie

They somehow use all their

00:09:17.800 --> 00:09:20.590
And that way they're
able to type much faster.

152
00:09:20.590 --> 00:09:26.220
So there software that can help you to

153
00:09:26.220 --> 00:09:30.460
So that the fingers are positioned

So you really don't have to start

00:09:34.170 --> 00:09:39.410
So you cannot do it automatically, and you

00:09:44.430 --> 00:09:47.710
positioned at A-S-D-F and

00:09:47.710 --> 00:09:53.420
And then in the process each of these

00:09:53.420 --> 00:09:56.770
so as you type AWAD you just know well

00:09:56.770 --> 00:09:59.580
And therefore these fingers
will automatically do it.

161
00:09:59.580 --> 00:10:01.670
Then you can type your work very,

You can see that there are numbers there,

There's space, it's entering, etc.

So as Ronnie said,
I think if there's not out of market,

00:10:12.080 --> 00:10:16.890

166

Because it'll make life much easier and

00:10:23.845 --> 00:10:25.100
>> [LAUGH] Yes.

00:10:25.100 --> 00:10:29.860

00:10:29.860 --> 00:10:33.580

00:10:33.580 --> 00:10:36.070
And it can improve your
productivity as well.

172
00:10:36.070 --> 00:10:40.320
>> I find it better to type because
my handwriting is really that bad.

That people are constantly asking me why

175

176

Do take the time to learn how to actually

177
00:10:56.720 --> 00:10:59.310

because there's a great
degree of flexibility.

402
00:24:07.960 --> 00:24:11.650
Yeah, it really becomes a little bit more
intuitive to the way that we naturally do

403
00:24:11.650 --> 00:24:16.260
things, which is by touch and feel,
but it does take a little bit of time

404
00:24:16.260 --> 00:24:19.570
especially on a computer screen if
you're doing something like this.

405
00:24:19.570 --> 00:24:21.260
And even in a smartphone
if you're not used to it,

406
00:24:21.260 --> 00:24:23.260
because well you're just not used to it.

407
00:24:23.260 --> 00:24:25.010
And so you do have to learn for

408
00:24:25.010 --> 00:24:28.680
that particular mechanism how those
different functions may work.

409
00:24:28.680 --> 00:24:31.360
Some of them do translate over
into different devices, but

410
00:24:31.360 --> 00:24:32.770
some of them may not.

411
00:24:32.770 --> 00:24:34.930
But you actually see that the more
that you actually work with it,

412
00:24:34.930 --> 00:24:37.375
the more intuitive it gets,
and the easier it becomes.

413
00:24:37.375 --> 00:24:41.190
Dr. Tawny, I remember the first
time I actually had an iPad, and

414
00:24:41.190 --> 00:24:43.080
I had to try and type an email with it.

415
00:24:43.080 --> 00:24:47.110
I found it incredibly difficult to learn
how to type everything with my thumbs.

416
00:24:47.110 --> 00:24:50.930
But after a couple of days it
just seemed like second nature.

417
00:24:50.930 --> 00:24:54.140
But I was used to saying, there's no way
I can do this during the first couple of

418
00:24:54.140 --> 00:24:56.690
days because I was holding
the device like this but

419
00:24:56.690 --> 00:24:59.980
couple of days later I was there
doing it like it was natural.

420
00:24:59.980 --> 00:25:03.370
So you can in this environment,
especially in the touch environment

421
00:25:03.370 --> 00:25:06.650
where most of these devices don't
ever come with instructions.

422
00:25:06.650 --> 00:25:10.710
If you've just gotten a new smartphone,
if you've just gotten a new tablet,

423
00:25:10.710 --> 00:25:13.530
you'll see that it doesn't come with
an instruction manual on how to do it.

424
00:25:13.530 --> 00:25:17.140
They're just saying look, you can just
pick this thing up and just touch it and

425
00:25:17.140 --> 00:25:19.310
watch what happens when you do so.

426
00:25:19.310 --> 00:25:22.570
And then you'll pick up some of the other
more specialized things along the way.

427
00:25:22.570 --> 00:25:26.830
So touch is gonna be here and
probably still the wave of the future.

428
00:25:26.830 --> 00:25:30.900
Inside of a business environment,
it hasn't really caught on as much, and

429
00:25:30.900 --> 00:25:33.520
the reason why is that
they are temperamental.

430
00:25:33.520 --> 00:25:37.190
If you happen to accidentally
drop that screen,

431
00:25:37.190 --> 00:25:40.640
well, you've not only broken the screen,
but you've broken your input, and

432
00:25:40.640 --> 00:25:43.295
your output device, and
the processing unit, at the same time.

433
00:25:43.295 --> 00:25:43.926
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

434
00:25:43.926 --> 00:25:46.900
most of it's that to isolate
the idea of breakage here.

435
00:25:46.900 --> 00:25:51.110
>> You might still find that they're still
relying on the traditional types of input

436
00:25:51.110 --> 00:25:52.760
devices but overall though,

437
00:25:52.760 --> 00:25:56.410
the world is moving to that and
you'll see that even computing systems

438
00:25:56.410 --> 00:25:59.640
actually move to where those screens
are actually touch sensitive as well.

439
00:25:59.640 --> 00:26:02.478
So we're starting to see more and
more of that too.

440
00:26:02.478 --> 00:26:07.990
And it is a great technology
as long as it works perfectly.

441
00:26:07.990 --> 00:26:11.280
You don't ever notice it
when it works terribly.

442
00:26:11.280 --> 00:26:15.190
You notice every defect to that
environment that's possible.

443
00:26:15.190 --> 00:26:18.550
It's amazing how quickly you notice it.

444
00:26:18.550 --> 00:26:22.610
>> Well the other, along the same lines,
we've got other input devices

445
00:26:22.610 --> 00:26:28.010
that we may not really spend a lot
of time on things like joysticks

446
00:26:28.010 --> 00:26:31.992
which are kind of like and you can move
things around like a gear of a car,

447
00:26:31.992 --> 00:26:37.640
there are drawing tablets where
you can use a stylus to probably

448
00:26:37.640 --> 00:26:42.600
write on it and then that content is
automatically captured onto the computer.

449
00:26:42.600 --> 00:26:46.810
Not very common, yeah, but
then there are people who still use them.

450
00:26:46.810 --> 00:26:50.270
Probably you may or
may not get an opportunity to use them.

451
00:26:50.270 --> 00:26:53.940
But let's go on to scanners.

452
00:26:53.940 --> 00:26:57.610
Before computers came, and

453
00:26:57.610 --> 00:27:01.700
even still now, we create a lot
of documents, physical documents.

454
00:27:01.700 --> 00:27:05.630
We print stuff, we draw things,
we take photos, etc.

455
00:27:05.630 --> 00:27:09.740
And every so often we want to digitize
that content, we want to convert it into

456
00:27:09.740 --> 00:27:13.920
digital format and store it on
computer because it's very easy,

457
00:27:13.920 --> 00:27:18.740
it's very easy to move it around,
to share the files and things like that.

458
00:27:18.740 --> 00:27:24.170
So scanners are one of
the best technology that

459
00:27:24.170 --> 00:27:28.099
enables us to convert physical
documents into digital documents.

460
00:27:29.160 --> 00:27:34.730
>> We have different kind of scanners,
those that can take several documents at

461
00:27:34.730 --> 00:27:40.248
a goal, or one after another,
feeding into the scanner a lot faster.

462
00:27:40.248 --> 00:27:44.530
There's the flatbed option,
where you just place one document and

463
00:27:44.530 --> 00:27:47.390
then you kind of like cover it and
then you press a button, and

464
00:27:47.390 --> 00:27:52.170
it's just one document at a time and
you have to open that screen again.

465
00:27:52.170 --> 00:27:56.830
Whatever it is, some of those we
have feeders that enable us to scan

466
00:27:56.830 --> 00:28:00.283
documents quickly whatever
it maybe on my screen.

467
00:28:00.283 --> 00:28:05.310
I'm just demonstrating one scanner
which is the flatbed scanner.

468
00:28:05.310 --> 00:28:11.300
And if you can see basically,
this is very simple illustration

469
00:28:11.300 --> 00:28:17.390
of a scanner flatbed where you open it up,
you put that document and you cover.

470
00:28:17.390 --> 00:28:18.990
You press a button and you go.

471
00:28:18.990 --> 00:28:22.580
Some of them are wireless and
some of them have physical connections,

472
00:28:22.580 --> 00:28:25.510
so the document then is
transmitted to the computer.

473
00:28:25.510 --> 00:28:27.640
And then you can do whatever
you wanna do with it.

474
00:28:27.640 --> 00:28:30.020
And you can reproduce, you can edit.

475
00:28:30.020 --> 00:28:33.080
I've found a scanner to be very useful.

476
00:28:33.080 --> 00:28:40.320
One particular example of where it was so
useful is I'd already traveled,

477
00:28:40.320 --> 00:28:44.800
and I was supposed to submit
a certain document to someone else.

478
00:28:44.800 --> 00:28:48.980
And I'd already left my home country,
and that document was urgently needed.

479
00:28:48.980 --> 00:28:52.800
And all I did is send a message to
someone, go pick that document,

480
00:28:52.800 --> 00:28:57.700
and scan it and send it that soft
copy to me exactly as I've written it

481
00:28:57.700 --> 00:28:59.270
with my signature over there.

482
00:28:59.270 --> 00:29:01.330
And then I attached it to someone else,
and

483
00:29:01.330 --> 00:29:04.509
in a matter of seconds that document was
available in another part of the world.

484
00:29:05.560 --> 00:29:08.510
So have you scanned something before,
Ronnie?

485
00:29:08.510 --> 00:29:12.860
>> I have used scanners quite often in
my life with dealing with computing.

486
00:29:12.860 --> 00:29:17.950
Scanners really do help us out in being
able to do what Doctor Tony talked about,

487
00:29:17.950 --> 00:29:23.130
digitizing a physical copy of something so
that we can store it as a file somewhere.

488
00:29:23.130 --> 00:29:26.250
And then that file can be delivered or
again, just stored.

489
00:29:26.250 --> 00:29:29.160
And then we can get rid of
the physical copy if we need to.

490
00:29:29.160 --> 00:29:32.570
Scanning technologies such as the flatbed
scanners have pretty much been traditional

491
00:29:32.570 --> 00:29:35.660
in businesses because a lot of
those documents do need to get

492
00:29:35.660 --> 00:29:37.010
converted that way.

493
00:29:37.010 --> 00:29:40.438
But Dr. Tonie, I actually have
a scanner on my smart phone.

494
00:29:40.438 --> 00:29:41.850
>> Mm-hm.
>> As well, and

495
00:29:41.850 --> 00:29:45.070
that type of scanner is
actually a software scanner.

496
00:29:45.070 --> 00:29:50.050
It’s an application that I downloaded and
was able to put onto my phone and

497
00:29:50.050 --> 00:29:53.800
now what I can do instead is I
can launch that application and

498
00:29:53.800 --> 00:29:58.330
it runs on my phone and it looks like
I'm taking a picture of that document.

499
00:29:58.330 --> 00:30:04.200
But when I do so with that application,
it digitizes what it sees.

500
00:30:04.200 --> 00:30:08.750
And that is what we call OCR,
optical character recognition.

501
00:30:08.750 --> 00:30:13.770
It literally can take that picture and
say, I'm going to translate that letter O

502
00:30:13.770 --> 00:30:19.150
into an actual font and
now that document can become editable.

503
00:30:19.150 --> 00:30:23.360
So in other words, I can now edit that
document if I need to to be able scan it.

504
00:30:23.360 --> 00:30:26.760
So I'm not actually just getting
a picture of the document, but

505
00:30:26.760 --> 00:30:29.130
actually something that is editable for

506
00:30:29.130 --> 00:30:33.510
me to be able to have, and
I could also use it for archival purposes.

507
00:30:33.510 --> 00:30:36.030
Now the one on my phone,
I don't use it for editing.

508
00:30:36.030 --> 00:30:40.310
I do use it for archival purposes instead
and you can find things like that, and

509
00:30:40.310 --> 00:30:45.860
that is because that technology has
actually developed so incredibly fast and

510
00:30:45.860 --> 00:30:51.560
so well that now any flatbed scanner

511
00:30:51.560 --> 00:30:57.330
used to cost two to three hundred dollars,
anybody can now download the app for $3.

512
00:30:57.330 --> 00:31:00.220
So it tells you how quickly
the market has dropped

513
00:31:00.220 --> 00:31:04.275
because now I can just take my phone and
do exactly the same thing page by page.

514
00:31:04.275 --> 00:31:07.140
Dr. Tani, if you told me that you
needed that and you were in Nairobi,

515
00:31:07.140 --> 00:31:10.430
right now I could go ahead and
say all right, here's that doc, and

516
00:31:10.430 --> 00:31:11.590
you said you need it scanned.

517
00:31:11.590 --> 00:31:13.510
I can scan it and then I email it to you.

518
00:31:13.510 --> 00:31:16.910
And you print it out, and it's just like
a scanner, exactly like a scanner, and

519
00:31:16.910 --> 00:31:18.780
that's exactly what you would see.

520
00:31:18.780 --> 00:31:23.410
And so it didn't even take me
having to get on anything else.

521
00:31:23.410 --> 00:31:26.810
The same device that I'm talking
to Dr Tonny on on my smartphone,

522
00:31:26.810 --> 00:31:30.650
I can scan the same device,
email it to him, all in one.

523
00:31:30.650 --> 00:31:32.955
Scanners are a really neat technology for
us.

524
00:31:32.955 --> 00:31:34.370
>> Mm-hm, wonderful.

525
00:31:34.370 --> 00:31:39.134
So we'll come to a close on the input
devices, but it's important for

526
00:31:39.134 --> 00:31:43.982
you to realize that there are other
common input devices that sometimes

527
00:31:43.982 --> 00:31:46.109
we don't think that they are.

528
00:31:46.109 --> 00:31:47.861
Think about a microphone.

529
00:31:47.861 --> 00:31:51.802
We can connect a microphone to
a computer and capture sound.

530
00:31:51.802 --> 00:31:55.023
All right, we can have headphones, and

531
00:31:55.023 --> 00:31:59.590
sometimes some of them have
an ability to capture sound.

532
00:31:59.590 --> 00:32:01.860
So that's another example
of an input device.

533
00:32:01.860 --> 00:32:07.900
So any voice recognition kind of a device
is actually an input device in itself,

534
00:32:07.900 --> 00:32:09.870
think about a camera.

535
00:32:09.870 --> 00:32:14.070
We can connect a camera to a computer,
and take photos or videos, or

536
00:32:14.070 --> 00:32:19.390
some computers actually have cameras
inbuilt into them, like laptops typically.

537
00:32:19.390 --> 00:32:23.400
Or you can mount a webcam onto a computer,
and

538
00:32:23.400 --> 00:32:28.650
that way you can have a conversation with
someone, and they actually see you live,

539
00:32:28.650 --> 00:32:32.360
almost live, so to speak,
on the other end of the conversation.

540
00:32:32.360 --> 00:32:38.540
You can have a physical camera
capturing what's happening on this end,

541
00:32:38.540 --> 00:32:42.920
and then as we speak right now, you're
probably seeing a presentation on screen.

542
00:32:42.920 --> 00:32:47.480
And we must have used an input device to
capture that content onto a computer,

543
00:32:47.480 --> 00:32:49.100
otherwise it will have
been very difficult.

544
00:32:50.230 --> 00:32:54.900
There are scanners that I use to capture

545
00:32:54.900 --> 00:33:00.210
content on a credit card or a debit card,
that's a typical card reader.

546
00:33:00.210 --> 00:33:03.920
We sometimes call magnetic card readers.

547
00:33:03.920 --> 00:33:08.610
You can swipe a card,
that's a form of input into a computer.

548
00:33:08.610 --> 00:33:12.949
And sometimes you can have fingerprint
readers, which are used now to identify

549
00:33:12.949 --> 00:33:16.837
people, because there's something
unique about your fingerprint,

550
00:33:16.837 --> 00:33:19.870
and that becomes a form
of input into a computer.

551
00:33:19.870 --> 00:33:27.080
Sometimes you can have, on smartphones
in particular, you can have QR codes.

552
00:33:27.080 --> 00:33:30.880
You have applications
that can capture content

553
00:33:30.880 --> 00:33:36.230
by reading the various codes
that are available out there.

554
00:33:36.230 --> 00:33:39.560
Sometimes we have bar code readers, yeah,

555
00:33:39.560 --> 00:33:44.486
which are used in supermarkets, or
shopping malls, or even petrol stations.

556
00:33:44.486 --> 00:33:48.000
In those kind of things, sometimes
when you drive around you can see

557
00:33:48.000 --> 00:33:50.980
something has captured
some details of your car.

558
00:33:50.980 --> 00:33:55.860
All those are possible different types
of imports they can be capturing

559
00:33:56.880 --> 00:34:02.240
light, sound, image,
text or whatever it is.

560
00:34:02.240 --> 00:34:07.062
So just get a set of those input devices,
and all that content goes into

561
00:34:07.062 --> 00:34:12.563
the computer and becomes digitized, and
becomes in form of binary form input.

562
00:34:12.563 --> 00:34:16.666
But the computer has a capacity to
understand all different kind of inputs

563
00:34:16.666 --> 00:34:19.800
and process them and
later on they become output.

564
00:34:19.800 --> 00:34:23.900
So in our next session we'll be
talking about output devices.

565
00:34:23.900 --> 00:34:28.065
>> All right, that sounds good, and
that means we are going to come back for

566
00:34:28.065 --> 00:34:31.365
a part two in input and
output as well as storage devices.

567
00:34:31.365 --> 00:34:34.560
So that's a great place for
us to also wrap this episode up.

568
00:34:34.560 --> 00:34:38.213
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong

569
00:34:38.213 --> 00:34:39.391
>> And my name is Dr.

570
00:34:39.391 --> 00:34:43.643
Tony Omwansa, enjoying having
learned together input devices

571
00:34:43.643 --> 00:34:45.297
>> Stay tuned right here for

572
00:34:45.297 --> 00:34:47.427
more computing fundamentals.

573
00:34:47.427 --> 00:34:53.676
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: in this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa discuss how to select storage.  They discuss the importance of choosing the right devices for the right context and settings and even the right software applications.  They show and discuss conventional hard drives, solid state, usb flash drives and even external usb drives..  They also discuss some of the useful criteria in selecting the storage that we may purchase.
episodes.title: Input, Output and Storage Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.201 --> 00:00:14.180
Welcome back to ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.180 --> 00:00:15.880
I’m your host, Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:15.880 --> 00:00:19.820
you're watching
the Computing Fundamentals IC3 show.

5
00:00:19.820 --> 00:00:21.630
Now, we're about to take a look into,

6
00:00:21.630 --> 00:00:26.600
well, the second part of input,
output, and storage devices.

7
00:00:26.600 --> 00:00:29.490
We're about to get in some
different output devices and

8
00:00:29.490 --> 00:00:32.347
who better to help us to understand
that than Dr. Tonny Omwansa.

9
00:00:32.347 --> 00:00:33.820
Dr. Omwansa, welcome back.

10
00:00:33.820 --> 00:00:34.800
>> Thank you very much,

11
00:00:34.800 --> 00:00:39.860
it's always a great pleasure to spend
time together thinking about technology.

12
00:00:39.860 --> 00:00:43.910
And thinking about output devices and
storage devices will be exciting.

13
00:00:43.910 --> 00:00:48.820
>> All right, so as we take a look here,
what we're now moving into is that

14
00:00:48.820 --> 00:00:52.830
realm of what we call output devices
>> When we have inputs such as when we

15
00:00:52.830 --> 00:00:56.300
actually type in something in our keyboard
or we move something around on the mouse,

16
00:00:56.300 --> 00:01:00.120
there has to be a way that confirms
that we're actually either clicking on

17
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:04.850
the right portion or actually typing in
the content that we believe that we need.

18
00:01:04.850 --> 00:01:07.920
And so we generally have output
devices that display for

19
00:01:07.920 --> 00:01:11.060
us the result of what we
actually have just done.

20
00:01:11.060 --> 00:01:14.260
So Dr. Tony there are many different types
of output devices what are we gonna talk

21
00:01:14.260 --> 00:01:15.760
about first?

22
00:01:15.760 --> 00:01:16.750
>> Well, there are so many.

23
00:01:16.750 --> 00:01:17.840
Actually there are very many and

24
00:01:17.840 --> 00:01:21.850
sometimes there some things we don't
quite think about them as output devices.

25
00:01:21.850 --> 00:01:23.130
So let's just take an example.

26
00:01:23.130 --> 00:01:25.140
There is a speaker.

27
00:01:25.140 --> 00:01:28.600
So some music was playing on
a computer and I can hear it somewhere.

28
00:01:28.600 --> 00:01:32.480
So it's basically getting out what is one
the computer and we're able to see it.

29
00:01:32.480 --> 00:01:33.670
Think about a printer.

30
00:01:33.670 --> 00:01:35.560
I printed something physical.

31
00:01:35.560 --> 00:01:39.460
Is actually an output devices calling
something off the computer and

32
00:01:39.460 --> 00:01:42.820
got it out somehow that
I can easily consume it.

33
00:01:42.820 --> 00:01:46.330
Or just think about what's being
displayed on the screen, so

34
00:01:46.330 --> 00:01:49.330
the screen is actively
acting as an output device.

35
00:01:49.330 --> 00:01:54.400
So anything that is able to get content
from the computer and display it or

36
00:01:54.400 --> 00:01:59.150
present it in a manner that we can consume
it, in a manner that we can understand it,

37
00:01:59.150 --> 00:02:02.140
then it becomes an output device.

38
00:02:02.140 --> 00:02:05.990
So a great place to start is to
think about the screens that we use.

39
00:02:05.990 --> 00:02:09.330
Different kind of screens and
different technologies that have

40
00:02:09.330 --> 00:02:13.040
evolved over time that enable
us to see things on-screen.

41
00:02:13.040 --> 00:02:18.380
Generally the one old technology that I
know is the cathode ray tube I remember,

42
00:02:18.380 --> 00:02:24.100
and we have this screen and
it's protruding backwards.

43
00:02:25.720 --> 00:02:30.470
And there is a technology that presents
content onto the screen itself.

44
00:02:30.470 --> 00:02:33.630
Ronnie, I think you understand
some of these physics in terms of

45
00:02:33.630 --> 00:02:37.100
how that cathode ray tube works
before we go into the LCD.

46
00:02:37.100 --> 00:02:41.220
>> When we start taking a look at
the idea of the cathode ray tube.

47
00:02:41.220 --> 00:02:45.360
What we really have in the background are
three different lights that essentially

48
00:02:45.360 --> 00:02:50.060
project the image that we're expecting
to see up against a phosphorus screen

49

The other day,

00:37:41.049 --> 00:37:48.407

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa introduce the basic operating system concept.  They discuss the functions every operating system does for the user.  They also mention and describe some of the most common operating systems based on device types, such as smartphones and tablets, desktops, and servers.  They also mention that the operating systems tend to have utilities to help maintain the operating system functions.  Lastly, they talk about the basics of a file system and how it helps to organize file management and even allows us to use some of the operating system utilities functions like compression, encryption, file extension and searching utilities at the file level.
episodes.title: Operating System Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa take a tour of the windows 7 operating systems.  They highlight the desktop interface, the basics of the start menu, using file explorer and working with files in Windows 7.  They demonstrate and point out certain elements and how to navigate around to find files, create files and even delete files.  The emphasize the need for the user to be familiar with navigating the operating system.
episodes.title: Introduction to Windows 7

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa discuss the different tools used for administration and maintenance in Windows 7.  They show how to create user accounts and explain the difference between standard user accounts and administrative user accounts.  They also describe some of the parental features and file permission can be used to control access to applications, games and files, respectively. Dr. Omwansa also describes some of the maintenance tools built into windows.  They end the episode by describing basic operating system troubleshooting.
episodes.title: Windows 7 Administration and Maintenance

you can see there is an option for

412
00:25:05.574 --> 00:25:07.174
Devices and Printers.

413
00:25:07.174 --> 00:25:10.471
You can go to the Control Panel and
find your way to the printers as well.

414
00:25:10.471 --> 00:25:16.630
But if I click right now here, I have
a set of Devices and Printers loading.

415
00:25:16.630 --> 00:25:18.380
Sometimes the computer gets a little slow.

416
00:25:18.380 --> 00:25:21.790
Maybe I need to defragment
mine as well [LAUGH].

417
00:25:21.790 --> 00:25:25.850
So when they load,
I'll have an opportunity to select

418
00:25:25.850 --> 00:25:29.300
which kind of printer do I want
to make a default printer,

419
00:25:29.300 --> 00:25:32.160
which one do I want to be non-default.

420
00:25:32.160 --> 00:25:35.450
And as you can see right here,
I've got a set of devices and

421
00:25:35.450 --> 00:25:41.250
I've got a set of printers which include a
fax, I didn't install all these printers.

422
00:25:41.250 --> 00:25:46.174
The one with the green tick over
here is considered the default.

423
00:25:46.174 --> 00:25:50.756
But if I come here and
click this, HP laserjet 3390,

424
00:25:50.756 --> 00:25:55.536
I can right-click it and
then I say Set as Default Printer.

425
00:25:55.536 --> 00:25:58.140
And then,
now that becomes my default printer,

426
00:25:58.140 --> 00:26:00.630
the green tick has already moved there.

427
00:26:00.630 --> 00:26:02.180
If I double click it,

428
00:26:02.180 --> 00:26:06.040
it will give me a sense of some
features about that particular printer.

429
00:26:06.040 --> 00:26:10.510
So I can see, I want to know what is
printing, so I double-click this.

430
00:26:10.510 --> 00:26:13.530
And now I can see,
something was actually printing.

431
00:26:13.530 --> 00:26:17.450
I had sent it, but then I disconnected
because I was in a hurry, and

432
00:26:17.450 --> 00:26:18.350
therefore it didn't print.

433
00:26:18.350 --> 00:26:23.187
And I could now click this particular
document, right-click it and restart or

434
00:26:23.187 --> 00:26:25.292
post or consolidate altogether.

435
00:26:25.292 --> 00:26:26.936
And it'll ask me, are you sure?

436
00:26:26.936 --> 00:26:28.906
And I'll say yes and it's gone.

437
00:26:28.906 --> 00:26:32.480
So then it means we'll never connect this
through the printer, it won't print again.

438
00:26:32.480 --> 00:26:35.670
Those are some of the things we need to
think about when maintaining the printer.

439
00:26:35.670 --> 00:26:37.820
>> There's no doubt that
as far as printers go,

440
00:26:37.820 --> 00:26:40.600
we do tend to see quite a few things.

441
00:26:40.600 --> 00:26:43.470
But overall though,
there's usually two mistakes that I make.

442
00:26:43.470 --> 00:26:47.868
One, is assuming that I've actually made
the default printer the right printer,

443
00:26:47.868 --> 00:26:50.000
depending on what network I'm on.

444
00:26:50.000 --> 00:26:53.010
So you always wanna think before
you hit the print button,

445
00:26:53.010 --> 00:26:56.020
verify that you've connected
to the right printer, as well.

446
00:26:56.020 --> 00:26:58.110
That's usually one of
the big ones that you have.

447
00:26:58.110 --> 00:27:00.800
And then the second one is
forgetting to turn the printer on,

448
00:27:00.800 --> 00:27:02.600
at least in my instance here.

449
00:27:02.600 --> 00:27:05.689
Is what I end up doing a lot of times is
just not realizing that the printer was

450
00:27:05.689 --> 00:27:07.270
turned off for one reason or another.

451
00:27:07.270 --> 00:27:11.606
Now Dr. Tonny we do have a little bit to
go as far as what we're talking about in

452
00:27:11.606 --> 00:27:13.611
maintenance and administration,

453
00:27:13.611 --> 00:27:17.160
which is moving into the idea
of basic troubleshooting.

454
00:27:17.160 --> 00:27:20.570
Windows 7 really does operate
by itself fairly well without

455
00:27:20.570 --> 00:27:23.950
a lot of me having to day to
day do some of these things.

456
00:27:23.950 --> 00:27:26.230
But we will encounter certain errors,
right?

457
00:27:26.230 --> 00:27:28.908
>> Yeah, you easily get into
trouble once in a while.

458
00:27:28.908 --> 00:27:30.800
Well, not really in a bad way, but

459
00:27:30.800 --> 00:27:34.140
sometimes the computer doesn't
function as you expect it.

460
00:27:34.140 --> 00:27:38.390
There are scenarios where, for example,
the computer may not just start up

461
00:27:38.390 --> 00:27:41.704
correctly, and all of a sudden you
are wondering what's going on.

462
00:27:41.704 --> 00:27:47.298
Or it's just looking a little sluggish,
and it's taking time to open documents and

463
00:27:47.298 --> 00:27:50.750
that might be to do with the memory or
things like that.

464
00:27:50.750 --> 00:27:53.620
Or just another message appears.

465
00:27:53.620 --> 00:27:56.090
Or sometimes an application is taking

466
00:27:56.090 --> 00:27:58.790
a little too long to
respond to instructions.

467
00:27:58.790 --> 00:28:02.670
Or it's simply just displaying and
you're trying to click and

468
00:28:02.670 --> 00:28:03.750
nothing is really happening.

469
00:28:03.750 --> 00:28:06.008
So such instances do happen, and

470
00:28:06.008 --> 00:28:09.887
we've got different kinds of
ways of dealing with this.

471
00:28:09.887 --> 00:28:16.301
I mean, the least of things that you can
do to solve this kind of problems is

472
00:28:16.301 --> 00:28:21.510
many and not always one particular
approach makes it work.

473
00:28:21.510 --> 00:28:24.470
So you have to be prepared,
at one point in time,

474
00:28:24.470 --> 00:28:26.410
you may have to restart the computer.

475
00:28:26.410 --> 00:28:27.300
At some point in time,

476
00:28:27.300 --> 00:28:32.070
you may have to deal with stopping
a particular application.

477
00:28:32.070 --> 00:28:35.100
Or you might be thinking
about defragmenting.

478
00:28:35.100 --> 00:28:38.440
So first of all, don't panic.

479
00:28:38.440 --> 00:28:39.560
I think that's the first thing.

480
00:28:39.560 --> 00:28:40.920
Cuz sometimes when we panic,

481
00:28:40.920 --> 00:28:44.630
we end up doing some things that end
up messing the computer even further.

482
00:28:44.630 --> 00:28:47.560
So the first thing is to
realize that it can happen.

483
00:28:47.560 --> 00:28:51.600
Just like you can get a cold or
a flu, it can happen, but

484
00:28:51.600 --> 00:28:53.130
that doesn't mean you're gonna be dead.

485
00:28:54.250 --> 00:28:58.540
You can just simply rest and
you can be fine.

486
00:28:58.540 --> 00:29:03.244
So in the context of the computer,
you wanna start asking yourself,

487
00:29:03.244 --> 00:29:07.940
is it possibly a hardware problem or
a software problem?

488
00:29:07.940 --> 00:29:13.390
Could it be a power related problem or
an application kind of related problem?

489
00:29:13.390 --> 00:29:18.280
First of all is to diagnose this,
what do you think it possibly could be?

490
00:29:18.280 --> 00:29:21.524
When you start seeing things slowing down,
you easily start thinking,

491
00:29:21.524 --> 00:29:23.079
well that could be either memory.

492
00:29:23.079 --> 00:29:29.090
Or there's a possibility that there's
overuse of certain resources.

493
00:29:29.090 --> 00:29:34.100
And probably there's a bit of confusion in
terms of how the resources are being used.

494
00:29:34.100 --> 00:29:36.720
So there may be specific things
that you could possibly do.

495
00:29:37.860 --> 00:29:42.170
We will list a few of them, for example,
I can decide to shut down a program.

496
00:29:43.600 --> 00:29:48.450
If I want to shut down a program, I can
go ahead and click the cancel button or

497
00:29:48.450 --> 00:29:53.440
close button, right, at the top left,
and I can restart it again.

498
00:29:53.440 --> 00:29:56.622
But sometimes I can click that one,
and for some reason,

499
00:29:56.622 --> 00:30:00.790
it's just not shutting down and
I'm wondering, it's taking a bit too long.

500
00:30:00.790 --> 00:30:05.181
So there's some tricks that we can use,
like very famous Ctrl+Alt+Del.

501
00:30:05.181 --> 00:30:08.830
Somebody will have to tell me,
how did that come about?

502
00:30:08.830 --> 00:30:15.730
So, if I click Ctrl+Alt+Del,
I can say Ctrl+Alt+Del, then what happens?

503
00:30:15.730 --> 00:30:20.380
On my screen,
I get to see options that have come up.

504
00:30:20.380 --> 00:30:25.390
There is an opportunity to lock
the computer, change the user, log off,

505
00:30:25.390 --> 00:30:27.830
change the password and Task Manager.

506
00:30:27.830 --> 00:30:30.890
Task Manager is a very
powerful tool that gets to

507
00:30:30.890 --> 00:30:33.640
give you a snapshot of how
your computer is performing.

508
00:30:33.640 --> 00:30:36.460
So if I click this,
maximize it just a little bit,

509
00:30:36.460 --> 00:30:39.530
it gives me a sense of the applications
that are currently running.

510
00:30:39.530 --> 00:30:41.490
I can see the processes.

511
00:30:41.490 --> 00:30:47.458
As you can tell, Chrome here, the exe,
there's several of them, how come?

512
00:30:47.458 --> 00:30:49.675
I only opened it once, how come?

513
00:30:49.675 --> 00:30:52.669
So it means something is
probably not working right.

514
00:30:52.669 --> 00:30:58.573
And remember, some of these are using some
resources that I don't need to be used.

515
00:30:58.573 --> 00:31:00.623
And I need to restart
some of these processes.

516
00:31:00.623 --> 00:31:04.683
The sense of performance over here is
giving you an indication of how the CPU is

517
00:31:04.683 --> 00:31:05.710
performing.

518
00:31:05.710 --> 00:31:06.810
How is it being used?

519
00:31:06.810 --> 00:31:07.500
What percentage?

520
00:31:07.500 --> 00:31:11.930
I can tell a sense of some of the users
that are currently using the computer.

521
00:31:11.930 --> 00:31:15.260
So it means for example, all of these
users are actually logged in but

522
00:31:15.260 --> 00:31:19.280
they were not all logged out and
that is potentially using some resources.

523
00:31:19.280 --> 00:31:24.518
So this is a very powerful tool that
you can get to see, like a snapshot,

524
00:31:24.518 --> 00:31:28.830
like a dashboard that gives you
a sense of what is the utilization.

525
00:31:28.830 --> 00:31:32.820
So if I decide, I think I need
to shut some things here, so

526
00:31:32.820 --> 00:31:37.960
I can come and click one of them and
then I end the process.

527
00:31:37.960 --> 00:31:40.910
When I end that process,
it's going to free up some space.

528
00:31:40.910 --> 00:31:46.120
If I say close, so some processing,
at least, will be restored.

529
00:31:46.120 --> 00:31:48.085
The CPU now has less work to do.

530
00:31:48.085 --> 00:31:50.560
Sometimes it's burdened by a lot of work.

531
00:31:50.560 --> 00:31:52.550
That's a typical example
of a tool we can use.

532
00:31:52.550 --> 00:31:54.547
We can talk a little bit about others,
but I don't know.

533
00:31:54.547 --> 00:31:58.216
Have you had some experience working
with this particular tool of

534
00:31:58.216 --> 00:31:59.490
the Taskbar Manager?

535
00:31:59.490 --> 00:32:03.550
>> [LAUGH] I have used it quite often
in helping When somebody's computer has

536
00:32:03.550 --> 00:32:06.888
actually kind of locked itself
up where it couldn't work.

537
00:32:06.888 --> 00:32:10.550
Now there's usually two types of errors
in that in the operating system.

538
00:32:10.550 --> 00:32:14.223
Either the entire Windows
environment itself can't work.

539
00:32:14.223 --> 00:32:16.291
And the way that you recognize
this is if you try and go and

540
00:32:16.291 --> 00:32:19.190
click on the Start button and
even the Start button won't work.

541
00:32:19.190 --> 00:32:20.800
But normally, Windows 7 is so

542
00:32:20.800 --> 00:32:24.910
good at managing all of the resources
that are available to you.

543
00:32:24.910 --> 00:32:29.730
Usually even if one application,
one tiny window locks up,

544
00:32:29.730 --> 00:32:32.430
the rest of the operating
system still continues to work.

545
00:32:32.430 --> 00:32:35.640
And that's what makes it so
good at what it does.

546
00:32:35.640 --> 00:32:39.683
If that one application stops working,
well, you can go and do what Dr.

547
00:32:39.683 --> 00:32:40.650
Tonny showed us.

548
00:32:40.650 --> 00:32:45.140
Which is to go into that taskbar and
into the Task Manager and

549
00:32:45.140 --> 00:32:47.680
then simply shut that program down.

550
00:32:47.680 --> 00:32:49.320
And then when you relaunch it again,

551
00:32:49.320 --> 00:32:53.120
you might find everything actually works
perfectly in the way that you want.

552
00:32:53.120 --> 00:32:56.160
The other thing that he mentioned at
the very beginning is what if it's

553
00:32:56.160 --> 00:33:00.560
not even going to allow you to
boot up the computer itself.

554
00:33:00.560 --> 00:33:03.320
That's where you need to decide
whether it's a hardware issue versus

555
00:33:03.320 --> 00:33:04.740
a software issue.

556
00:33:04.740 --> 00:33:07.070
And if you think that it's
the operating system,

557
00:33:07.070 --> 00:33:11.460
there is a mode that is called Safe Mode
that allows you to boot into it.

558
00:33:11.460 --> 00:33:14.830
Now, it's a little bit tricky but
it's fairly easy to do.

559
00:33:14.830 --> 00:33:18.500
When the computer is off and
as soon as you turn the power button on.

560
00:33:18.500 --> 00:33:19.850
What you're waiting for is it for

561
00:33:19.850 --> 00:33:24.980
it to get through its initial screen
where you see a logo just kind of pop up.

562
00:33:24.980 --> 00:33:31.240
But before the Windows logo pops up, you
need to hit the F8 keyon your keyboard.

563
00:33:31.240 --> 00:33:36.010
You can just tap on it and that will
launch you into what is called Safe Mode.

564
00:33:36.010 --> 00:33:41.301
Safe Mode is Windows 7, but
only the most minimal version of Window 7,

565
00:33:41.301 --> 00:33:45.490
it will look like a primary
school version of Windows 7.

566
00:33:45.490 --> 00:33:50.080
Nothing you want to work in, but
if you know that you can get access there,

567
00:33:50.080 --> 00:33:53.780
that means that the operating
system files itself are perfect.

568
00:33:53.780 --> 00:33:56.720
And that normally leads you to
being able to say all right,

569
00:33:56.720 --> 00:33:59.200
if the operating system files are perfect.

570
00:33:59.200 --> 00:34:04.890
Then something during start up that was
loaded is imperfect, it is not working.

571
00:34:04.890 --> 00:34:08.170
And this is where you can then just
reboot and then you can go back and

572
00:34:08.170 --> 00:34:10.280
use that tool that Dr.
Tonny was talking about.

573
00:34:10.280 --> 00:34:15.140
Again, in the Task Manager, and
go in and look at the Startup tab.

574
00:34:15.140 --> 00:34:18.191
And then simply uncheck
each one of those or

575
00:34:18.191 --> 00:34:22.103
you can uncheck all of them and
add them in one at a time.

576
00:34:22.103 --> 00:34:25.784
And when you end up with that
program that is now checked,

577
00:34:25.784 --> 00:34:28.400
that loads up at the boot time.

578
00:34:28.400 --> 00:34:32.410
Then you know that that is the program
that is causing you an issue.

579
00:34:32.410 --> 00:34:35.850
So you can use all these tools in
conjunction to help you to troubleshoot

580
00:34:35.850 --> 00:34:37.082
Windows 7.

581
00:34:37.082 --> 00:34:40.890
Very effectively,
if you will take the time to try and

582
00:34:40.890 --> 00:34:43.100
learn them a little bit on your own.

583
00:34:43.100 --> 00:34:45.000
So in other words, don't just watch this,

584
00:34:45.000 --> 00:34:47.020
I know everything that there is
to know about troubleshooting.

585
00:34:47.020 --> 00:34:50.580
But you've gotta take these skills that
we've talked about and apply them.

586
00:34:50.580 --> 00:34:51.970
And that's really the key and

587
00:34:51.970 --> 00:34:55.510
the more often you do it, the better
you will become at troubleshooting.

588
00:34:55.510 --> 00:34:59.780
All right, Doctor Tonny, any last words
before we close out of this episode.

589
00:34:59.780 --> 00:35:02.070
>> I think I would just
mention two more things.

590
00:35:02.070 --> 00:35:06.443
Sometimes you can try even to press
that Control + Alt + Delete and

591
00:35:06.443 --> 00:35:11.225
you try to go that application that
enables you to see that performance.

592
00:35:11.225 --> 00:35:14.990
And for example, is probably not even
responding and you're wondering.

593
00:35:14.990 --> 00:35:19.380
So sometimes restarting
the computer happens to be a very

594
00:35:19.380 --> 00:35:24.320
useful mechanism of restoring and
troubleshooting your computer.

595
00:35:24.320 --> 00:35:29.070
So you would just press the start
button for a few seconds and

596
00:35:29.070 --> 00:35:30.980
then you will automatically go off.

597
00:35:30.980 --> 00:35:34.380
And then you'll press it again and
then you'll come back and

598
00:35:34.380 --> 00:35:37.080
then the operating system and
the system software

599
00:35:37.080 --> 00:35:41.260
will just kind of reorganize itself again
and then a computer starts to function.

600
00:35:41.260 --> 00:35:46.430
The other thing that I think is important
to know is that there is a help function.

601
00:35:46.430 --> 00:35:51.220
So every time since you have a problem and
you really don't understand what to do,

602
00:35:51.220 --> 00:35:54.420
this episode of course has
given you some insights.

603
00:35:54.420 --> 00:35:56.400
You can read, follow if you want.

604
00:35:56.400 --> 00:35:59.380
But right there, if you don't have
an opportunity to find a book or

605
00:35:59.380 --> 00:36:03.410
anything like that, you can press
the F1 button and then there you go.

606
00:36:03.410 --> 00:36:06.880
It gives you help function and
then you can read and

607
00:36:06.880 --> 00:36:10.160
then you can figure out what you
can possibly do in that context.

608
00:36:10.160 --> 00:36:13.990
So with that kind of information, we
wanna believe that somehow you empowered

609
00:36:13.990 --> 00:36:18.120
a little bit to troubleshoot your
computer when it has a problem.

610
00:36:18.120 --> 00:36:21.210
That if you're not able to fix it and

611
00:36:21.210 --> 00:36:24.750
you have a technician anywhere nearby,
you can reach out to them.

612
00:36:25.768 --> 00:36:27.620
Try to be the network of one or

613
00:36:27.620 --> 00:36:32.450
two persons you can call and
you can get your problem solved.

614
00:36:32.450 --> 00:36:36.141
But do remember that the computer
also has a lifetime,

615
00:36:36.141 --> 00:36:41.680
it's not a permanent device that never
gets old [LAUGH] at some point in time.

616
00:36:41.680 --> 00:36:46.530
It will have served this purpose and then
you probably have to make a replacement.

617
00:36:46.530 --> 00:36:51.160
Buy a new one because sometimes as it gets
a little older, you try to troubleshoot,

618
00:36:51.160 --> 00:36:53.613
it seems to be taking
back to where you are.

619
00:36:53.613 --> 00:36:58.080
And then now you're studying should spend
a bit too much time and effort on it.

620
00:36:58.080 --> 00:37:01.570
And even when you try to upgrade it, it's
now starting to cost you a little more.

621
00:37:01.570 --> 00:37:04.910
So there's a point in time,
because it depreciates over time,

622
00:37:04.910 --> 00:37:09.326
it's an electronic device and you will
replace, so I do hope that this is useful.

623
00:37:09.326 --> 00:37:13.999
>> All right, Dr. Tonny, thank you again
for helping us in understanding more about

624
00:37:13.999 --> 00:37:17.150
the administration and
the maintenance of Windows 7.

625
00:37:17.150 --> 00:37:20.410
And it's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

626
00:37:20.410 --> 00:37:23.820
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

627
00:37:23.820 --> 00:37:29.070
>> And my name is Dr. Tonny Omwanza,
enjoy learning together on Windows 7.

628
00:37:29.070 --> 00:37:32.194
>> All right, thank you and
thank you for watching and

629
00:37:32.194 --> 00:37:35.401
come back right here more
computing fundamentals.

630
00:37:35.401 --> 00:37:45.401
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa describe application software types computer users will normally use on a day by day basis.  They describe a few categories of software:  Business Productivity, Specialized software, and entertainment software.  Dr. Omwansa describe the usage of each category of software, emphasizing the business productivity software.
episodes.title: Understanding Application Software
episodes.transcript: WEBVTT

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa describe the microsoft office 2010 productivity suite.  They emphasize nature of the user interface and it’s consistency across Microsoft Word, Excel, Powerpoint and to an extent Microsoft Access.  Dr. Omwansa emphasizes this interface consistency will make it easier for users to learn the different products.
episodes.title: Introduction to Microsoft Office 2010
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.114 --> 00:00:10.114
[MUSIC]

2

Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.710 --> 00:00:19.660
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and you're
watching the computer fundamentals IC3

4
00:00:19.660 --> 00:00:25.370
show where we're taking a look now into
the realm of business productivity suites.

5

More specifically, gonna be talking
about Microsoft Office itself, 2010.

6
00:00:28.800 --> 00:00:32.440
Making sure that we understand some
of the different concepts there.

7
00:00:32.440 --> 00:00:35.968
And who better to help us than Dr.
Tonny Omwansa today?

8

So Dr. Tonny, welcome back to our studios.

9

>> Thank you very much for having me.

10

It's always good being here and
using this as a forum to learn and

11
00:00:43.740 --> 00:00:48.750
exchange knowledge, so
we get better in improving our services,

12
00:00:48.750 --> 00:00:50.740
our work environment and the like.

13
00:00:50.740 --> 00:00:55.520
So today, if you have been with us,
now we are zooming in to

14
00:00:55.520 --> 00:00:58.930
some very specific things,

15

If you haven't watched the previous shows,
maybe you may want to go and

17
00:01:06.880 --> 00:01:11.300
>> Okay, so when we start talking about
the idea of using Microsoft Office and

18
00:01:11.300 --> 00:01:15.340
sticking with this one productivity suite,
some of the things that we're gonna end up

seeing is that it actually really helps us
out when we choose one particular suite.

20
00:01:20.340 --> 00:01:23.695
Microsoft Office is one of the most
popular ones out there, and Dr.

21

Tonny is actually gonna show us why.

22
00:01:25.300 --> 00:01:28.430
And when we start taking we've got
some of the different products,

23
00:01:28.430 --> 00:01:30.910
we're gonna see some very
familiar interfaces to them.

24
00:01:30.910 --> 00:01:33.772
And we're actually gonna see why
it's actually worth our time

25
00:01:33.772 --> 00:01:37.012
in getting used to learning about
this one particular product as well.

26
00:01:37.012 --> 00:01:39.490
So Dr. Tonny,
what are we gonna start off with?

27
00:01:39.490 --> 00:01:40.250
>> All right great,

28
00:01:40.250 --> 00:01:44.850
as we spoke last time, this suite
entails several specific products.

29
00:01:44.850 --> 00:01:47.720
We've got Microsoft Word,
we've got Microsoft Excel,

30
00:01:47.720 --> 00:01:51.310

and Microsoft PowerPoint.

31
00:01:51.310 --> 00:01:55.130
And if you looked at it last time,
there's something common about them,

32
00:01:55.130 --> 00:01:57.600
that some elements are generic about them.

33
00:01:57.600 --> 00:02:01.738
So, we're gonna spend some time in this
particular show to think about what

34
00:02:01.738 --> 00:02:06.137
are some of the generic things that once
we've learnt them we just now continue to

35
00:02:06.137 --> 00:02:10.033
use them irrespective of which
product we're gonna spend our time on.

36
00:02:10.033 --> 00:02:11.049
[COUGH].

37
00:02:11.049 --> 00:02:15.149
So we're going to start identifying
some of the basic parts

38
00:02:15.149 --> 00:02:17.855
of Microsoft application interface.

39
00:02:19.645 --> 00:02:24.205
We'll think about the common features

40
00:02:24.205 --> 00:02:28.165
We'll think about how do you open,
how do you save, how do you create files,

41
00:02:28.165 --> 00:02:30.425
how do you name files and the like.

42
00:02:30.425 --> 00:02:32.903
And then we'll think about maybe
you want to email something or

43
00:02:32.903 --> 00:02:34.560
you want to print something.

44
00:02:34.560 --> 00:02:40.110
And finally, how do you adjust certain
elements of a specific application?

45
00:02:40.110 --> 00:02:45.000
That's what we're, we'll see how
far we'll go hopefully we finish.

46
00:02:45.000 --> 00:02:48.200
>> There's no doubt that a lot of
times what ends up happening is you

47
00:02:48.200 --> 00:02:51.330
choose let's say different products for
each thing that you want to do,

48
00:02:51.330 --> 00:02:55.590
you end up having actually relearn
a product again because the environment or

49
00:02:55.590 --> 00:02:57.180
the interface is so different.

50
00:02:57.180 --> 00:03:01.130
What we're about to see here is by
choosing this one entire suite which

51
00:03:01.130 --> 00:03:04.690
encompasses all those products that we've
talked about in our previous episode,

52
00:03:04.690 --> 00:03:07.020
Microsoft Word, Excel, PowerPoint and

53
00:03:07.020 --> 00:03:09.920
Access, that there are a lot
of commonalities there.

54
00:03:09.920 --> 00:03:13.230
And what that actually mean for
us is that the knowledge transfers over.

55
00:03:13.230 --> 00:03:16.020
If you actually learn about one
product where certain things are,

56
00:03:16.020 --> 00:03:18.040
you'll actually be able to
carry that over to other ones.

57
00:03:18.040 --> 00:03:20.276
So what are we gonna see first Dr. Tonny?

58
00:03:20.276 --> 00:03:23.320
>> Okay, great.

59
00:03:23.320 --> 00:03:27.246
The one thing I like about computing is
that it borrows a lot from real life.

60
00:03:27.246 --> 00:03:30.980
When we say memory, so
we talk about memory in a computer,

61
00:03:30.980 --> 00:03:32.760
but that's also how we memorize.

62
00:03:32.760 --> 00:03:38.950
We think about a dialogue box, or we think
about a tab, or we think about storage.

63
00:03:38.950 --> 00:03:40.840
That's what we do,
that's how we process things.

64
00:03:40.840 --> 00:03:44.550
So, we're gonna learn a few terminologies
and we're gonna demonstrate that

65
00:03:44.550 --> 00:03:48.070
physically here, on the computer,
so that you appreciate.

66
00:03:48.070 --> 00:03:51.290
So a great place to start is
let's open Microsoft Word.

67
00:03:52.300 --> 00:03:55.900
So there I am,
I'm opening Microsoft Word as I did before

68
00:03:58.000 --> 00:04:02.740
on to the programs,
on to Microsoft Office, and there I am.

69
00:04:02.740 --> 00:04:05.130
Microsoft Word 2010.

70
00:04:05.130 --> 00:04:10.860
Now right before I go into this, you
will notice, even if I opened Excel and

71
00:04:10.860 --> 00:04:16.650
Access, particularly Access, you'll
see certain elements that are similar.

72
00:04:16.650 --> 00:04:17.560
So, and that's fine.

73
00:04:17.560 --> 00:04:19.090
That's why we're here.

74
00:04:19.090 --> 00:04:23.140
So to start off, I think one thing
that we need to appreciate is that

75
00:04:23.140 --> 00:04:25.900
you can see tabs appear.

76
00:04:25.900 --> 00:04:28.370
You can see things organized
in certain groups.

77
00:04:28.370 --> 00:04:31.960
It's important to appreciate
what each of these is about.

78
00:04:31.960 --> 00:04:36.300
Earlier versions of Microsoft Word
were a little different.

79
00:04:36.300 --> 00:04:38.690
This is a way of grouping things so

80
00:04:38.690 --> 00:04:44.500
that things that are related are grouped
together and you can easily add things.

81
00:04:44.500 --> 00:04:47.060
You can configure this to add things.

82
00:04:47.060 --> 00:04:50.120
So let's start off with a first step for
example.

83
00:04:50.120 --> 00:04:56.940
This is telling me about how to
manipulate text that I already have put.

84
00:04:56.940 --> 00:05:00.600
So assuming I had a word here, word.

85
00:05:00.600 --> 00:05:02.350
I would try to increase that font.

86
00:05:02.350 --> 00:05:04.757
Now don't worry exactly how
I'm doing it for now, but

87
00:05:04.757 --> 00:05:06.810
I'm going to simply
illustrate a few things.

88
00:05:06.810 --> 00:05:11.220
So I can click this and I can select it.

89
00:05:11.220 --> 00:05:15.610
I now have selected this word, and
therefore I can do something with it.

90
00:05:15.610 --> 00:05:19.290
I can make it bold,
I can change the color.

91
00:05:20.630 --> 00:05:24.840
I can underline it,
don't worry exactly how I'm doing it but

92
00:05:24.840 --> 00:05:27.010
the point is that it's doable.

93
00:05:27.010 --> 00:05:30.850
I can increase the font size,
I can make it italicized.

94
00:05:30.850 --> 00:05:31.930
Now what I'm doing here?

95
00:05:31.930 --> 00:05:34.270
I'm manipulating text in this section.

96
00:05:34.270 --> 00:05:39.660
So to just give you a little more
insight into that, we can group things.

97
00:05:39.660 --> 00:05:44.490
So what I've done here is that I've taken
a section to explain is that look, there's

98
00:05:44.490 --> 00:05:48.870
something called a group which basically
is a named section of a ribbon tab.

99
00:05:48.870 --> 00:05:54.800
So each of these sections
can be considered as one.

100
00:05:54.800 --> 00:05:57.330
We've grouped it, we've got to Insert.

101
00:05:57.330 --> 00:06:01.610
If you go to Page Layout,
you can see a line here and a line here.

102
00:06:01.610 --> 00:06:04.770
This is some kind of a group and
it is named down here, so

103
00:06:04.770 --> 00:06:09.970
this is a page setup group, or
a background group or paragraph group.

104
00:06:09.970 --> 00:06:11.200
Or theme group.

105
00:06:11.200 --> 00:06:13.670
If I go back home we've got
something about paragraph,

106
00:06:13.670 --> 00:06:15.240
we've got something about font.

107
00:06:15.240 --> 00:06:17.910
If I go to review we've got
something about tracking,

108
00:06:17.910 --> 00:06:19.500
we've got something about changing.

109
00:06:19.500 --> 00:06:24.280
So, things are organized in groups so that
things that are related just like we spoke

110
00:06:24.280 --> 00:06:29.432
about Access earlier on, the things that
are related tends to be grouped together.

111
00:06:29.432 --> 00:06:34.070
So that's one important thing in thinking
about the interface of Microsoft Office

112
00:06:34.070 --> 00:06:38.937
and that kind of applies in a number
of these other application softwares.

113
00:06:38.937 --> 00:06:40.415
>> All right.

114
00:06:40.415 --> 00:06:44.505
So, when we start seeing this idea of
these different types of things that he

115
00:06:44.505 --> 00:06:48.205
showed us on the home tab, what we're
seeing is that they're also sub-divided

116
00:06:48.205 --> 00:06:51.295
up into those different groupings to
allow us to get the functionality.

117
00:06:51.295 --> 00:06:54.575
And underneath each one of those groups
is, normally, the name of that group.

118
00:06:54.575 --> 00:06:57.255
And that really helps you
out when you're looking for

119
00:06:57.255 --> 00:07:00.405
a particular functionality,
to be able to go, and go, all right,

120
00:07:00.405 --> 00:07:04.010
underneath this particular group for
editing, or for cut, copy and

121
00:07:04.010 --> 00:07:07.680
paste you'll actually see that they
normally show little icons that would

122
00:07:07.680 --> 00:07:12.780
show you images that actually do
relate to what is going to be.

123
00:07:12.780 --> 00:07:15.695
The other thing that we also will
end up seeing is that throughout

124
00:07:15.695 --> 00:07:19.475
whatever program, even though
Dr Tonny showed us this in Word,

125
00:07:19.475 --> 00:07:23.925
that if you open up Excel,
you'll get the same familiarity.

126
00:07:23.925 --> 00:07:26.255
Si if you're just used to
working in Word and you go,

127
00:07:26.255 --> 00:07:28.485
I've never worked in Excel before.

128
00:07:28.485 --> 00:07:31.131
Once you open it up and
you'll see that same idea,

129
00:07:31.131 --> 00:07:34.974
you'll actually see that working
inside of each one of those programs,

130
00:07:34.974 --> 00:07:37.431
even though they will
actually be different,

131
00:07:37.431 --> 00:07:41.778
a lot of the processes that you and I will
use between them will feel very familiar,

132
00:07:41.778 --> 00:07:44.313
and even intuitive at
times to help us out here.

133
00:07:44.313 --> 00:07:46.420
Now, when we start seeing that, right?

134
00:07:46.420 --> 00:07:47.495
It helps us here.

135
00:07:47.495 --> 00:07:50.367
Because what we're gonna go over later on,
right, is that Dr.

136
00:07:50.367 --> 00:07:53.201
Tonny is gonna lead us through
each one of these applications.

137
00:07:53.201 --> 00:07:56.929
And what we're establishing now is
the terminology that he'll be using So

138
00:07:56.929 --> 00:08:00.537
that way you can follow along on your
own with these programs as well, and

139
00:08:00.537 --> 00:08:03.794
understand exactly where he's
actually going to be clicking and

140
00:08:03.794 --> 00:08:08.010
what he's gonna be showing us, and
how to do the things that we need to do.

141
00:08:08.010 --> 00:08:10.930
But becoming familiar with that
interface is pretty much the key,

142
00:08:10.930 --> 00:08:14.630
when you start taking look at something
like the groups and the tabs.

143
00:08:14.630 --> 00:08:18.720
Now, the top part of that screen that
we are seeing on Dr Tony's computer.

144
00:08:18.720 --> 00:08:23.780
That is also called the ribbon interface
too and that is because it has a ribbon of

145
00:08:23.780 --> 00:08:29.450
those different icons and text across the
top and it doesn't cover any of the area

146
00:08:29.450 --> 00:08:34.280
that we saw on the word processing itself,
and you'll see that.

147
00:08:34.280 --> 00:08:37.090
Nothing, actually,
kinda pulls down and drops down

148
00:08:37.090 --> 00:08:40.610
over the area that you're working in,
but, actually, slides as a ribbon.

149
00:08:40.610 --> 00:08:44.282
You click on another tab above that
to the right, you actually see that.

150
00:08:44.282 --> 00:08:47.380
It will just switch, and so you'll
actually see different elements, but

151
00:08:47.380 --> 00:08:50.530
none of it ever covers the area
that you're actually working in

152
00:08:50.530 --> 00:08:52.720
at that particular point in time.

153
00:08:52.720 --> 00:08:56.733
So when you start seeing those types
of element you again are gonna see them

154
00:08:56.733 --> 00:09:01.070
across multiple interfaces or multiple
applications that we're gonna see and

155
00:09:01.070 --> 00:09:05.208
hopefully you'll say all right, I know I
can work in that cuz I did it in Word I

156
00:09:05.208 --> 00:09:09.350
know it gonna work the same in Excel,
and probably the same in PowerPoint and

157
00:09:09.350 --> 00:09:11.644
even the same in Access
a lot of the times.

158
00:09:11.644 --> 00:09:14.829
>> Great, now after spending some
time think about the ribbon,

159
00:09:14.829 --> 00:09:16.625
let's go to the base of that page.

160
00:09:16.625 --> 00:09:20.990
The base of that page is a status bar, so

161
00:09:20.990 --> 00:09:24.310
it gives us a sense of
the status of the document.

162
00:09:24.310 --> 00:09:30.250
So let's look at my example here, so
if I copy this word and I put four of them

163
00:09:30.250 --> 00:09:34.980
at the base somewhere here, at the status
bar, you can see that I have four words.

164
00:09:34.980 --> 00:09:40.630
Now, of course,
if I reduce they're becoming three,

165
00:09:40.630 --> 00:09:45.190
if I increase the number of pages,
the number of pages now have become two,

166
00:09:45.190 --> 00:09:49.323
so if I come to the right and
I try to reduce the,

167
00:09:49.323 --> 00:09:54.670
I zoom in, I zoom in, I zoom in now it
tells me that I actually have two pages.

168
00:09:54.670 --> 00:09:58.490
So, the status bar gives you
an opportunity to think about

169
00:09:58.490 --> 00:10:00.620
how does the whole document
generally look like.

170
00:10:00.620 --> 00:10:05.170
If I want to do some counting of words,
if I select some words and

171
00:10:05.170 --> 00:10:09.610
I want to know, how many are they,
how many characters are there.

172
00:10:09.610 --> 00:10:12.390
So, it gives you a sense
of the document itself.

173
00:10:13.570 --> 00:10:18.140
All right, so at the top,
once we've opened the document.

174
00:10:18.140 --> 00:10:23.100
So let's say I want to
manipulate this document,

175
00:10:23.100 --> 00:10:25.820
there are a number of
things I could do with it.

176
00:10:25.820 --> 00:10:32.220
And the typical, Microsoft document
there's always an opportunity

177
00:10:32.220 --> 00:10:37.480
to minimize it, an opportunity to maximize
it, and an opportunity to close it.

178
00:10:37.480 --> 00:10:41.290
So, let's look at the top
right corner of this window.

179
00:10:41.290 --> 00:10:45.420
So, at the top right corner, the last,
and it's almost, most of the time, red,

180
00:10:45.420 --> 00:10:48.580
and, I think, because he wanted to tell
you, ho, are you sure you want to do that?

181
00:10:48.580 --> 00:10:50.720
So, it is an x over there,
you can see an x.

182
00:10:50.720 --> 00:10:56.040
The x is for closing that document so
if I click it, it will always ask me.

183
00:10:56.040 --> 00:10:59.490
Turns like a prompt and tells me do
you want to save that document or

184
00:10:59.490 --> 00:11:01.860
you don't want to save or
you want to cancel.

185
00:11:01.860 --> 00:11:06.820
Saving means, it is going to retain the
content that you've already worked on and

186
00:11:06.820 --> 00:11:07.990
we will give it a name so

187
00:11:07.990 --> 00:11:11.130
that every time you want to come
back to it you can always open it.

188
00:11:11.130 --> 00:11:15.830
Don't save simply means, it means you're
gonna lose everything you've been working

189
00:11:15.830 --> 00:11:17.430
on, if at all you are working on anything,
so

190
00:11:17.430 --> 00:11:20.870
it's not going to save that document,
none of the content.

191
00:11:20.870 --> 00:11:23.670
Cancel means let's go back
to exactly where we are, so

192
00:11:23.670 --> 00:11:26.150
don't do anything, right there.

193
00:11:26.150 --> 00:11:28.830
That's the first button on extreme right.

194
00:11:28.830 --> 00:11:30.420
Next is restore.

195
00:11:30.420 --> 00:11:35.390
It means well, take it back to the exact
position it was in the previous so

196
00:11:35.390 --> 00:11:37.910
if I have moved this document
to some point in time and

197
00:11:37.910 --> 00:11:41.590
then I maximize it, I have an opportunity
to return it to the way it was.

198
00:11:41.590 --> 00:11:44.103
If let's say I was working on
four documents at the same time.

199
00:11:44.103 --> 00:11:46.600
So maybe this was on
the left top right corner.

200
00:11:46.600 --> 00:11:52.500
And then I say, I've maximized it and
then I go back to that, I have resized it.

201
00:11:52.500 --> 00:11:55.232
It goes back to exactly
the way it was physically.

202
00:11:55.232 --> 00:11:57.917
And then the last one,
which is one of those three, is minimize.

203
00:11:57.917 --> 00:12:01.399
It means bring it right to the bottom
here, so I wouldn't see it, but

204
00:12:01.399 --> 00:12:05.301
at least I can see some kind of a short
cut, something that tells me, ah-ha,

205
00:12:05.301 --> 00:12:07.847
if I want to go back to it,
I can always point at it.

206
00:12:07.847 --> 00:12:12.134
So for now, it is minimized and
I can always restore that one and pick,

207
00:12:12.134 --> 00:12:16.784
if I have several documents at the same
time, so now I go back to my document,

208
00:12:16.784 --> 00:12:20.100
it goes to the resized position and
I can maximize it.

209
00:12:20.100 --> 00:12:22.800
So there you're playing around with
a particular document that you've

210
00:12:22.800 --> 00:12:24.030
already opened.

211
00:12:24.030 --> 00:12:26.512
You have an opportunity to
look at the status bar.

212
00:12:26.512 --> 00:12:30.221
And you can close it, you can resize it,
and you can minimize it.

213
00:12:30.221 --> 00:12:32.290
How is that Ronald?

214
00:12:32.290 --> 00:12:36.408
>> Yeah, that's a great part of the actual
control of the application that we're

215
00:12:36.408 --> 00:12:37.338
taking a look at.

216
00:12:37.338 --> 00:12:41.020
By using the Close, we can close
out of that entire application for

217
00:12:41.020 --> 00:12:43.672
the instance that we've
actually got it open.

218
00:12:43.672 --> 00:12:45.157

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa continue to demonstrate features of the common shared interface in Office 2010.  They emphasize that learning these features helps the user to feel confident that they control the Microsoft Office 2010 environment regardless of which product they are using.  They also show how to save and name files to a location to help them to reuse it later as well as how to print when needing a hard copy of their work.
