00:30:28.190 --> 00:30:33.520
You can get options that Microsoft Word
thinks could be what you mean.

528
00:30:33.520 --> 00:30:36.278
So you could select the one
that you think is correct.

529
00:30:36.278 --> 00:30:40.595
So that opportunity, it just helping us so

530
00:30:40.595 --> 00:30:44.805
that we don't always,
if we forget to change words or

531
00:30:44.805 --> 00:30:49.925
spelled incorrectly, we get an reminder
just by putting some red underline there.

532
00:30:49.925 --> 00:30:52.335
I get a reminder,
possibly your word is incorrect.

533
00:30:52.335 --> 00:30:53.685
So you can change.

534
00:30:53.685 --> 00:30:56.195
Another way,
assuming that there was several words that

535
00:30:56.195 --> 00:30:59.565
you actually you made a mistake on and
that can happen.

536
00:30:59.565 --> 00:31:04.840
So I have three of them
here in this document, it's

537
00:31:04.840 --> 00:31:08.950
good to learn a few shortcuts so every
time we talk about something on the menu,

538
00:31:08.950 --> 00:31:12.230
we also give some shortcuts,
in this case, I will give a shortcut.

539
00:31:12.230 --> 00:31:15.100
So if I wanted to do a spell
checking mechanism for

540
00:31:15.100 --> 00:31:18.160
the entire document, I can press F7.

541
00:31:18.160 --> 00:31:22.062
When I press F7,
what basically the Microsoft Word does,

542
00:31:22.062 --> 00:31:26.508
it runs through and picks certain words,
check things one by one and

543
00:31:26.508 --> 00:31:30.428
asks you to make a suggestion
of what you want for that word.

544
00:31:30.428 --> 00:31:31.587
So, same, I can see,

545
00:31:31.587 --> 00:31:34.920
it gives me a suggestion that
maybe you wanted to say same.

546
00:31:34.920 --> 00:31:36.800
So in which case I say change.

547
00:31:36.800 --> 00:31:37.890
So that's changed it.

548
00:31:37.890 --> 00:31:39.330
I can see documents.

549
00:31:39.330 --> 00:31:40.680
I'd put double s.

550
00:31:40.680 --> 00:31:41.650
I say change.

551
00:31:41.650 --> 00:31:43.300
If I feel that one is correct.

552
00:31:43.300 --> 00:31:46.000
I can ignore it, but for
sure in this should be changed.

553
00:31:46.000 --> 00:31:48.280
Application, I've also changed it,
all right.

554
00:31:48.280 --> 00:31:52.020
And finally it says the spelling and
grammar check is complete.

555
00:31:52.020 --> 00:31:53.720
Now I'm done so I say OK.

556
00:31:53.720 --> 00:31:55.807
So my document looks good.

557
00:31:55.807 --> 00:31:58.604
It might have some problems even when
the spell checker is complete because it

558
00:31:58.604 --> 00:32:00.594
depends on how the spell
checker has been configured.

559
00:32:00.594 --> 00:32:04.484
But this is here we are.

560
00:32:04.484 --> 00:32:07.016
So we can take ones, we can change ones,

561
00:32:07.016 --> 00:32:10.510
and we are helped when we
are changing this ones.

562
00:32:10.510 --> 00:32:14.050
The last thing, so
that we can close the show, is printing.

563
00:32:14.050 --> 00:32:17.257
So once I created this document,
when I'm doing Microsoft one or

564
00:32:17.257 --> 00:32:21.470
PowerPoint or Excel, I can possibly
print this and create a physical copy.

565
00:32:21.470 --> 00:32:26.680
So what I would do is I'd go to File and
I get an option Print.

566
00:32:26.680 --> 00:32:31.530
Just, if I also may help,
I can give you a shortcut, Control P.

567
00:32:31.530 --> 00:32:33.860
Boom, takes me to the same spot.

568
00:32:33.860 --> 00:32:36.880
At that point in time,
I can click the print button and

569
00:32:36.880 --> 00:32:39.420
it will send the document to the printer.

570
00:32:39.420 --> 00:32:43.690
It is assumed in this case that
the printer has been installed and

571
00:32:43.690 --> 00:32:47.570
configured properly, because I can send
and I'm wondering wow, I'm waiting for

572
00:32:47.570 --> 00:32:49.440
the document to come out, but it's not.

573
00:32:49.440 --> 00:32:50.900
So the printer must have been installed,

574
00:32:50.900 --> 00:32:53.780
which is an output device
from the particular computer.

575
00:32:53.780 --> 00:32:56.450
It could be a printer
connected in a network or

576
00:32:56.450 --> 00:32:59.550
directly to this particular computer,
and I can send.

577
00:32:59.550 --> 00:33:04.035
I can make a few changes here,
like I can say I want two copies or

578
00:33:04.035 --> 00:33:08.604
I want page one to five,
I don't want to print all the pages, or

579
00:33:08.604 --> 00:33:12.249
I want to print back to back,
whatever settings.

580
00:33:12.249 --> 00:33:15.619
But the point is that it is possible to
print your document once you've worked on

581
00:33:15.619 --> 00:33:17.240
it and you're very happy.

582
00:33:17.240 --> 00:33:20.020
The beauty about printing is that it
can give you an opportunity to review

583
00:33:20.020 --> 00:33:20.680
the document and

584
00:33:20.680 --> 00:33:25.200
see how it looks physically in as much as
it's been shown on screen how it may look.

585
00:33:25.200 --> 00:33:27.130
You can give people to comment and

586
00:33:27.130 --> 00:33:30.310
then you can come back to your
document and finally edit it.

587
00:33:30.310 --> 00:33:31.680
There are other ways of doing it.

588
00:33:31.680 --> 00:33:37.140
But last, printing is a powerful tool
that you can use in Microsoft one or

589
00:33:37.140 --> 00:33:38.740
other Microsoft tools.

590
00:33:38.740 --> 00:33:41.940
So with this, I think we've
covered some reasonable ground and

591
00:33:41.940 --> 00:33:43.105
I feel like we need some break.

592
00:33:43.105 --> 00:33:46.110
>> [LAUGH] That sounds good to me.

593
00:33:46.110 --> 00:33:48.800
Well, remember, that what you took
a look at in this episode of course

594
00:33:48.800 --> 00:33:52.550
is that second part of working
with Microsoft Office itself.

595
00:33:52.550 --> 00:33:55.480
Remember that the whole goal
here is to get you familiar

596
00:33:55.480 --> 00:33:59.100
with those concepts that we took
a look in both parts one and part two.

597
00:33:59.100 --> 00:34:03.048
Because regardless of which particular
product you're looking at inside of

598
00:34:03.048 --> 00:34:07.119
Microsoft Office, the majority if not
everything that we've shown you should

599
00:34:07.119 --> 00:34:11.371
work across all of them, and that should
make you feel much more confident, should

600
00:34:11.371 --> 00:34:15.379
make you feel much more relaxed hopefully
when working with each one of those,

601
00:34:15.379 --> 00:34:19.058
even if you never open them up before or
you've only open one up before.

602
00:34:19.058 --> 00:34:22.779
It will allows you to go move between
those products and go hey, this is not so

603
00:34:22.779 --> 00:34:24.520
bad, its not so different.

604
00:34:24.520 --> 00:34:27.270
We can actually do that,
and I can do that as well.

605
00:34:27.270 --> 00:34:30.880
And that helps me out in my confidence
when I start talking about working with

606
00:34:30.880 --> 00:34:31.920
more computers.

607
00:34:31.920 --> 00:34:32.690
All right.

608
00:34:32.690 --> 00:34:35.440
Well that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

609
00:34:35.440 --> 00:34:39.490
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Ronny Wong.

610
00:34:39.490 --> 00:34:42.340
>> My name is Dr. Tony Monsat,
its been great learning together,

611
00:34:42.340 --> 00:34:44.900
I hope to see you again next time for
the next episode.

612
00:34:46.010 --> 00:34:51.805
>> All right, take care, stay tuned right
here for more computing fundamentals.

613
00:34:51.805 --> 00:34:53.597
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa introduce the skills and techniques for getting started with Microsoft Word 2010.  They describe and show how to format text and paragraphs using the tools found in the ribbon to make an effective looking document.  Using the built in tools, they also show to working with larger documents and even with lists.  This episode is rounded out by Dr. Omwansa emphasizing the importance of learning to use Word with proper fundamentals rather than creating bad habits in learning the fundamentals.
episodes.title: Introduction to Microsoft Word 2010
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.430 --> 00:00:15.200
Welcome to a great show here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.200 --> 00:00:18.380
We're about to take a look
at computing fundamentals.

4
00:00:18.380 --> 00:00:19.830
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

5
00:00:19.830 --> 00:00:24.780
what we're about to take a look at
of course is getting into Word 2010.

6
00:00:24.780 --> 00:00:28.169
And who better to help us than Dr.
Tonny Omwansa.

7
00:00:28.169 --> 00:00:30.230
Dr. Tonny, welcome back to our videos.

8
00:00:30.230 --> 00:00:30.820
>> Thank you very much.

9
00:00:30.820 --> 00:00:32.800
It's always great to be here and

10
00:00:32.800 --> 00:00:35.480
there's always an opportunity
to learn in a fun way.

11
00:00:35.480 --> 00:00:39.130
>> When we start taking a look
of course then at the idea of

12
00:00:39.130 --> 00:00:42.090
work inside of a word processing program.

13
00:00:42.090 --> 00:00:45.320
This is one of the fundamental
skills that we all need to have.

14
00:00:45.320 --> 00:00:47.980
Because when you actually go to work and
you're working with computers a lot of

15
00:00:47.980 --> 00:00:53.100
times you are having to produce some type
of document which normally requires us to

16
00:00:53.100 --> 00:00:58.300
be able to manipulate and be able to work
around something like Microsoft Word.

17
00:00:58.300 --> 00:01:01.690
And Dr. Tonny is gonna help us to
understand how we get started in

18
00:01:01.690 --> 00:01:02.260
doing this and

19
00:01:02.260 --> 00:01:06.730
some of the basic things that will help
us to succeed working inside of Word.

20
00:01:06.730 --> 00:01:09.040
So where are we gonna start today?

21
00:01:09.040 --> 00:01:12.820
>> So I think the best place to start is
to connect from what we did last time.

22
00:01:12.820 --> 00:01:15.360
So what we were doing last
time is thinking about

23
00:01:15.360 --> 00:01:18.620
the general framework of the interface
of Microsoft applications.

24
00:01:18.620 --> 00:01:23.440
We get to see how the menu's organized,
how to save documents, create new

25
00:01:23.440 --> 00:01:28.450
documents, open them, move them around,
understand file types and the like.

26
00:01:28.450 --> 00:01:31.630
Now we also try to spend a little bit of
time thinking about generic things like

27
00:01:31.630 --> 00:01:36.270
copying, pasting formatting
a little bit here and there,

28
00:01:36.270 --> 00:01:37.870
changing color and stuff like that.

29
00:01:37.870 --> 00:01:41.280
So what we're gonna do today is we will
immerse ourselves a little more into

30
00:01:41.280 --> 00:01:42.610
Microsoft Word.

31
00:01:42.610 --> 00:01:45.920
We're gonna spend time thinking
about well, how do you edit and

32
00:01:45.920 --> 00:01:48.260
format say paragraphs or lines?

33
00:01:49.460 --> 00:01:52.100
How do you insert say, page numbers,

34
00:01:52.100 --> 00:01:54.910
or how do you create new
sections of a document.

35
00:01:54.910 --> 00:01:58.910
How do you insert an image, for
example, how do you create at table?

36
00:01:58.910 --> 00:02:03.970
How do you manipulate that table, create
a title, think about the columns and rows.

37
00:02:03.970 --> 00:02:07.450
And also we try to think a little
more about how we correct our work,

38
00:02:07.450 --> 00:02:11.940
the quality of work we're doing, and how
could we possibly collaborate with others.

39
00:02:11.940 --> 00:02:15.870
That's what we'll spend a bit of time
today and hopefully it will be fun and

40
00:02:15.870 --> 00:02:17.480
we'll be able to do it ourselves.

41
00:02:17.480 --> 00:02:19.280
>> That sounds like a great place for
us to start.

42
00:02:19.280 --> 00:02:24.600
So now that we understand how we
get access into Microsoft Word and

43
00:02:24.600 --> 00:02:27.950
we know that when we open up we end
up with a document at the beginning.

44
00:02:27.950 --> 00:02:30.270
What else do we need to know
now that we've gotten in there?

45
00:02:30.270 --> 00:02:33.270
We might know how to type, hopefully,
of course, you have that skill.

46
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:35.360
If you don't,
you need to learn how to type as well.

47
00:02:35.360 --> 00:02:38.400
But now when we start talking about
the idea of editing in format text,

48
00:02:38.400 --> 00:02:39.440
where do we need to begin?

49
00:02:40.630 --> 00:02:44.730
>> The best place to begin
is you have a document and

50
00:02:44.730 --> 00:02:47.590
you possibly have some text there
because you know how to type.

51
00:02:47.590 --> 00:02:52.030
So right on my screen now, I've put
a section that talks about editing and

52
00:02:52.030 --> 00:02:52.920
formatting text.

53
00:02:54.120 --> 00:02:58.230
So if you look at this screen,
the text already is in there, so

54
00:02:58.230 --> 00:03:01.170
we assume you already have
some text out there and

55
00:03:02.590 --> 00:03:06.832
the cursor is currently pointing
at the section on paragraph.

56
00:03:06.832 --> 00:03:10.750
And under that section, we're going to
learn a little bit about putting numbers

57
00:03:10.750 --> 00:03:16.680
on texts, put them in bullet font,
trying to create new paragraphs,

58
00:03:16.680 --> 00:03:20.560
think about creating breaks and
things like that.

59
00:03:20.560 --> 00:03:25.680
So if I open now my Word document,
which I have just created,

60
00:03:25.680 --> 00:03:30.030
the text there is My title, well you can
have whatever title you wanna out there.

61
00:03:30.030 --> 00:03:34.570
But there something interesting you'll
see at the end of that, those two words.

62
00:03:34.570 --> 00:03:35.800
There is a sign there, and

63
00:03:35.800 --> 00:03:39.185
that sign help us to know that we
are now moving to a new paragraph.

64
00:03:39.185 --> 00:03:42.450
[COUGH] Between the two
words there is a dot.

65
00:03:42.450 --> 00:03:45.410
It helps us to know that there
is a space between those two.

66
00:03:45.410 --> 00:03:47.910
Now suppose you wanted to
know I type something but

67
00:03:47.910 --> 00:03:51.970
I don't know how many spaces did I put,
and I want to reduce that.

68
00:03:51.970 --> 00:03:54.130
Sometimes you can't see in there too, so

69
00:03:54.130 --> 00:04:00.020
it's better to introduce a component
[COUGH] that we use to track spaces and

70
00:04:00.020 --> 00:04:03.530
paragraphs and right there,
I'm pointing at it.

71
00:04:03.530 --> 00:04:06.030
And if you wanted to learn a lot
more about it you could just press

72
00:04:06.030 --> 00:04:07.790
F1 at that point in time.

73
00:04:07.790 --> 00:04:12.530
But if you see, it's what we call
a toggle in the sense that it's boolean,

74
00:04:12.530 --> 00:04:15.440
in the sense that if I click it,
it'll be visible, and

75
00:04:15.440 --> 00:04:18.170
if I unclick it, it's not visible.

76
00:04:18.170 --> 00:04:19.240
So there we go.

77
00:04:19.240 --> 00:04:22.430
Now I can see, wow, I have several spaces.

78
00:04:22.430 --> 00:04:26.370
I have only one paragraph, idea.

79
00:04:26.370 --> 00:04:30.150
So if I get right in the middle of that
text, somewhere in the middle, and

80
00:04:30.150 --> 00:04:35.170
I want to create a new paragraph,
so maybe right here, For,

81
00:04:35.170 --> 00:04:39.550
and I click the Enter button,
it creates a paragraph for me.

82
00:04:39.550 --> 00:04:43.157
And then all of a sudden, I have this mark
over here that gives me a sense that wow,

83
00:04:43.157 --> 00:04:44.860
you created a paragraph.

84
00:04:44.860 --> 00:04:49.260
I can of course undo them, remember Ctrl
+ z and go back to where I was before.

85
00:04:49.260 --> 00:04:55.140
That give me a sense of how do I
format some text, how do I create

86
00:04:55.140 --> 00:05:02.180
a new paragraph, and how do I insure that
I have reasonable spaces in between.

87
00:05:02.180 --> 00:05:06.670
Now if you are going to format your text,
as is now, you already have it,

88
00:05:06.670 --> 00:05:08.550
there are many things you can do there.

89
00:05:08.550 --> 00:05:12.280
So let's go back to our text and
think about, well,

90
00:05:12.280 --> 00:05:16.970
sometimes you create a document and
you want some sections to look a little

91
00:05:16.970 --> 00:05:21.420
differently, or the entire document
to have a certain framework,

92
00:05:21.420 --> 00:05:24.480
a certain template where
the titles look in a certain way,

93
00:05:24.480 --> 00:05:27.720
subtitles look in a certain way,
and the text look in a certain way.

94
00:05:27.720 --> 00:05:30.740
So that's what we are spending
a bit of time thinking about.

95
00:05:30.740 --> 00:05:38.500
So if you look at my document now,
there is a description on fonts.

96
00:05:38.500 --> 00:05:39.820
So there are theme fonts.

97
00:05:39.820 --> 00:05:43.670
So if I go to my document,
when I click this arrow on the fonts,

98
00:05:43.670 --> 00:05:45.450
that's a drop down.

99
00:05:45.450 --> 00:05:49.540
It gives me an idea of the different
types of fonts that exist.

100
00:05:49.540 --> 00:05:52.480
Some are like headings,
you know some are interesting,

101
00:05:52.480 --> 00:05:57.435
some are straight, others italicize,
there's a whole range of fonts.

102
00:05:57.435 --> 00:05:59.660
And you can explore as much as you want.

103
00:05:59.660 --> 00:06:02.907
So if I pick some text for
example and then I go, wow okay,

104
00:06:02.907 --> 00:06:05.570
I wanna see how this font will look like.

105
00:06:05.570 --> 00:06:07.830
Look, that looks really interesting.

106
00:06:07.830 --> 00:06:10.230
Some are smaller, some give more space.

107
00:06:10.230 --> 00:06:12.710
So it really,
really depends on your taste.

108
00:06:12.710 --> 00:06:15.390
But at the time you have to
cognizant of the fact that

109
00:06:15.390 --> 00:06:18.170
you're preparing this document for
someone else to read.

110
00:06:18.170 --> 00:06:19.370
Yeah, you may be preparing for

111
00:06:19.370 --> 00:06:23.760
yourself but, sometimes as you define
those forms you really must think about

112
00:06:23.760 --> 00:06:27.410
the experience that someone else is going
to go through when they're reading it.

113
00:06:28.920 --> 00:06:33.170
All right, in addition to fonts
there's something we call style.

114
00:06:34.170 --> 00:06:37.870
See the style gives you an opportunity
to determine what the entire document is

115
00:06:37.870 --> 00:06:38.930
going to look like.

116
00:06:38.930 --> 00:06:41.335
So this section is about style.

117
00:06:41.335 --> 00:06:46.360
Now sometimes it's not really very
useful to reinvent the wheel.

118
00:06:46.360 --> 00:06:49.180
Some people have spent a lot
of time thinking about how

119
00:06:49.180 --> 00:06:52.860
could a professional document look like,
how could a formal document look like,

120
00:06:52.860 --> 00:06:55.000
how could an elegant document look like?

121
00:06:55.000 --> 00:06:59.830
So some of these styles have been created
which are templates that you can adopt and

122
00:06:59.830 --> 00:07:02.410
the entire document gets
to have a certain style.

123
00:07:02.410 --> 00:07:06.840
So look at my document, the font here is
times new roman, both for the title and

124
00:07:06.840 --> 00:07:07.870
the text.

125
00:07:07.870 --> 00:07:12.889
Now if I go up to the right here on
my text and I have changed style, and

126
00:07:12.889 --> 00:07:18.703
I click it and then I can see style set,
now there are several options of style,

127
00:07:18.703 --> 00:07:24.894
there's distinctive, elegant, fancy,
normal, manuscript, modern, etc.

128
00:07:24.894 --> 00:07:28.782
So as I click each of them,
the whole document seems to change and

129
00:07:28.782 --> 00:07:30.610
have a particular format.

130
00:07:30.610 --> 00:07:32.670
So the beautiful thing about this,

131
00:07:32.670 --> 00:07:36.070
people have spent a lot of time framing
how these styles are going to look like.

132
00:07:36.070 --> 00:07:39.830
So you could be easily just adopt
a document and maintain that style.

133
00:07:39.830 --> 00:07:43.050
How do you know if, Ronnie,
this has been a useful tool for you?

134
00:07:43.050 --> 00:07:45.559
>> Yes, all these tools that
you've mentioned so far,

135
00:07:45.559 --> 00:07:47.915
very useful when we start
working inside of Word.

136
00:07:47.915 --> 00:07:52.254
And a lot of times, even though we may

to take a look at here Dr. Tonny?

00:20:37.511 --> 00:20:39.023
>> There are more interesting things,

I mean I'm sure you have seen

Now sometimes you want to create titles,
and

you want the titles to be using existing

00:20:50.590 --> 00:20:54.520
And so all you would need to do, is you

00:20:54.520 --> 00:20:57.920
If you look at Style,
we spoke a little bit about Style, and

00:20:57.920 --> 00:20:59.920
we selected different Styles over here.

00:21:01.690 --> 00:21:05.418
But there is also an opportunity to
quickly pick a style without having to

00:21:05.418 --> 00:21:08.790
struggle, trying to imagine,
how would it possibly look like?

366
00:21:08.790 --> 00:21:10.232
So what Microsoft Word has done,

367
00:21:10.232 --> 00:21:12.766
is that they've actually put
the various Styles up here.

368
00:21:12.766 --> 00:21:16.351
So just by pointing at them,

00:21:16.351 --> 00:21:19.941
whoa this is what my text

00:21:19.941 --> 00:21:24.810
So let me select My title, and

371
00:21:24.810 --> 00:21:32.470
I see an option, Normal, No Spacing,
Heading 1, Heading 2, Title, Subtitle.

372
00:21:32.470 --> 00:21:34.410
As you can see, my title is changing.

373
00:21:34.410 --> 00:21:36.260
So let me pick title 1.

00:21:36.260 --> 00:21:39.510
The reason why I want us to go through
this section is because it's leading us

00:21:39.510 --> 00:21:44.070
to another section of how we could
organize things in specific pages, and

376
00:21:44.070 --> 00:21:48.530
create breaks in pages, so that we
can have titles in different pages.

377
00:21:48.530 --> 00:21:51.930
Typically, if you're working on a report,
chances are very high that

00:21:51.930 --> 00:21:56.000
every major report will start at
the top of a page, that's very typical.

379
00:21:56.000 --> 00:22:00.130
So what if your text,
towards the end of the first topic or

00:22:00.130 --> 00:22:03.375

00:22:03.375 --> 00:22:07.460
So chances are that you create a mechanism
that sends you to the next page, so

00:22:07.460 --> 00:22:10.000
that you can begin right
at the top of the document.

383
00:22:10.000 --> 00:22:14.313
So there we go, I have a title,

384
00:22:14.313 --> 00:22:19.330
So I've selected that, as you can see
up here, it is of Heading 1 type.

00:22:19.330 --> 00:22:22.610
If I click my text,
it tells me that this is Normal.

386
00:22:23.910 --> 00:22:28.080
So let's say, that towards the end,

00:22:28.080 --> 00:22:34.910
And then I say, well somewhere here, I'm
gonna remove this indicator for paragraph.

388
00:22:34.910 --> 00:22:40.381
So I'm gonna say now over here,
I want to go to Title 2, okay?

00:22:40.381 --> 00:22:45.319
So now I have an option, I could very
easily enter tab, Enter, Enter, Enter,

00:22:45.319 --> 00:22:47.248
until it goes to the next page.

391
00:22:47.248 --> 00:22:51.109
The problem with that, is that sometimes

392
00:22:51.109 --> 00:22:55.113
And it's gonna catch up with you,
especially when you move things later on,

393
00:22:55.113 --> 00:22:57.010
and things start moving.

394
00:22:57.010 --> 00:22:59.850
So you can create a rule,
and say that I want

00:22:59.850 --> 00:23:05.170
Title 2 to always be at the beginning of a

00:23:05.170 --> 00:23:09.800
So as I type things out, if I want to just

00:23:09.800 --> 00:23:13.770
I want always this Title 2 to

00:23:13.770 --> 00:23:17.027
So if things spill into

00:23:17.027 --> 00:23:20.150
I want this now to jump to the third page.

So let me remove this and

00:23:24.160 --> 00:23:28.900
So let's take the cursor right

00:23:28.900 --> 00:23:33.980
and I go to Insert and I say Page Break.

00:23:33.980 --> 00:23:36.752
Now that takes me to a new page.

00:23:36.752 --> 00:23:40.070
And then what I'm going to do now,

00:23:40.070 --> 00:23:43.900
I'll go back Home, and

00:23:43.900 --> 00:23:45.950
So it means now we have two Heading 1s.

00:23:45.950 --> 00:23:49.520
We have the first one that we worked with,

408
00:23:49.520 --> 00:23:52.914
Now later on you will see

00:23:52.914 --> 00:23:57.054
For example if you're creating table of
contents, you don't have to keep typing,

00:23:57.054 --> 00:24:00.920

00:24:00.920 --> 00:24:02.925
And you know.
When things move around.

00:24:02.925 --> 00:24:05.430
Then again, you're trying to figure
out which page number was that now.

413
00:24:05.430 --> 00:24:06.630
So I can come and change.

414
00:24:06.630 --> 00:24:08.640
You can do all that automatically.

415
00:24:08.640 --> 00:24:10.590
You don't even have to worry
about table of contents.

416
00:24:10.590 --> 00:24:16.890
That is the power of the styles because
the document now becomes intelligent.

417
00:24:16.890 --> 00:24:19.030
And it can easily make things so easy.

418
00:24:19.030 --> 00:24:22.940
If you want to clear table of figures,
you create table of content.

419
00:24:22.940 --> 00:24:27.880
You want to take like all the tables
of actually having your document

420
00:24:27.880 --> 00:24:29.870
where you've done any referencing.

421
00:24:29.870 --> 00:24:32.820
That can be done all
automatically if you use style.

422
00:24:32.820 --> 00:24:34.610
So this is an encouragement.

423
00:24:34.610 --> 00:24:39.440
But you need to understand how
to use the styles because later

00:24:39.440 --> 00:24:41.310
It'll become a very powerful tool.

425
00:24:42.320 --> 00:24:45.260
Ronald, I learned a very
simple joke some time back.

00:24:45.260 --> 00:24:45.760
>> Okay.

427
00:24:46.960 --> 00:24:49.040
>> I was trying to learn
how to play tennis.

00:24:49.040 --> 00:24:50.350
And I went and bought a racket.

429
00:24:50.350 --> 00:24:52.430
But I bought some kind of old racket.

430
00:24:52.430 --> 00:24:54.060
Which was just kind of poor quality.

431
00:24:54.060 --> 00:24:56.800
And then my friend came and
told me, why are you buying this?

432
00:24:56.800 --> 00:24:59.250
Well I said look,
I'm just learning some basics so far.

433
00:24:59.250 --> 00:25:00.430
So don't you worry, I'll be fine.

434
00:25:00.430 --> 00:25:02.900
He said no, no, no,
no You should buy a good racket.

435
00:25:02.900 --> 00:25:04.310
I said, well I don't think so.

436
00:25:04.310 --> 00:25:06.310
So I went and bought it anyway.

437
00:25:06.310 --> 00:25:08.540
And then I played with it for some time.

438
00:25:08.540 --> 00:25:11.140
I never got professional training.

439
00:25:11.140 --> 00:25:14.610
So one day, when I was getting courageous.

440
00:25:14.610 --> 00:25:18.650
How to hit that ball, I actually hit it so
hard the racquet broke.

441
00:25:20.040 --> 00:25:23.090
And someone who was a professional
trainer came to me and told me.

442
00:25:23.090 --> 00:25:25.250
Tony, let me tell you
the mistake you made.

443
00:25:26.410 --> 00:25:27.520
You bought the wrong racquet.

444
00:25:28.540 --> 00:25:31.324
And number two,
you refuse to pay to be taught.

445
00:25:31.324 --> 00:25:33.460
>> [LAUGH]
>> So now here's what I'm going to do.

446
00:25:33.460 --> 00:25:36.620
He said I'll charge you to teach you

447
00:25:36.620 --> 00:25:40.050
to unlearn the bad habits you've already
picked while trying to learn tennis.

448
00:25:40.050 --> 00:25:43.870
And secondly, I'm going to
teach you how to read properly.

449
00:25:43.870 --> 00:25:46.350
Now that means now you're
going to pay twice, all right?

450
00:25:46.350 --> 00:25:49.720
And then you have to go and get
the right racket for this kind of work.

00:25:49.720 --> 00:25:52.668
So the reason I'm giving

Is that getting some of these right habits

00:25:59.080 --> 00:26:00.680
It might look like
a little bit challenging.

00:26:00.680 --> 00:26:03.580
Or okay,
why don't I just do the easy way out?

00:26:03.580 --> 00:26:07.890
But just learning some of these habits
will make life much lighter later.

00:26:07.890 --> 00:26:08.850
Isn't that true Ronald?

00:26:08.850 --> 00:26:12.480

getting some of these foundational skills

00:26:12.480 --> 00:26:13.820
down really helps.

00:26:13.820 --> 00:26:15.890
Instead of you trying

00:26:15.890 --> 00:26:19.630
So learning the techniques here

00:26:19.630 --> 00:26:21.620
Now what we've done so far, right.

Especially the idea of the styles here

Whether we're talking about the thesis

Or whether that we're

00:26:45.240 --> 00:26:48.790

A lot of times those kinds

And it may be your

Using styles ahead of time and getting

00:27:04.810 --> 00:27:09.150

And go, I have to actually

00:27:16.110 --> 00:27:19.620
So by learning that technique right

00:27:19.620 --> 00:27:23.770
Instead of you learning it after five or

00:27:23.770 --> 00:27:24.850

00:27:24.850 --> 00:27:29.010

00:27:29.010 --> 00:27:31.420

00:27:31.420 --> 00:27:34.660
As well by using these styles and

00:27:34.660 --> 00:27:37.350
So you are actually getting

00:27:37.350 --> 00:27:39.720
And the great thing is,
instead of you trying to go,

00:27:39.720 --> 00:27:41.480
I wish I would of known that two months.

00:27:43.320 --> 00:27:47.010

00:27:53.660 --> 00:27:58.870
We'll talk about changing
this tile of a page.

00:27:58.870 --> 00:28:00.830
Orientation is something.

00:28:00.830 --> 00:28:03.910
Sometimes you find a document
that is kind of like horizontal.

00:28:03.910 --> 00:28:06.280
And another one kind of
looks like it is vertical.

00:28:06.280 --> 00:28:08.400
So that's called orientation.

00:28:08.400 --> 00:28:10.880
One is portrait, one is vertical.

00:28:10.880 --> 00:28:14.530
And one is kind of like horizontal,

00:28:14.530 --> 00:28:16.340
When you're printing,

00:28:16.340 --> 00:28:18.950
that becomes useful depending on
the kind of content that you have.

00:28:18.950 --> 00:28:21.380
If you have a table that
have several columns,

00:28:21.380 --> 00:28:26.910
that document ideally should be in
an orientation that is landscape.

00:28:26.910 --> 00:28:29.280
So that's an important tool to know.

00:28:29.280 --> 00:28:35.680
If you look at my screen now, there's a
section up there a tab called page layout.

00:28:36.910 --> 00:28:39.150
Now, on the page layout,
there are many things that we can learn.

00:28:39.150 --> 00:28:41.240
But let's just focus on that orientation.

00:28:41.240 --> 00:28:44.980
We spoke about page break earlier on,

00:28:44.980 --> 00:28:49.170
You could do a page break using this set
of options here, we just pick Page Break.

00:28:49.170 --> 00:28:54.410
But now, let's just talk about
that orientation of our page.

00:28:54.410 --> 00:28:56.010
So, in order for us to see.

00:28:56.010 --> 00:29:02.970
Let me just try and resize this document
so that you see three sheets on a page.

514
00:29:02.970 --> 00:29:05.300
There we go.
Ok, so this current is portrait.

515
00:29:06.560 --> 00:29:09.490
If I came here and select orientation and

00:29:09.490 --> 00:29:12.520
pick landscape,
see what happens to my document.

517
00:29:12.520 --> 00:29:16.650
Now you see two pages,
two sheets on the screen.

518
00:29:16.650 --> 00:29:20.070
Of course I can reduce this farther and

00:29:20.070 --> 00:29:24.400
But what has happened is automatically the
entire document is actually been converted

00:29:24.400 --> 00:29:25.920

00:29:25.920 --> 00:29:28.090
Now, sometimes you might say, well no.

00:29:28.090 --> 00:29:32.400
I just wanted a particular page in

00:29:32.400 --> 00:29:34.240
While everything else is portrait.

00:29:34.240 --> 00:29:34.978
We'll come to that.

00:29:34.978 --> 00:29:39.120
We're going to have a very

00:29:39.120 --> 00:29:41.190
And conversion of landscape and portrait.

00:29:41.190 --> 00:29:43.060
So we'll come to that at the right time.

00:29:43.060 --> 00:29:45.082
But just to let you know, that's possible.

00:29:45.082 --> 00:29:50.020
We can have a mix of document, of pages,

00:29:50.020 --> 00:29:52.720
Has that been useful in any way for

531
00:29:52.720 --> 00:29:55.530
>> Definitely, when you start seeing
that you have a lot of data and

00:29:55.530 --> 00:29:56.900
you need to offset something.

533
00:29:56.900 --> 00:29:57.830
So a lot of times.

534
00:29:57.830 --> 00:30:02.000
What I normally use the idea of changing
the orientation of the page for,

535
00:30:02.000 --> 00:30:05.860
is I have a table of data that
I also need to include into

536
00:30:05.860 --> 00:30:08.746
my regular reporting of the data as well.

537
00:30:08.746 --> 00:30:11.110
By being able to actually
create that table and

538
00:30:11.110 --> 00:30:14.750
the landscape, it may allow me to
add in one or two extra columns.

539
00:30:14.750 --> 00:30:19.080
That the regular portrait style of
a page would not have allowed me to do.

540
00:30:19.080 --> 00:30:23.230
So unless I decreased the size
of my table to a point

541
00:30:23.230 --> 00:30:25.310
where it almost became unreadable.

00:30:25.310 --> 00:30:29.160
By simply changing landscape in

543
00:30:29.160 --> 00:30:30.950
Some types of reports though, or

00:30:30.950 --> 00:30:35.340
some type of document that you may end up

00:30:35.340 --> 00:30:39.930
And that is because that document is

00:30:39.930 --> 00:30:44.100
A lot of time the idea of using
step by step process is changing

547
00:30:44.100 --> 00:30:49.290
the orientation to that
landscape process allows me.

548
00:30:49.290 --> 00:30:52.420
Then to bind one edge and

00:30:52.420 --> 00:30:54.400
That allows me to also continue to read.

550
00:30:54.400 --> 00:30:57.790
But then actually have it
flip over the page by page.

551
00:30:57.790 --> 00:31:00.670
So understanding what the overall outcome.

552
00:31:00.670 --> 00:31:04.760
What that document is going to be is

00:31:04.760 --> 00:31:08.120

00:31:08.120 --> 00:31:10.210
Or if you do have something like a table.

00:31:10.210 --> 00:31:14.140
That, when I tried to print this out,

00:31:14.140 --> 00:31:16.980
And then another two columns

00:31:16.980 --> 00:31:20.720
Changing the orientation of that one page
may allow you to take that one table,

558
00:31:20.720 --> 00:31:22.790

559
00:31:22.790 --> 00:31:25.060
Without it actually
looking like it's broken.

560
00:31:25.060 --> 00:31:27.850
So, I've actually used this quite often.

561
00:31:27.850 --> 00:31:30.470
Just to try and
make my point the way that I needed to.

562
00:31:30.470 --> 00:31:33.930
Or to keep a certain number of pages

00:31:35.150 --> 00:31:36.290

So,

00:32:35.420 --> 00:32:38.290
as we are working with
the word product itself.

586
00:32:38.290 --> 00:32:40.520
Well, great place to
end these episode then.

587
00:32:40.520 --> 00:32:44.940
Sign off for ITproTV,
I've been your host Ronny Wong.

588
00:32:44.940 --> 00:32:46.210
>> And my name Doctor Tony.

589
00:32:46.210 --> 00:32:51.710
It's been great learning together with
you and with great company, over and out.

590
00:32:51.710 --> 00:32:54.767
>> All right, stay tuned right here for
more computing fundamentals

591
00:32:56.255 --> 00:33:03.517
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa continue to describe and demonstrate the skills and techniques for getting started with Microsoft Word 2010.  This time, they begin with page number and headers and footers and show how to work with larger documents that can be easily disorganized without using  the styles to format documents and sections.  Dr. Omwansa finishes the introduction by showing the use of comments and tracking changes.
episodes.title: Introduction to Microsoft Word Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.068 --> 00:00:15.279
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.279 --> 00:00:16.910
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

4
00:00:16.910 --> 00:00:20.390
you're watching
the Computing Fundamentals IC3 show.

5
00:00:20.390 --> 00:00:24.725
Where we are actually continuing
on on a part two introducing

6
00:00:24.725 --> 00:00:27.616
ourselves to Microsoft Word 2010.

7
00:00:27.616 --> 00:00:30.189
Now we're ready take a look at
several elements before and

8
00:00:30.189 --> 00:00:32.000
some we understand we have to do.

9
00:00:32.000 --> 00:00:36.901
But we are now continuing on and with us
again in the studio is Dr. Tonny Omwanza.

10
00:00:36.901 --> 00:00:38.700
Dr. Tonny, welcome back to our studios.

11
00:00:38.700 --> 00:00:39.690
>> Thank you very much.

12
00:00:39.690 --> 00:00:43.110
I am last looking forward
to digging deeper.

13
00:00:43.110 --> 00:00:43.780
>> Excellent.

14
00:00:43.780 --> 00:00:45.768
So when we start taking a log now,

15
00:00:45.768 --> 00:00:50.312
we're ready to talk some of those
different elements that really helps us to

16
00:00:50.312 --> 00:00:54.860
make our Word documents kind of be able
to format and do the things I wanna do.

17
00:00:54.860 --> 00:00:56.540
But now as we continue to move forward,

18
00:00:56.540 --> 00:00:59.970
we're starting to see where we're
starting off with very small elements.

19
00:00:59.970 --> 00:01:02.820
And now we're working towards
what larger elements and

20
00:01:02.820 --> 00:01:05.450
we're now gonna take
a look at page numbers.

21
00:01:05.450 --> 00:01:08.910
And this is normally done because we do
tend to work with very large documents

22
00:01:08.910 --> 00:01:09.670
at times, right?

23
00:01:09.670 --> 00:01:11.600
>> That's very correct.

24
00:01:11.600 --> 00:01:13.280
Sometimes you work on a thesis.

25
00:01:13.280 --> 00:01:17.640
When I was doing my PhD, I worked on
a document that was over 300 pages.

26
00:01:17.640 --> 00:01:20.710
>> Wow.
>> So you're gonna have a sense,

27
00:01:20.710 --> 00:01:22.325
you can look on page 37,
something like this.

28
00:01:22.325 --> 00:01:25.810
So you got organize that
document with page numbers and

29
00:01:25.810 --> 00:01:29.300
then when you work on the table of
contents, then you can relate very easily.

30
00:01:29.300 --> 00:01:32.260
So think about people working
on a whole large document like

31
00:01:32.260 --> 00:01:36.740
what I'm holding over here for the IC3
certification Computing Fundamentals.

32
00:01:36.740 --> 00:01:38.490
I don't know, it's like how many pages?

33
00:01:38.490 --> 00:01:39.945
722.

34
00:01:39.945 --> 00:01:40.608
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

35
00:01:40.608 --> 00:01:43.237
you better think about how you're
organizing those page numbers.

36
00:01:43.237 --> 00:01:46.170
So let's spend a little bit
of time starting right there.

37
00:01:46.170 --> 00:01:47.630
Now on my screen,

38
00:01:47.630 --> 00:01:50.540
I've opened a page that is very
familiar with what we've been doing.

39
00:01:51.710 --> 00:01:53.980
I just call it simple document,
document two.

40
00:01:55.790 --> 00:01:57.350
See what I'm gonna do.

41
00:01:57.350 --> 00:02:00.410
I'm gonna click somewhere
at the top of the document.

42
00:02:00.410 --> 00:02:01.940
I double-click over there.

43
00:02:01.940 --> 00:02:06.560
When I double-click, some line come
over here and it's written here Header.

44
00:02:06.560 --> 00:02:09.270
If I scroll down,
we already did the scrolling.

45
00:02:09.270 --> 00:02:13.200
If I come to the end of the document,
I've got a Footer, all right?

46
00:02:13.200 --> 00:02:16.560
So those have been automatically created,
they exist.

47
00:02:16.560 --> 00:02:19.160
So as long as you click there,
they're gonna show up.

48
00:02:19.160 --> 00:02:20.630
And what has happened
to the main document?

49
00:02:20.630 --> 00:02:24.480
It's kind of a little blurred now, so
the focus is not in the main document.

50
00:02:24.480 --> 00:02:25.850
It's on the header and the footer.

51
00:02:25.850 --> 00:02:28.770
So we're gonna spend a little bit of time
thinking about what would I do without

52
00:02:28.770 --> 00:02:29.990
header and footer.

53
00:02:29.990 --> 00:02:33.600
So let's start by Insert and

54
00:02:33.600 --> 00:02:38.240
then go move all over the place and
get to a place called Page Numbers.

55
00:02:38.240 --> 00:02:41.410
If I click Page Numbers, click that arrow.

56
00:02:41.410 --> 00:02:43.386
It gives me a menu.

57
00:02:43.386 --> 00:02:47.970
[INAUDIBLE] top or bottom or
something about page numbers here.

58
00:02:47.970 --> 00:02:52.240
Current position, format of page
numbers and remove page numbers.

59
00:02:52.240 --> 00:02:55.180
So this menu gives you an option to
play around with where you wanna

60
00:02:55.180 --> 00:02:56.690
put the page numbers.

61
00:02:56.690 --> 00:02:58.350
What format do you want them to be?

62
00:02:58.350 --> 00:03:02.520
They can be at the top, at the bottom,
right, left, they can be A, B, C, D or

63
00:03:02.520 --> 00:03:04.947
they can be one, two, three, four, five.

64
00:03:04.947 --> 00:03:08.382
So let's just take an example quickly,
select top of the page and

65
00:03:08.382 --> 00:03:12.870
then decide whether you want to do on
the left, in the middle or on the right.

66
00:03:12.870 --> 00:03:16.460
Maybe this look like an interesting one,
so I'm going to click this.

67
00:03:16.460 --> 00:03:18.990
And then I come to the center
of the document and

68
00:03:18.990 --> 00:03:21.080
click somewhere there,
now I have a page number.

69
00:03:21.080 --> 00:03:24.420
1 page, well,
that looks interesting, right?

70
00:03:24.420 --> 00:03:28.318
So what do you think would have
happened to the next page, Ronnie?

71
00:03:28.318 --> 00:03:31.780
>> Well, hopefully it's a header and
it's actually doing it on every page.

72
00:03:31.780 --> 00:03:34.580
We should see where it turns to page two,
I believe.

73
00:03:34.580 --> 00:03:39.138
>> Uh-huh, so what basically has happened
here is that we have page numbers from

74
00:03:39.138 --> 00:03:40.321
page one to the end.

75
00:03:40.321 --> 00:03:42.080
There are other things
you can do with that.

76
00:03:42.080 --> 00:03:45.260
Assuming I want to change
the page number type.

77
00:03:45.260 --> 00:03:47.980
So let's say I go back to Insert and

78
00:03:47.980 --> 00:03:52.220
then I go to Page Number and
then I go to Format Page Numbers.

79
00:03:52.220 --> 00:03:54.894
Now you see their number format is 1,
2, 3.

80
00:03:54.894 --> 00:03:57.780
If I click this, I have different options.

81
00:03:57.780 --> 00:03:59.760
Maybe I want Roman 1, 2, 3.

82
00:03:59.760 --> 00:04:03.750
And I say okay, it automatically
changes all my page numbers.

83
00:04:03.750 --> 00:04:05.450
There are many other things
I can do over there.

84
00:04:05.450 --> 00:04:10.310
So Page Number again,
Remove Page Number, it's all gone.

85
00:04:10.310 --> 00:04:14.420
So on my header and footer I have
power to do a number of things.

86
00:04:14.420 --> 00:04:16.110
So let me just take back the page numbers.

87
00:04:16.110 --> 00:04:19.037
So I'm gonna say okay, top of the page,

88
00:04:19.037 --> 00:04:23.270
center and I have inserted Roman one,
two, three.

89
00:04:23.270 --> 00:04:25.740
The power of that is
that in some books and

90
00:04:25.740 --> 00:04:29.820
actually in thesis,
you will find a section of the book.

91
00:04:29.820 --> 00:04:31.270
Has Roman one, two, three and

92
00:04:31.270 --> 00:04:35.510
then normally from the first chapter,
we start with page one, two, three.

93
00:04:35.510 --> 00:04:39.030
So that's why it is important to
know how to play around with this.

94
00:04:39.030 --> 00:04:41.750
These are mixed that we'll talk about
a little later when you want to do

95
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:44.620
page breaks and then different numbers.

96
00:04:44.620 --> 00:04:48.930
In other words, conceptually the document
is a collection of documents.

97
00:04:48.930 --> 00:04:51.867
So the first part is
numbered Roman one to X and

98
00:04:51.867 --> 00:04:56.040
then the second part is
numbered one through whatever.

99
00:04:56.040 --> 00:04:57.550
So that can all be done and

100
00:04:57.550 --> 00:05:00.390
it can be reflected automatically
in the table of content.

101
00:05:00.390 --> 00:05:02.654
So there we go, we have page numbers.

102
00:05:02.654 --> 00:05:06.367
So let's say I want something
to appear in the header and

103
00:05:06.367 --> 00:05:10.721
footer of every page,
just like the page numbers are appearing.

104
00:05:10.721 --> 00:05:13.120
I want something to appear on every page.

105
00:05:13.120 --> 00:05:15.000
So let me just type something here.

106
00:05:15.000 --> 00:05:18.180
If I say it's been great.

107
00:05:18.180 --> 00:05:22.730
Well, that doesn't make a lot of sense but
just check it out.

108
00:05:22.730 --> 00:05:26.940
I go back to Home, I want to write a line,
we would have write a few things already.

109
00:05:26.940 --> 00:05:27.880
Write a line.

110
00:05:27.880 --> 00:05:30.040
The page number is right in the center and

111
00:05:30.040 --> 00:05:34.570
then I go click right in the middle of
the document and then I scroll down.

112
00:05:34.570 --> 00:05:38.726
See, already it's there on all pages,
all right?

113
00:05:38.726 --> 00:05:41.530
So I want to believe that
this is a useful feature.

114
00:05:41.530 --> 00:05:45.420
Because if for example, I'm working
on a report for an organization and

115
00:05:45.420 --> 00:05:50.660
they want their logo to appear on
every single page, 300 page document.

116
00:05:50.660 --> 00:05:54.610
How would you just copy that logo and
try to paste it in every single page?

117
00:05:54.610 --> 00:05:56.140
I don't think that's really smart.

118
00:05:56.140 --> 00:05:58.060
That's why Microsoft Word
created this tool.

119
00:05:58.060 --> 00:06:03.070
So all you just need to do is set
the logo in one spot, Header or

120
00:06:03.070 --> 00:06:05.510
footer and you're done.

121
00:06:05.510 --> 00:06:10.500
We can also do something on the footer and
it also appears on every single document.

122
00:06:10.500 --> 00:06:11.850
That's powerful, isn't it?

123
00:06:11.850 --> 00:06:14.870
>> It really is a powerful way for
us to make sure

124
00:06:14.870 --> 00:06:18.290
especially that when we start working
with larger amounts of documents.

125
00:06:18.290 --> 00:06:19.738
Now, our larger pages.

126
00:06:19.738 --> 00:06:24.710
Now Dr. Tonny used the example of his
particular dissertation to help us out.

127
00:06:24.710 --> 00:06:26.570
But we can understand
that within a company,

128
00:06:26.570 --> 00:06:29.190
as we do bring documents together.

129
00:06:29.190 --> 00:06:32.400
That what we want of course, is the page
number that extends all the way through

130
00:06:32.400 --> 00:06:36.190
those multiple documents we may
want to go ahead and put together.

131
00:06:36.190 --> 00:06:39.095
By making sure that everybody
does it in the page headers,

132
00:06:39.095 --> 00:06:43.032
we can now unite those documents together
as you actually learn how to do that.

133
00:06:43.032 --> 00:06:47.823
And you can make that page header to
be the same throughout the entire

134
00:06:47.823 --> 00:06:49.017
organization.

135
00:06:49.017 --> 00:06:50.390
Now Dr. Tonny,

136
00:06:50.390 --> 00:06:55.520
I've actually helped somebody by
editing a book for them before.

137
00:06:55.520 --> 00:06:59.580
And what they wanted was that ability
to be able to say here's what I want,

138
00:06:59.580 --> 00:07:01.396
I want the page numbers
to appear on each page.

139
00:07:01.396 --> 00:07:04.430
But then we even have this ability to say

140
00:07:04.430 --> 00:07:09.510
what he wanted was on the odd number pages
for the title of the book to appear.

141
00:07:09.510 --> 00:07:11.370
But then on the even numbered pages,

142
00:07:11.370 --> 00:07:15.670
he wanted the chapter title
to actually appear as well.

143
00:07:15.670 --> 00:07:19.810
So you have a lot of flexibility
here to be able to say hey,

144
00:07:19.810 --> 00:07:22.900
as you flip through here,
you know exactly what chapter you're in.

145
00:07:22.900 --> 00:07:24.350
And then you can look
on the other page and

146
00:07:24.350 --> 00:07:28.030
know what the title of the book
is going to be as well.

147
00:07:28.030 --> 00:07:29.800
So you have that ability and

148
00:07:29.800 --> 00:07:33.650
then with the page numbers, you can
then have things that are in sequence.

149
00:07:33.650 --> 00:07:38.660
I would have hate to actually seen Dr.
Tonny’s dissertation without page numbers.

150
00:07:38.660 --> 00:07:40.120
And all of a sudden you take 10 or

151
00:07:40.120 --> 00:07:43.560
15 pages, you throw them up on the air,
in the air and they all land.

152
00:07:43.560 --> 00:07:45.854
And then try and
gather them up and even though Dr.

153
00:07:45.854 --> 00:07:49.092
Tonnt wrote that, I think you would
even have a challenging time.

154
00:07:49.092 --> 00:07:50.306
What order does this come in?

155
00:07:50.306 --> 00:07:53.229
But by putting page numbers
on these larger documents,

156
00:07:53.229 --> 00:07:57.097
it allows us to be able to go ahead and
put them back in the proper sequence.

157
00:07:57.097 --> 00:07:59.784
So use of page numbers and headers here.

158
00:07:59.784 --> 00:08:04.280
The headers make it more efficient and
more productive for us to do it.

159
00:08:04.280 --> 00:08:08.736
The numbering itself and also whatever
other information gives us the logical

160
00:08:08.736 --> 00:08:10.964
ability to put things back in order, or

161
00:08:10.964 --> 00:08:15.170
to allow us to logically identify
what that work element is about.

162
00:08:15.170 --> 00:08:17.650
So that's why we want to
use things like this.

163
00:08:17.650 --> 00:08:19.550
Whether it appears in the page header or

164
00:08:19.550 --> 00:08:23.840
the page footer is all gonna depend on a
lot of times, especially at the university

165
00:08:23.840 --> 00:08:29.110
level, on a style guide that they may
actually ask you to use to present that.

166
00:08:29.110 --> 00:08:33.670
What goes where, they'll actually tell you
what they actually want in what position.

167
00:08:33.670 --> 00:08:37.471
But inside of a company you may have to
follow whatever standard formatting that

168
00:08:37.471 --> 00:08:40.250
they're using that lets you
know what you'll put in a page

169
00:08:40.250 --> 00:08:42.935
header versus what you'll put
in a page footer as well.

170
00:08:42.935 --> 00:08:46.949
So there's a lot of applications where
you'll see that this is gonna be stuff

171
00:08:46.949 --> 00:08:51.310
that they're gonna expect you to know
how to do, and to modify if necessary.

172
00:08:51.310 --> 00:08:55.026
So learning it right here is actually
a great place to begin, but there's a lot

173
00:08:55.026 --> 00:08:58.538
more details, just like I explained
to you, that you can learn how to do.

174
00:08:58.538 --> 00:09:01.930
>> Mm-hm, great, let's talk about
something very interesting also.

175
00:09:03.270 --> 00:09:05.970
Some people read Bibles.

176
00:09:05.970 --> 00:09:09.602
And when you look at the Bible it's
normally organized in columns.

177
00:09:09.602 --> 00:09:14.140
On the same page you've got text
in two different columns or more.

178
00:09:14.140 --> 00:09:18.570
And sometimes we also have magazines and
newspapers that have columns.

179
00:09:18.570 --> 00:09:21.450
Have you asked yourself,
how did someone organize that?

180
00:09:21.450 --> 00:09:22.580
Here, we'll show you.

181
00:09:22.580 --> 00:09:26.700
So look at my screen,
if I select some text now.

182
00:09:26.700 --> 00:09:30.370
I say, well I would like this to
be two columns so when we read to

183
00:09:30.370 --> 00:09:34.250
the bottom there's some space there and
then you move to another column.

184
00:09:34.250 --> 00:09:37.050
So let's go to Page Layout tab and

185
00:09:37.050 --> 00:09:40.420
then that's where the orientation
was about page set up.

186
00:09:40.420 --> 00:09:41.700
There is something about columns.

187
00:09:41.700 --> 00:09:44.460
So if I click that, it gives me options.

188
00:09:44.460 --> 00:09:49.260
You can have one column, two columns,
three columns, left, right.

189
00:09:49.260 --> 00:09:50.170
So you have an option there.

190
00:09:50.170 --> 00:09:52.560
So let me just pick three columns.

191
00:09:52.560 --> 00:09:54.890
My text is already in three
columns automatically.

192
00:09:56.360 --> 00:10:01.100
Well, what if I wanted to manipulate
this space within, between the two or

193
00:10:01.100 --> 00:10:03.550
three paragraphs,
I mean columns, for that matter.

194
00:10:03.550 --> 00:10:07.490
So I can come and click Columns and
I go to More Columns.

195
00:10:07.490 --> 00:10:09.990
It gives me a few other options.

196
00:10:09.990 --> 00:10:13.370
I could actually increase the number
of columns and make them many.

197
00:10:13.370 --> 00:10:15.190
Five, six, whatever number.

198
00:10:15.190 --> 00:10:15.800
But of course,

199
00:10:15.800 --> 00:10:20.600
you gotta be realistic as to how much
text can there be in a particular column.

200
00:10:20.600 --> 00:10:24.040
So let's say I wanna do three columns, and

201
00:10:24.040 --> 00:10:27.920
I want to play around with
the space between the columns.

202
00:10:27.920 --> 00:10:34.160
So I can say well, the width of the column
is gonna be something like two inches.

203
00:10:34.160 --> 00:10:38.702
And then I reduce the space between and
say it's gonna be 0.1.

204
00:10:38.702 --> 00:10:42.020
So I can play around with that and
then I say boom, let me select.

205
00:10:42.020 --> 00:10:43.550
See, the text has actually moved.

206
00:10:43.550 --> 00:10:48.428
So I could basically work on an entire
document and have it in different formats.

207
00:10:48.428 --> 00:10:53.753
So a page could have columns,
another one we're going to have images,

208
00:10:53.753 --> 00:10:56.338
another one probably has a table.

209
00:10:56.338 --> 00:11:00.050
And so we're gonna go now into very
specific things just like I just

210
00:11:00.050 --> 00:11:02.840
mentioned, tables and
images as we proceed.

211
00:11:02.840 --> 00:11:05.970
I really do hope that this is
an interesting feature that you can use.

212
00:11:05.970 --> 00:11:10.100
>> This is really one of the great
features that actually helped you out in

213
00:11:10.100 --> 00:11:11.649
Word to be very creative.

214
00:11:11.649 --> 00:11:16.207
In college, Dr. Tonny, I had a newsletter
that I actually created by using

215
00:11:16.207 --> 00:11:19.995
something like Word, and
I wanted it to look like a newspaper.

216
00:11:19.995 --> 00:11:22.074
Now, they weren't, of course,

217
00:11:22.074 --> 00:11:26.850
anything as far as the intellectual
ability of my writing at that point.

218
00:11:26.850 --> 00:11:30.880
But overall though, I really wanted it to
look like a regular newspaper would look.

219
00:11:30.880 --> 00:11:33.910
And even though I only had
a regular printer with me, and

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa introduce the skills and techniques for getting started with Microsoft Excel 2010.  They show and describe working with workbooks and worksheets helping users to distinguish between them.  They also show how to navigate around the interface of Excel 2010 and selecting text in Excel.  Dr. Omwansa shows how to use the series fill feature to help with productivity.  They slow down when it comes to deleting the data from a cell because of the effect it will have on the surrounding data.  Lastly, they take a look at using Merge and Center to help logically segment the data in an easy and effective manner.
episodes.title: Introduction to Microsoft Excel 2010

00:22:07.090 --> 00:22:10.620
say okay, so what if I want to
play around with that table,

402
00:22:10.620 --> 00:22:14.390
that text that I've already put
together into columns and rows.

403
00:22:14.390 --> 00:22:20.460
So what you could do here is,
I just created my simple document here.

404
00:22:20.460 --> 00:22:23.802
Just added a little value to it,
put some color on that-

405
00:22:23.802 --> 00:22:25.219
>> The header.

406
00:22:25.219 --> 00:22:29.263
>> The heading, like the header there is
starting to look a little interesting.

407
00:22:29.263 --> 00:22:32.853
As you can tell, the columns and
rows are just looking the same, so

408
00:22:32.853 --> 00:22:35.161
we can begin to add value to this table,
and

409
00:22:35.161 --> 00:22:38.516
there are a lot of other things
we can do with that table later.

410
00:22:38.516 --> 00:22:42.946
So let's first of all say, suppose I want
to add a column right in the middle, or

411
00:22:42.946 --> 00:22:46.200
a row, or I want to add a cell,
I want to delete a cell.

412
00:22:46.200 --> 00:22:50.269
That means I'm configuring these tables to
be a little more flexible and friendly.

413
00:22:51.340 --> 00:22:55.420
So over here, if I want to delete
an entire row, I can just go and

414
00:22:55.420 --> 00:22:58.430
point right up here at the header.

415
00:22:58.430 --> 00:23:01.930
And when I click it,
it selects the entire row.

416
00:23:01.930 --> 00:23:05.838
And then I right-click, and
I can actually delete it.

417
00:23:05.838 --> 00:23:10.600
Assuming I wanted to add something before
H like a column, so I can right there.

418
00:23:10.600 --> 00:23:16.910
D > Right-click > Insert, it inserts for
me a row, or a column rather.

419
00:23:16.910 --> 00:23:21.640
Then I can resize that column if I want,
right, left.

420
00:23:21.640 --> 00:23:25.150
I can say well,
I want to insert another row here, and

421
00:23:25.150 --> 00:23:28.670
I can right-click and
insert a row there, all right?

422
00:23:28.670 --> 00:23:32.813
And then, if I wanted to delete it,
I can just click the whole row, and

00:23:32.813 --> 00:23:33.734
then I delete.

424
00:23:33.734 --> 00:23:38.940
And then, let's say I'm not
sure I wanted this cell here.

00:23:38.940 --> 00:23:40.880
I can actually delete that cell.

00:23:40.880 --> 00:23:43.390
Something very interesting

427
00:23:43.390 --> 00:23:47.805
If you're deleting a cell, what happens
to the rest of the text that was

00:23:47.805 --> 00:23:51.058
in that particular row, or
column for that matter?

429
00:23:51.058 --> 00:23:53.449
So Excel will ask you simple questions.

430
00:23:53.449 --> 00:23:56.790
Well look,
do you want to shift everything up?

431
00:23:56.790 --> 00:23:57.553
Because you're not losing.

432
00:23:57.553 --> 00:24:00.413
You only wanted to delete the cell,
not the entire column, or

433
00:24:00.413 --> 00:24:02.600
you wanna move things through the right.

434
00:24:02.600 --> 00:24:03.220
What do you wanna do?

435
00:24:03.220 --> 00:24:05.040
So it gives you the various options.

436
00:24:05.040 --> 00:24:10.670
So for me, I'm just speaking a default one
here, shift things up and I shift them.

437
00:24:10.670 --> 00:24:13.910
Now you have to be very sure that's
what you wanted to do because,

438
00:24:13.910 --> 00:24:18.450
as you can tell now, the age of 21 is 18.

439
00:24:18.450 --> 00:24:21.062
The last I checked, I'm actually not 18.

440
00:24:21.062 --> 00:24:24.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right?

441
00:24:24.400 --> 00:24:28.060
And what has happened to the rest of
the people is it dramatically shifted

442
00:24:28.060 --> 00:24:28.725
their ages.

443
00:24:28.725 --> 00:24:30.333
That could actually not be true.

444
00:24:30.333 --> 00:24:34.195
So you have to be careful about
what you do, if you do it that way.

445
00:24:34.195 --> 00:24:36.745
That's why sometimes moving
the entire row, entire column,

446
00:24:36.745 --> 00:24:41.395
is easier and a little more accurate.

447
00:24:41.395 --> 00:24:44.635
The likelihood that you
will change things and

448
00:24:44.635 --> 00:24:47.065
destruct the whole document is much lower.

449
00:24:47.065 --> 00:24:48.975
But anyway,
sometimes you might need to do that.

450
00:24:48.975 --> 00:24:51.415
So what I've just done here,
I've undone the whole thing.

451
00:24:54.190 --> 00:24:55.352
So now, here you go.

452
00:24:55.352 --> 00:24:56.260
You can do cells.

453
00:24:56.260 --> 00:24:57.190
You can do columns.

454
00:24:57.190 --> 00:24:58.031
You can do rows.

455
00:24:58.031 --> 00:24:59.640
You can add.

456
00:24:59.640 --> 00:25:02.450
Right now, you still haven't made
this table very sophisticated but

457
00:25:02.450 --> 00:25:03.370
at least there you go.

458
00:25:03.370 --> 00:25:06.305
You can play around with the cells,
columns, and rows.

459
00:25:06.305 --> 00:25:09.842
>> In this idea and feature of
actually deleting the information.

460
00:25:09.842 --> 00:25:15.640
This is where we must be incredibly
careful the way that Doctor described it.

461
00:25:15.640 --> 00:25:20.130
And the reason why is that because of the
way that the information is stored now,

462
00:25:20.130 --> 00:25:23.860
in which all the data
is related in that row.

463
00:25:23.860 --> 00:25:25.470
If you do happen to try and

464
00:25:25.470 --> 00:25:29.150
delete a single cell,
you only have those default options.

465
00:25:29.150 --> 00:25:33.490
And that means it's gonna pretty
much either shift all the other

466
00:25:33.490 --> 00:25:38.790
information in that column or that row a
way that you may not actually understand.

467
00:25:38.790 --> 00:25:42.200
So before you ever do this,
verify, and check, and

468
00:25:42.200 --> 00:25:45.510
ensure that you're data
is exactly what you need.

469
00:25:45.510 --> 00:25:50.980
If you are unsure of this, my
recommendation instead is to make a copy

470
00:25:50.980 --> 00:25:55.010
of that worksheet or that workbook and
name it something else.

471
00:25:55.010 --> 00:25:58.120
And then try and delete it from there and

472
00:25:58.120 --> 00:26:01.960
see if that result actually
gives you what you want.

473
00:26:01.960 --> 00:26:07.890
If not, do not do it on your data that
is actually in use for your company.

474
00:26:07.890 --> 00:26:12.210
Because by shifting just one row of data,
or

475
00:26:12.210 --> 00:26:16.010
that one cell of data, or
that one column of data up just one row.

476
00:26:16.010 --> 00:26:21.902
You could really have data that no
longer means anything to your company.

477
00:26:21.902 --> 00:26:26.603
Which now means it's useless to you
because it's no longer reporting accurate

478
00:26:26.603 --> 00:26:27.522
information.

479
00:26:27.522 --> 00:26:29.675
But there are times you need to do so, so

480
00:26:29.675 --> 00:26:33.120
you want to be very careful
about this particular tool.

481
00:26:33.120 --> 00:26:37.570
It is one of the things that if you,
it can really mess up

482
00:26:37.570 --> 00:26:42.010
information very badly so
be very careful, but it is a useful tool.

483
00:26:42.010 --> 00:26:43.720
As long as you remember, columns,

484
00:26:43.720 --> 00:26:47.560
all the information are stored in
that particular row is interrelated.

485
00:26:47.560 --> 00:26:51.200
And then those columns, if you shift
stuff up, it's gonna break those column

486
00:26:51.200 --> 00:26:55.760
relationships, as far as the logical
relationship of the data in-between them.

487
00:26:55.760 --> 00:26:57.110
So be very careful here.

488
00:26:57.110 --> 00:27:00.100
It's a strict warning,
it's an over emphasized warning, but

489
00:27:00.100 --> 00:27:04.600
it is necessary cuz you do not want
to break somebody else's data.

490
00:27:04.600 --> 00:27:08.700
It is very much not something ever
that you want somebody to say,

491
00:27:08.700 --> 00:27:10.300
well, the data's meaningless anymore.

492
00:27:11.680 --> 00:27:14.337
>> All right, so
we're gonna do is just two more things.

493
00:27:14.337 --> 00:27:17.600
Because our show's a little bit
in terms of amount of Time.

494
00:27:17.600 --> 00:27:21.197
We're gonna do two more things, and then
we can wrap up in this particular show.

495
00:27:21.197 --> 00:27:26.340
I've just created additional
row at the top of my table.

496
00:27:26.340 --> 00:27:27.969
Maybe I'll just do two.

497
00:27:27.969 --> 00:27:30.910
So I've inserted,
now we've got two additional rows.

498
00:27:30.910 --> 00:27:34.360
So let's say that this table
needed to have a title.

499
00:27:34.360 --> 00:27:39.270
And then my boss told me that
the title is supposed to be Students

500
00:27:39.270 --> 00:27:40.660
who did not show up.

501
00:27:40.660 --> 00:27:45.940
So I go like, okay,
Students who did not show up.

502
00:27:45.940 --> 00:27:49.130
Now, if I select that particular cell and

503
00:27:49.130 --> 00:27:53.870
I look at the formula bar,
the whole text is there.

504
00:27:53.870 --> 00:27:57.936
But as I can tell, that text is kind

00:27:57.936 --> 00:28:03.950
One way to handle this is that I
can actually widen that column.

506
00:28:03.950 --> 00:28:05.990
And then there we go, so
it's not overlapping.

507
00:28:05.990 --> 00:28:07.860
But again, I've lost the format of this.

00:28:07.860 --> 00:28:10.210
It's doesn't look like it's really nice.

509
00:28:10.210 --> 00:28:12.960
I wish all the columns were

00:28:12.960 --> 00:28:15.020
So let me undo that, and

00:28:15.020 --> 00:28:19.880

00:28:19.880 --> 00:28:24.830
So if I select this cell and drop to the

00:28:24.830 --> 00:28:28.080
And I go up there,
there is an opportunity to merge cells.

514
00:28:28.080 --> 00:28:29.990
Of course, you can do right-click here and

515
00:28:29.990 --> 00:28:33.840
then you can try to figure out how
to merge through the format cells.

516
00:28:33.840 --> 00:28:36.070
But now let me merge those two cells.

517
00:28:36.070 --> 00:28:37.820
So there we go, I've merged the two cells.

518
00:28:37.820 --> 00:28:39.452
But as I think about it,

00:28:39.452 --> 00:28:43.600
it's still not very well balanced,

00:28:43.600 --> 00:28:47.930
So one way to do it is to select the

00:28:47.930 --> 00:28:50.020

00:28:51.070 --> 00:28:53.290
And that means I have several options.

I can merge and center align it,

00:28:57.880 --> 00:29:00.050

00:29:00.050 --> 00:29:01.220
So, there we go.

00:29:01.220 --> 00:29:06.520
My text is now symmetrically center

527
00:29:06.520 --> 00:29:08.980
So now I have a title for my table.

528
00:29:08.980 --> 00:29:10.727
And maybe, if I was in the right mood,

00:29:10.727 --> 00:29:12.923
I can actually put some

00:29:12.923 --> 00:29:16.296
And say, okay, fine,
it's gonna be something like grey, and

00:29:16.296 --> 00:29:18.620

00:29:18.620 --> 00:29:21.550
Now what I'm doing here is I'm actually

00:29:21.550 --> 00:29:26.150

534
00:29:26.150 --> 00:29:29.630
And that's why we spend some time to

00:29:29.630 --> 00:29:33.530
So now we have center aligned, some title.

00:29:33.530 --> 00:29:39.900
And sometimes maybe the text can be so

00:29:39.900 --> 00:29:43.010
So maybe I say, I put in bracket,

00:29:43.010 --> 00:29:46.930

00:29:46.930 --> 00:29:51.530
So let's hypothetically say I

00:29:51.530 --> 00:29:54.430

541
00:29:54.430 --> 00:29:56.238
I don't want it to spill

00:29:56.238 --> 00:30:01.730
Because if I move and point elsewhere,

00:30:01.730 --> 00:30:04.674
I don't want to start

00:30:04.674 --> 00:30:09.890
What I could possibly do is I can actually

00:30:09.890 --> 00:30:14.850
What that, basically, does is it

00:30:14.850 --> 00:30:16.630
Now, right now, it's not visible, but

00:30:16.630 --> 00:30:21.480
if I actually increase the height

548
00:30:21.480 --> 00:30:22.540
Then, wow, there I am.

00:30:22.540 --> 00:30:26.720
I now have something in brackets and

550
00:30:26.720 --> 00:30:30.010
It's well balanced and

551
00:30:30.010 --> 00:30:32.780
So looking at that whole section up there.

00:30:32.780 --> 00:30:35.780
We've talked a little about wrapping and

00:30:35.780 --> 00:30:38.500

00:30:38.500 --> 00:30:44.810
And the beautiful thing about tables, and

00:30:44.810 --> 00:30:49.020

00:30:49.020 --> 00:30:51.970
You can also do for the entire cell,

00:30:51.970 --> 00:30:56.740
So you can actually align to the top, or

00:30:56.740 --> 00:30:58.200
to the right of the center.

559
00:30:58.200 --> 00:30:59.990
All those options exist.

560
00:30:59.990 --> 00:31:03.410
And I hope this is a useful function,
because now we're gonna close for

00:31:03.410 --> 00:31:04.390
this session.

562
00:31:04.390 --> 00:31:09.140
And I hope that you can create some

563
00:31:09.140 --> 00:31:12.610
>> There's no doubt that these functions
that we're seeing, that merge and center.

564
00:31:12.610 --> 00:31:17.569
Really does help set off that particular
type of data as something that people

00:31:17.569 --> 00:31:19.280

00:31:19.280 --> 00:31:23.840
You may have lots of information, but you

the example here,
sales only in the month of August.

00:31:28.150 --> 00:31:32.050
And even though you might have the entire

569
00:31:32.050 --> 00:31:34.940
You may go ahead and create that
where you merge, and center, and

570
00:31:34.940 --> 00:31:37.170

571
00:31:37.170 --> 00:31:41.590
And that way it looks like it's broken

572
00:31:41.590 --> 00:31:43.410
And doing that merge and
center really does help.

573
00:31:43.410 --> 00:31:47.310
Because it helps to set and distinguish
itself from all the other figures

574
00:31:47.310 --> 00:31:49.650
that you may have set up there as well.

575
00:31:49.650 --> 00:31:53.530
Well, this actually does give us at
least a great starting point for

576
00:31:53.530 --> 00:31:57.000
what we need to understand when

577
00:31:57.000 --> 00:32:00.490
But there is plenty more to go and so,
Doctor that means we're coming back for

578
00:32:00.490 --> 00:32:01.390
a part two, right?

579
00:32:01.390 --> 00:32:03.070
>> Yeah.
We're gonna come back for part two.

580
00:32:03.070 --> 00:32:03.590

581

Well, that's a great place for

582
00:32:06.322 --> 00:32:08.190
Signing off for ITPro TV.

583
00:32:08.190 --> 00:32:10.750
I've been your host, Ronny Wong.

584
00:32:10.750 --> 00:32:14.320
>> And right here,
enjoying learning together.

00:32:14.320 --> 00:32:18.699

00:32:18.699 --> 00:32:24.019
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa continue with the skills and techniques for getting started with Microsoft Excel 2010.  They start with introducing numbering formats and explain the importance of them for receivers of the data and how to change the numbering format. Also they show how to add borders to cells and tables.  Dr. Omwansa also introduces users how to create a basic formula in excel and how to use the simple auto fill functions to produce some aggregate value.  Also in this episode, they show how to work with data tables and create charts for the data we have.
episodes.title: Introduction to Microsoft Excel 2010 Part 2

And where we begin is the idea of
