which I call Sales.

487
00:28:33.700 --> 00:28:39.300
And I said, well, let's just simplify
it and we have the same names there.

488
00:28:39.300 --> 00:28:45.130
And then we have, Tony was able to sell

489
00:28:47.470 --> 00:28:51.170
merchandise worth 100 King's shillings,
hypothetical.

490
00:28:51.170 --> 00:28:55.850
And then Jim's was able to sell
worth 18 shillings, John 40, on and

491
00:28:55.850 --> 00:28:58.220
on and on, all right?

492
00:28:58.220 --> 00:28:58.950
So I'm going to try and

493
00:28:58.950 --> 00:29:03.188
increase the font so that maybe it's
a little more visible, there we go.

494
00:29:03.188 --> 00:29:07.830
So I have a total of an amount, and

495
00:29:07.830 --> 00:29:11.480
what happened is that people were
selling in different months.

496
00:29:13.560 --> 00:29:17.290
So the months should be any
month between January and

497
00:29:17.290 --> 00:29:21.300
December and simple.

498
00:29:21.300 --> 00:29:28.580
Somebody came and reported that Tony
sold 100 worth in the month of December.

499
00:29:28.580 --> 00:29:32.782
And James sold 18 in the month of
February, something along those lines.

500
00:29:32.782 --> 00:29:34.590
Of course,
this doesn't make a lot of sense yet,

501
00:29:34.590 --> 00:29:38.630
but just to demonstrate we need
to create some simple chart.

502
00:29:38.630 --> 00:29:44.341
So if I come here and select the entire
text like we said, and then I go Insert.

503
00:29:44.341 --> 00:29:48.750
And then I select, let's say we
want to create some bar charts.

504
00:29:50.950 --> 00:29:56.510
And it's in column version,
cuz you can also do it in horizontal form.

505
00:29:56.510 --> 00:30:01.122
So let's pick one and
I want to do a two dimensional chart,

506
00:30:01.122 --> 00:30:04.680
bar chart for that matter.

507
00:30:04.680 --> 00:30:06.250
And here we come.

508
00:30:06.250 --> 00:30:09.800
So it's created for me some simple chart.

509
00:30:09.800 --> 00:30:11.810
And I want to resize it, so

510
00:30:11.810 --> 00:30:16.780
that we see what is the connection
between the chart itself and the data.

511
00:30:16.780 --> 00:30:21.200
So what Excel has done, is it has
created for me an x axis and a y axis.

512
00:30:21.200 --> 00:30:25.130
So x axis gives me the names
of the people, and

513
00:30:25.130 --> 00:30:29.450
on the y axis, it's given me that amount.

514
00:30:29.450 --> 00:30:32.282
It's just created a scale from 0 to 250.

515
00:30:32.282 --> 00:30:36.387
Now, you will note that it has
created very reasonable intervals.

516
00:30:36.387 --> 00:30:40.462
I didn't create them, but it has
the intelligence to figure out, well,

517
00:30:40.462 --> 00:30:43.435
the largest amount that
you had was actually 200.

518
00:30:43.435 --> 00:30:48.725
So I'll give it up to 250 and then I'll
list all the individuals on the right.

519
00:30:48.725 --> 00:30:50.635
Now there are two columns.

520
00:30:50.635 --> 00:30:54.427
So what it's basically done, for
Tonny O, it's actually said,

521
00:30:54.427 --> 00:30:57.895
you can see the amount of 100
is actually reflected here.

522
00:30:57.895 --> 00:31:00.684
And if you point right there,
you'll see the value is 100.

523
00:31:00.684 --> 00:31:07.180
And then it has also put the second
column, for Tonny again, of 12.

524
00:31:07.180 --> 00:31:12.890
So using the same scale, that's why this
one is appearing to be smaller, all right?

525
00:31:12.890 --> 00:31:16.400
So this way I am now represented and
automatically it created for

526
00:31:16.400 --> 00:31:18.040
me some kind of index,

527
00:31:18.040 --> 00:31:23.672
some kind of way of describing what
exactly are the two colors for, all right.

528
00:31:23.672 --> 00:31:30.590
So color legend or whatever it may be
called in your own representation.

529
00:31:30.590 --> 00:31:31.550
So there we go.

530
00:31:31.550 --> 00:31:34.850
We can have a title if we want it,
but at least it gives you a sense.

531
00:31:34.850 --> 00:31:38.490
Now lets try to change a value and
see what happens to the chart.

532
00:31:38.490 --> 00:31:41.965
So I'm gonna change this to 8.

533
00:31:43.500 --> 00:31:46.040
See what happens,
automatically it increases.

534
00:31:46.040 --> 00:31:48.646
So let's look at this,
the long one of 200.

535
00:31:48.646 --> 00:31:52.060
So assuming it's a mistake,
it should have been 100.

536
00:31:52.060 --> 00:31:53.709
So I delete this and put 100.

537
00:31:53.709 --> 00:31:58.509
Yep, then it's adjusted.

538
00:31:58.509 --> 00:32:03.079
And basically what happens, it adjust the
Entire sheet, so that it's proportionate.

539
00:32:03.079 --> 00:32:09.870
If for example, this was 400 because
the scale right now is up to 150,

540
00:32:09.870 --> 00:32:15.290
so let's change that to 400 and
see what will happen.

541
00:32:15.290 --> 00:32:16.664
So I delete and say 400.

542
00:32:18.050 --> 00:32:20.700
So what it's basically done,
it's changed the scale.

543
00:32:20.700 --> 00:32:24.710
Recomputes, figures out what would
be the possibly largest number.

544
00:32:24.710 --> 00:32:25.390
Yeah, 400.

545
00:32:25.390 --> 00:32:27.370
Now, I'm trying to add that by 100.

546
00:32:27.370 --> 00:32:31.953
It's created maximum 500, and then,

547
00:32:31.953 --> 00:32:36.150
it redistributes the entire
set of numbers over there.

548
00:32:36.150 --> 00:32:37.830
And you can see 400 is the largest.

549
00:32:37.830 --> 00:32:43.460
It's just a simple way
of creating a chart.

550
00:32:43.460 --> 00:32:45.570
Just a simple chart.

551
00:32:45.570 --> 00:32:49.360
There are many other kinds of
charts as you can see up here.

552
00:32:49.360 --> 00:32:53.812
There are bar charts, there are areas,
there are scatters, there are pie charts,

553
00:32:53.812 --> 00:32:55.750
there are line graphs, all that.

554
00:32:55.750 --> 00:33:00.610
And it's possible to move between these
kind of charts, different kinds of charts.

555
00:33:00.610 --> 00:33:06.030
So for example, I could say let me try,
I pick name and

556
00:33:06.030 --> 00:33:10.770
the amount and
then I say I wanna do a pie chart.

557
00:33:10.770 --> 00:33:12.790
And I just click a pie chart.

558
00:33:12.790 --> 00:33:13.770
I've got a pie chart here.

559
00:33:13.770 --> 00:33:19.270
Of course I can do the necessary edits
that I want, and then there is a chart.

560
00:33:19.270 --> 00:33:24.190
This is the largest area and I can go to
the data and see what exactly was that.

561
00:33:24.190 --> 00:33:26.290
I can change one chart to another.

562
00:33:26.290 --> 00:33:27.400
I can very,

563
00:33:27.400 --> 00:33:32.220
very easily, if I right-click that chart,
I can simply change that chart type.

564
00:33:32.220 --> 00:33:34.740
If I click that and then I go, okay,

565
00:33:34.740 --> 00:33:37.350
I want to see what other
chart could it possibly be.

566
00:33:37.350 --> 00:33:40.000
Let me select this one and
see what happens.

567
00:33:40.000 --> 00:33:42.630
Whoa, it creates a different
kind of chart, same data,

568
00:33:42.630 --> 00:33:44.440
but different representation.

569
00:33:44.440 --> 00:33:47.900
So why do you possibly need
different representation?

570
00:33:47.900 --> 00:33:50.820
It depends on the kind of
communication you wanna give.

571
00:33:50.820 --> 00:33:53.300
What kind of information
do you wanna pass around?

572
00:33:53.300 --> 00:33:57.310
Because some charts are better at
representing certain kind of data.

573
00:33:57.310 --> 00:34:00.930
You don't want hundreds of bars.

574
00:34:00.930 --> 00:34:04.990
Or it you have some very simple data
that is showing three elements,

575
00:34:04.990 --> 00:34:08.420
you're probably wanting
to show how do these

576
00:34:08.420 --> 00:34:11.020
three elements relate to
the larger scheme of things.

577
00:34:11.020 --> 00:34:12.900
So out of 100 where do they fit?

578
00:34:12.900 --> 00:34:15.100
What is the ratio here?

579
00:34:15.100 --> 00:34:18.160
So you could do a bar chart.

580
00:34:18.160 --> 00:34:19.020
So this is not for

581
00:34:19.020 --> 00:34:23.380
purposes of trying to explain what
is a chart and what kind of chart.

582
00:34:23.380 --> 00:34:28.110
We're not in a statistics class now, we're
basically trying to say that you have

583
00:34:28.110 --> 00:34:32.740
an opportunity for creating different kind
of charts, moving around between charts.

584
00:34:32.740 --> 00:34:36.017
And then after which you can manipulate
this chart, create the titles,

585
00:34:36.017 --> 00:34:40.110
the themes, you can change the colors
here and there and re-present these and

586
00:34:40.110 --> 00:34:41.180
you can export these.

587
00:34:41.180 --> 00:34:44.200
That means we can extract it and
put it in a different document.

588
00:34:44.200 --> 00:34:47.210
So you're working on a Word document,
and you're writing a report.

589
00:34:47.210 --> 00:34:49.880
You can manipulate this data,
generate the chart, and

590
00:34:49.880 --> 00:34:52.480
then migrate that chart and
put it in a Word document.

591
00:34:52.480 --> 00:34:53.560
And then print something really,

592
00:34:53.560 --> 00:34:57.030
really beautiful which contains
a lot of information all together.

593
00:34:57.030 --> 00:35:01.140
I want to believe that charts is one
of the very important tools that

594
00:35:01.140 --> 00:35:03.530
people must learn when
they're using Excel.

595
00:35:03.530 --> 00:35:07.410
>> There is no doubt that charts really
make the impact that we need to and

596
00:35:07.410 --> 00:35:11.160
it really helps to give
us a graphical summary

597
00:35:11.160 --> 00:35:13.620
of a bunch of the data that we're seeing.

598
00:35:13.620 --> 00:35:16.640
Now the key here to understanding
what charts to pick is

599
00:35:16.640 --> 00:35:19.830
you being familiar with
the data that you're using.

600
00:35:19.830 --> 00:35:23.220
It doesn't tend to make sense if you're
not familiar with the data that you're

601
00:35:23.220 --> 00:35:26.040
using to try and make a chart at all.

602
00:35:26.040 --> 00:35:31.290
But once you start seeing the actual data,
it may be where somebody says you need to

603
00:35:31.290 --> 00:35:38.390
create a chart in which you're comparing
the sales user for the month of January.

604
00:35:38.390 --> 00:35:40.020
Well, if you have a single series chart,

605
00:35:40.020 --> 00:35:42.885
you may go,
well that's actually a piece of the pie.

606
00:35:42.885 --> 00:35:47.180
Well how much does each particular
salesperson make of that piece of the pie?

607
00:35:47.180 --> 00:35:52.020
Or you may be comparing each salesperson
with the multiple months, so

608
00:35:52.020 --> 00:35:56.820
it might be where you actually say, I
want to see all of the actual sales data,

609
00:35:56.820 --> 00:36:00.770
by salesperson and
the first quarter of the year.

610
00:36:00.770 --> 00:36:02.590
Well, you're actually taking
a look at the same data, but

611
00:36:02.590 --> 00:36:05.060
for each month in the first year.

612
00:36:05.060 --> 00:36:07.790
Well, then you might create a bar
chart that actually shows multiple

613
00:36:07.790 --> 00:36:11.170
series of data that's the same
type of data, but over time.

614
00:36:11.170 --> 00:36:14.420
And you might find yourself actually
using some of the other ones.

615
00:36:14.420 --> 00:36:18.950
But at the very beginning, at least
understanding the basics of a pie and

616
00:36:18.950 --> 00:36:21.610
bar chart is where we want to begin.

617
00:36:21.610 --> 00:36:25.470
And this is all so that we don't
tend to hand over a spreadsheet

618
00:36:25.470 --> 00:36:29.710
that just has let's say 60 rows in it and

619
00:36:29.710 --> 00:36:34.790
then of course that means there's actually
three or four or maybe ten columns.

620
00:36:34.790 --> 00:36:38.770
What we might be able to do instead is
actually be able to summarize that data,

621
00:36:38.770 --> 00:36:41.080
present it in a graphical way.

622
00:36:41.080 --> 00:36:43.880
And now which people can
take a look at that and

623
00:36:43.880 --> 00:36:48.756
begin to actually say, all right, so
comparatively by using the chart,

624
00:36:48.756 --> 00:36:53.560
Did Tonny actually win in the first
quarter as far as number of sales?

625
00:36:53.560 --> 00:36:55.988
Well, we don’t have to look
at the individual numbers.

626
00:36:55.988 --> 00:36:59.450
If Dr Tonny's bar is higher than
everybody else's, then we know,

627
00:36:59.450 --> 00:37:02.560
yes, he actually did
take a lead in that one.

628
00:37:02.560 --> 00:37:04.690
And that's why charts are very important.

629
00:37:04.690 --> 00:37:09.860
It doesn't actually give us really, as far
as a lot of technical details behind it.

630
00:37:09.860 --> 00:37:14.650
But presenting that summary information
allows us to then be able to interpret

631
00:37:14.650 --> 00:37:19.370
that data and make good decision based
off of the details of the data, without

632
00:37:19.370 --> 00:37:23.710
having to overwhelm whoever the audience
is with the details of that data as well.

633
00:37:23.710 --> 00:37:25.450
So very much an important element,

634
00:37:25.450 --> 00:37:30.300
in terms of you learning how to use Excel,
is learning how to create these charts.

635
00:37:30.300 --> 00:37:32.320
>> Right.
We've been here on it for a while and

636
00:37:32.320 --> 00:37:36.330
I think it's about time that
we come to close this session.

637
00:37:36.330 --> 00:37:40.180
But this is one thing
I want us to go with.

638
00:37:40.180 --> 00:37:40.970
Sorting data.

639
00:37:42.110 --> 00:37:47.050
If you've created columns and rows, and
we've got numbers in there, sometimes you

640
00:37:47.050 --> 00:37:52.770
want to have a sense, roughly, what is the
sequence, what is the pattern, all right.

641
00:37:52.770 --> 00:37:56.085
So what I've done on my computer right
now is that I've actually selected

642
00:37:56.085 --> 00:37:58.331
the text that we've been
actually working with,

643
00:37:58.331 --> 00:38:01.740
the names there, there's Kenyan
shillings and there's month.

644
00:38:01.740 --> 00:38:06.120
So let us try to say,
I want to get a sense of

645
00:38:06.120 --> 00:38:10.150
the order as to who are the people
who owes the largest amount.

646
00:38:10.150 --> 00:38:14.640
You know, so I start with the largest and
go all the way to the lowest.

647
00:38:14.640 --> 00:38:17.910
So we can organize this in many,
many ways but

648
00:38:17.910 --> 00:38:21.120
I just want to simply
illustrate a simple example.

649
00:38:21.120 --> 00:38:25.110
So I can select this whole text and

650
00:38:25.110 --> 00:38:29.180
then I can go sort and
filter and I do a custom sort.

651
00:38:29.180 --> 00:38:32.448
The reason I'm going with the custom sort
is that there are generic ways of course

652
00:38:32.448 --> 00:38:35.000
of doing all of this that have
been already pre designed.

653
00:38:35.000 --> 00:38:37.740
But I think a custom sort is
going to help us create our own

654
00:38:37.740 --> 00:38:39.380
rules of how we want to sort it.

655
00:38:39.380 --> 00:38:41.450
So I'm going to click Custom Sort.

656
00:38:41.450 --> 00:38:44.650
And then it gives me
an opportunity to decide by what

657
00:38:44.650 --> 00:38:46.520
do I want to sort that text.

658
00:38:46.520 --> 00:38:49.720
So I'll say I want to sort it
by the Kenyan shillings column,

659
00:38:49.720 --> 00:38:53.930
which tells me that fine,
everything else will remain the same.

660
00:38:53.930 --> 00:38:55.250
So it'll be moved, but

661
00:38:55.250 --> 00:39:00.870
the sorting will happen on the basis
of the amount that is owed to us.

662
00:39:00.870 --> 00:39:03.010
And then I pick the values.

663
00:39:03.010 --> 00:39:06.240
And then I say I want to sort
from the largest to the smallest.

664
00:39:06.240 --> 00:39:07.130
And then I say OK.

665
00:39:08.420 --> 00:39:14.010
Now what happens over here is
that it moves the rows up and

666
00:39:14.010 --> 00:39:19.300
down and arranges based on
the certain sort of the amount owed.

667
00:39:19.300 --> 00:39:26.320
So Tonny is the one who owes us 200 Kenyan
shillings, and that's for the month.

668
00:39:26.320 --> 00:39:27.558
Forget about the month for now.

669
00:39:27.558 --> 00:39:34.051
A different Tonny maybe, owes us 100,
Tonny owes us this much.

670
00:39:34.051 --> 00:39:38.870
So right now they owe that
in decrementing order.

671
00:39:38.870 --> 00:39:42.870
I could have done in incrementing order,
I could've done in whatever.

672
00:39:42.870 --> 00:39:45.370
I could've ordered this on month.

673
00:39:45.370 --> 00:39:49.710
And then the good thing about this
is that when you now begin to create

674
00:39:49.710 --> 00:39:53.345
your tables or your graph for that matter.

675
00:39:53.345 --> 00:39:56.690
Graphs starts making a little more
sense when you start seeing patterns,

676
00:39:56.690 --> 00:39:57.800
when it's visual.

677
00:39:57.800 --> 00:40:04.290
So if right now the plan is to create
some simple chart, there I go.

678
00:40:04.290 --> 00:40:07.700
It actually shows me in decreasing order.

679
00:40:07.700 --> 00:40:13.790
So if I went here and changed this into
increasing order and I did my custom and

680
00:40:13.790 --> 00:40:18.900
I just did smallest to largest and
I say OK, everything changes.

681
00:40:18.900 --> 00:40:23.480
So now this is interesting,
it shows me that there's a trend.

682
00:40:23.480 --> 00:40:28.070
It also shows me quickly who owes
the largest and who owes the smallest, and

683
00:40:28.070 --> 00:40:29.660
I can easily make decisions.

684
00:40:29.660 --> 00:40:32.240
So there are mechanisms for sorting data.

685
00:40:32.240 --> 00:40:36.650
And that data that is sorted can be
reflected in the way we organize our

686
00:40:36.650 --> 00:40:39.000
charts and bars and whatnot.

687
00:40:39.000 --> 00:40:41.970
So I hope that that's
a great way to conclude,

688
00:40:41.970 --> 00:40:47.370
as we've covered a lot of ground in Excel
document, and I hope that this was useful.

689
00:40:48.390 --> 00:40:49.310
>> It definitely is, yeah.

690
00:40:49.310 --> 00:40:53.030
Sorting data is one of the most useful
tools that we can use to help us to see

691
00:40:53.030 --> 00:40:54.720
the way that Dr. Tonny showed us.

692
00:40:54.720 --> 00:40:59.090
A lot of times just bringing it to the top
or to the bottom, that way we can make

693
00:40:59.090 --> 00:41:02.690
decisions very quickly on just some
information that we need to see,

694
00:41:02.690 --> 00:41:05.380
whether it's based on largest or
smallest numbers.

695
00:41:05.380 --> 00:41:08.520
Well that's great place for
us to also end this episode then.

696
00:41:08.520 --> 00:41:10.150
Signing off for ITPro.TV.

697
00:41:10.150 --> 00:41:12.990
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

698
00:41:12.990 --> 00:41:15.810
>> And my name is Dr. Tonny Omwansa,
it's been great learning together,

699
00:41:15.810 --> 00:41:18.380
I'm really looking forward
to another session.

700
00:41:18.380 --> 00:41:21.122
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Computing Fundamentals.

701
00:41:21.122 --> 00:41:30.373
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonney Omwansa show how to get started with Microsoft Access 2010.  They describe why access is necessary and talk about the difference between a database and a spreadsheet.  Dr. Omwansa describes the concepts of Entity, Fields, Records.  According to the guys, these are basic terms that everyone must understand.  They also describe the logical connection between Entities (Tables) using primary key and foreign key (one to one or one to many relationships).  They conclude the segment by also mentioning forms and reports, along with the entities and relationships are the fundamentals of using Microsoft Access 2010.
episodes.title: Introduction to Microsoft Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa continue with the basics in Microsoft Access 2010.  They show and describe creating tables in design view and also how they can be created on the fly in spreadsheet view.  They discuss the importances of setting field properties and naming tables too.  They emphasize these are the structures that will house the data we will enter into our databases and so much be created with care before data entry occurs.
episodes.title: Introduction to Microsoft Access Part 2

WEBVTT

2

00:26:57.480 --> 00:27:01.785
We may have mentioned it back
through the unique identifier, and

457
00:27:01.785 --> 00:27:08.210
it gives us an opportunity
to uniquely identify rules.

458
00:27:09.370 --> 00:27:13.450
Every rule will be unique, and that now
brings in a different intelligence that

459
00:27:13.450 --> 00:27:19.000
the Access database provides over and
above, a simple spreadsheet.

460
00:27:19.000 --> 00:27:21.640
So I can uniquely identify fields.

461
00:27:21.640 --> 00:27:25.170
Once I have this field,
it means the in one way or another,

462
00:27:25.170 --> 00:27:26.610
the entire row will be unique.

463
00:27:26.610 --> 00:27:31.230
So, if I match it to something
else at another, in another table,

464
00:27:31.230 --> 00:27:35.070
I will always know there's only
one row that will be like that.

465
00:27:35.070 --> 00:27:37.280
That doesn't mean that some
things we've been there or

466
00:27:37.280 --> 00:27:41.390
will not be the same as another row
there can, but when you think about

467
00:27:41.390 --> 00:27:46.520
the entire row it's unique because
of that primary key, all right?

468
00:27:46.520 --> 00:27:47.610
So that gives us an idea.

469
00:27:47.610 --> 00:27:50.990
So now we can create several tables
over here, it's not a problem.

470
00:27:50.990 --> 00:27:53.250
We can create many tables
depending on what we want.

471
00:27:54.330 --> 00:28:01.540
Now, at this second tab for
creating we can use wizards.

472
00:28:01.540 --> 00:28:04.380
We currently used the design version.

473
00:28:04.380 --> 00:28:06.430
So, where you create it yourself.

474
00:28:06.430 --> 00:28:09.790
And it's always good to know what exactly
is happening in the background before

475
00:28:09.790 --> 00:28:10.708
you use wizards.

476
00:28:10.708 --> 00:28:14.990
Of course wizards can very quickly create
for you things, you just select stuff and

477
00:28:14.990 --> 00:28:17.220
then you have something
at the end of the day.

478
00:28:17.220 --> 00:28:19.630
But, we encourage that for
purposes of learning and

479
00:28:19.630 --> 00:28:23.440
understanding, it's good to
play with the design version.

480
00:28:23.440 --> 00:28:25.720
So, you create the tables yourself.

481
00:28:25.720 --> 00:28:30.460
Now as you can right across here there's
an opportunity to create tables.

482
00:28:30.460 --> 00:28:35.369
So, you can design tables,
you can go ahead and design queries,

483
00:28:35.369 --> 00:28:40.725
you can use query Wizard, you can
create forms, you can design forms,

484
00:28:40.725 --> 00:28:45.297
and you can have a blank form and
play then you around with it.

485
00:28:45.297 --> 00:28:49.684
So all these options exist here, so
there are tables, there are queries,

486
00:28:49.684 --> 00:28:53.970
there are forms, there are reports,
there are macros and code.

487
00:28:53.970 --> 00:28:56.850
But don't worry about
that towards the end.

488
00:28:56.850 --> 00:29:01.970
So I hope that that overall layout gives
you a sense that you can possibly create

489
00:29:01.970 --> 00:29:06.380
next several things,
depending on what exactly you want.

490
00:29:06.380 --> 00:29:08.890
Do you wanna say anything along
those lines, or that's good?

491
00:29:08.890 --> 00:29:11.940
>> Yeah.
Let's talk on that unique identifier

492
00:29:11.940 --> 00:29:15.810
again, cuz I know that when I first got
started into working with databases,

493
00:29:15.810 --> 00:29:18.250
it was very difficult for
me to understand.

494
00:29:18.250 --> 00:29:21.370
Especially when you mention
like a tables club students.

495
00:29:21.370 --> 00:29:25.370
It is very possible, and I've run
into this not just with students, but

496
00:29:25.370 --> 00:29:30.680
actually at companies in which
somebody was named John C Smith, and

497
00:29:30.680 --> 00:29:36.290
then later on I looked at that table, and
somebody else was named John C Smith.

498
00:29:36.290 --> 00:29:37.580
And actually,

499
00:29:37.580 --> 00:29:43.520
I found a single company that had
about 26 people named John C Smith.

500
00:29:43.520 --> 00:29:46.400
Well they all worked for
the same company, and so

501
00:29:46.400 --> 00:29:49.670
if they are to receive
their particular wages for

502
00:29:49.670 --> 00:29:54.320
that week or that month, we have to
be able to uniquely identify them.

503
00:29:54.320 --> 00:29:58.118
And that's what that unique
identifier column that Dr.

504
00:29:58.118 --> 00:30:00.850
Omwansa was talking about is important.

505
00:30:00.850 --> 00:30:05.390
In every single database, we have at
least one field that will help us

506
00:30:05.390 --> 00:30:08.520
to uniquely identify
each of those records.

507
00:30:08.520 --> 00:30:12.670
And it also provides for
us a constraint as well.

508
00:30:12.670 --> 00:30:16.790
Once you create that and you actually do
mark that column as being your unique

509
00:30:16.790 --> 00:30:21.770
identifier, it really does, by using
that primary key, even if everything

510
00:30:21.770 --> 00:30:26.700
else is the same, and it can possibly be,
you might actually have John C Smith that

511
00:30:26.700 --> 00:30:31.640
may be even living in the same house or in
the same district or whatever it might be,

512
00:30:31.640 --> 00:30:34.220
well all of a sudden, you actually have so
many matching fields.

513
00:30:34.220 --> 00:30:36.970
But with that unique identifier,
it ensures that that one record isn't

514
00:30:36.970 --> 00:30:42.770
actually unique, and that way,
even two particular weeks' wages,

515
00:30:42.770 --> 00:30:46.030
they're actually gonna be sent to
the right employee at the right time.

516
00:30:46.030 --> 00:30:48.260
So it's very important
that we understand that.

517
00:30:48.260 --> 00:30:52.030
The constraint that it offers though,
is also this ability

518
00:30:52.030 --> 00:30:56.420
to ensure that uniqueness, so
that you don't have duplicates that go in,

519
00:30:56.420 --> 00:30:59.080
and then somebody else says,
no, that's a duplicate record.

520
00:30:59.080 --> 00:31:01.510
But then when you realize
it's actually two different,

521
00:31:01.510 --> 00:31:04.660
unique IDs,
that's what will actually help us out and

522
00:31:04.660 --> 00:31:08.060
that's why it's so very important that we
understand that when creating the tables.

523
00:31:08.060 --> 00:31:11.840
The other things that we mentioned
essentially you'll see are almost

524
00:31:11.840 --> 00:31:14.250
identical to creating the tables.

525
00:31:14.250 --> 00:31:16.580
So when we start talking
about the queries,

526
00:31:16.580 --> 00:31:20.180
once we actually have the tables created,
you'll see that you can pick from those

527
00:31:20.180 --> 00:31:24.855
different fields of the information that
and you want to gather together, and

528
00:31:24.855 --> 00:31:28.470
then you will also give us that
spreadsheet like output that Dr.

529
00:31:28.470 --> 00:31:33.345
Omwansa has been talking about, or if you
choose to create a report later on, and

530
00:31:33.345 --> 00:31:38.955
design it into the format that you want to
it still works in just about the same way.

531
00:31:38.955 --> 00:31:40.915
You have a more graphical design,

532
00:31:40.915 --> 00:31:44.670
just like you also have with forms and,
but you'll also be able to create it

533
00:31:44.670 --> 00:31:47.540
just about in the same way
in that design view as well.

534
00:31:47.540 --> 00:31:52.440
So it's a little bit more challenging in
terms of the number of things you have

535
00:31:52.440 --> 00:31:56.810
to accomplish to make a database
at the very beginning so

536

it's not like a Word document, right?

537
00:31:58.430 --> 00:32:02.830
So if you contrast that, a Word
document you simply start typing and

538
00:32:02.830 --> 00:32:05.360
then you can format it,
and you're ready to go.

539
00:32:05.360 --> 00:32:09.060
Inside of Access, you do have to
understand logically what's put in there

540
00:32:09.060 --> 00:32:13.130
first, and then of course then create
the structures to make it all work.

541
00:32:13.130 --> 00:32:17.870
So you have to actually understand
a bit more in just the general concepts

542
00:32:17.870 --> 00:32:21.310
to ensure that Access works in
the way that you need it to but it,

543
00:32:21.310 --> 00:32:23.030
just a little bit more complex.

544
00:32:23.030 --> 00:32:25.508
It's not that it can't be done,
I definitely learned it, and

545
00:32:25.508 --> 00:32:27.530
that means that you can learn it as well.

546
00:32:27.530 --> 00:32:31.750
>> Absolutely, so what we've done
is we've gone systematically to

547
00:32:31.750 --> 00:32:36.640
demonstrate how to create a simple
database and also have tables.

548
00:32:36.640 --> 00:32:41.410
And we've tried gently to go through
some of the fundamentals that we need to

549
00:32:41.410 --> 00:32:43.880
appreciate, what does the overall
database gonna look like?

550
00:32:43.880 --> 00:32:48.040
Have forms, row, have queries,
have reports, etc.

551
00:32:48.040 --> 00:32:52.060
And we've gone ahead and created a simple
table, and we've explained a little bit

552
00:32:52.060 --> 00:32:57.840
about, what are the fields, what
are different data types, how do you name?

553
00:32:57.840 --> 00:32:59.470
We call that the naming convention.

554
00:32:59.470 --> 00:33:03.160
You can create your own convention if
it makes it easy for you to follow

555
00:33:03.160 --> 00:33:07.000
through what exactly you need and when
you send such a database to someone else

556
00:33:07.000 --> 00:33:11.240
they can get to see what the tables look
like, what the fields look like, what

557
00:33:11.240 --> 00:33:14.260
are the characteristics of each othersd
fields, what are the data types for

558
00:33:14.260 --> 00:33:17.855
those fields, what are the descriptions
for each of those fields.

559
00:33:17.855 --> 00:33:23.130
So as it always is we don't take too
much time we're going step by step we're

560
00:33:23.130 --> 00:33:26.900
going to close this show so you understand
that we still have some work to do.

561
00:33:26.900 --> 00:33:30.450
So when we get back we'll now
again focus on a little bit about

562
00:33:30.450 --> 00:33:32.590
queries a little bit about forms and

563
00:33:32.590 --> 00:33:37.040
we will try to put together that
data base that we can ship to you.

564
00:33:37.040 --> 00:33:41.240
>> Sounds like a great idea for

565
00:33:41.240 --> 00:33:44.860
So it's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

566
00:33:44.860 --> 00:33:48.379
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

567
00:33:48.379 --> 00:33:51.948
>> And my name is Dr.
Tonny Omwansa, enjoying learning together.

568
00:33:51.948 --> 00:33:56.684
>> Stay tuned right here for

569
00:33:56.684 --> 00:34:05.280
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa continue more basics in Microsoft Access 2010.  They discuss and demonstrate the use of forms, reports and queries.  Dr. Omwansa discuss the nature of using forms and why it’s important when you have multiple tables within your Access database.  Also, they mention the purpose and show the creation of simple reports and forms using the built in Wizards available.   Lastly, they spend some time, discuss the the concept of querying an Access database using the wizard and the design view as well.  Each of these tools can be created easily and modified to present the user with the proper form, report and query without needing to learn programing.  They end the episode briefly emphasizing the importance of databases in our everyday life.
episodes.title: Introduction to Microsoft Access Part 3

we're gonna go into relationships.

there is an entity that

45
00:02:29.410 --> 00:02:31.020

Customer, order,

00:02:33.190 --> 00:02:38.340

48

So this order was done on 30th at two

So within those, that particular order

00:02:47.620 --> 00:02:49.990

51
00:02:51.440 --> 00:02:53.800
So what I am now doing is that
I have a typical customers,

I have a typical orders and I have typical

Including the number of

56
00:03:08.880 --> 00:03:13.670
So let's start by looking

57
00:03:13.670 --> 00:03:15.140
I've made it very simple.

58
00:03:15.140 --> 00:03:19.498
I have simply put two fields,

60
00:03:24.690 --> 00:03:25.596

61

00:03:34.468 --> 00:03:39.101

00:03:39.101 --> 00:03:41.130
The one which was on customer ID.

00:03:41.130 --> 00:03:43.970

66

That means a composite key but

70

Then we open my second table

So I call it order customer ID, so

76
00:04:22.060 --> 00:04:25.670
Now if you think about it there's

So that it's clear that this is

86
00:05:05.330 --> 00:05:07.200
So fine, so it's going to be text.

87
00:05:07.200 --> 00:05:08.088
So I have three fields.

88
00:05:08.088 --> 00:05:13.623
So now the relationship
between the order details and

89
00:05:13.623 --> 00:05:18.912
the order is that the primary
key in the orders table

90
00:05:18.912 --> 00:05:24.694
called OrderID will be used

91
00:05:24.694 --> 00:05:26.831
So that they can tell me ha,

92
00:05:26.831 --> 00:05:32.400
these are the products that were actually

93
00:05:32.400 --> 00:05:35.090
So I will carry this key to that place.

94
00:05:35.090 --> 00:05:37.690
Now you don't remove it and take it there.

95
00:05:37.690 --> 00:05:38.950
We retain it here.

96
00:05:38.950 --> 00:05:43.210
But then we also list it there and
then we're going to match the two.

97
00:05:43.210 --> 00:05:45.850
So we're going to learn

98
00:05:45.850 --> 00:05:47.040
One is the foreign key.

99
00:05:48.490 --> 00:05:53.547
So when we take a key into another

100
00:05:53.547 --> 00:05:59.156

101
00:05:59.156 --> 00:06:03.490
There are other notations that I

102
00:06:03.490 --> 00:06:10.120
But let's call it the foreign key in

103
00:06:10.120 --> 00:06:14.380

104
00:06:14.380 --> 00:06:18.340
So we have introduced a new

105
00:06:18.340 --> 00:06:20.050

00:08:40.600 --> 00:08:43.290

00:09:05.955 --> 00:09:09.664

00:09:09.664 --> 00:09:16.588

00:09:16.588 --> 00:09:21.090

00:09:21.090 --> 00:09:24.220

00:09:24.220 --> 00:09:29.064

00:09:30.398 --> 00:09:34.584

00:09:40.022 --> 00:09:45.560

00:09:50.500 --> 00:09:55.560

00:09:55.560 --> 00:10:00.600
Then if we say

169
00:10:00.600 --> 00:10:04.110
go update that fields otherwise
you'll lose integrity again.

170
00:10:04.110 --> 00:10:08.160
You might just have some foreign key

171
00:10:08.160 --> 00:10:10.350
So that's why you enforce

Well, now it becomes a bit
more challenging for

566
00:32:48.480 --> 00:32:51.340
you to do that individually,
one at a time.

567
00:32:51.340 --> 00:32:56.740
A query though, can take that and go into
the relational database management system

568
00:32:56.740 --> 00:33:00.132
and actually pull that query up and
maybe in a matter of minutes,

569
00:33:00.132 --> 00:33:03.090
be able to give you all the results
that you're looking for, so

570
00:33:03.090 --> 00:33:06.720
it's a very powerful thing that you
can have here with the queries.

571
00:33:06.720 --> 00:33:09.580
And Dr. Amanza showed us one more
thing that was actually great and

572
00:33:09.580 --> 00:33:13.500
this is the way that I actually create
reports too, is to go ahead and

573
00:33:13.500 --> 00:33:18.510
create the query, verify that that's the
information I definitely need to see and

574
00:33:18.510 --> 00:33:21.140
then I go and
create my report based on the query.

575
00:33:21.140 --> 00:33:24.260
And that way I'm not looking for
or when I'm creating the report I

576
00:33:24.260 --> 00:33:28.190
already know that all the information that
I need to see is based on that query and

577
00:33:28.190 --> 00:33:30.750
now the report that I
want to give to somebody

578
00:33:30.750 --> 00:33:33.810
is all based right there
off that one single query.

579
00:33:33.810 --> 00:33:37.740
And I didn't have to learn
anything about that SQL language.

580
00:33:37.740 --> 00:33:40.920
I simply needed to verify that I
picked all the right fields, and

581
00:33:40.920 --> 00:33:43.350
that's how powerful
Microsoft Access 2010 is.

582
00:33:43.350 --> 00:33:47.230
It is a great utility and a great tool for

583
00:33:47.230 --> 00:33:52.060
those of you that are actually going on
to do more about working with databases.

584
00:33:52.060 --> 00:33:55.125
It's a great place to begin,
this is exactly where I began.

585
00:33:55.125 --> 00:33:58.960
It was actually way back in different
versions of Access, Access 97,

586
00:33:58.960 --> 00:34:02.990
but overall though, it kind of still works
the same even though the interface has

587
00:34:02.990 --> 00:34:07.340
changed over time but the skills
are transferable and that's why you still

588
00:34:07.340 --> 00:34:11.110
seeing it used today even though
its been around for a long time.

589
00:34:11.110 --> 00:34:15.219
So Dr. Amanza, any last parting
words of advice on Access?

590
00:34:16.420 --> 00:34:20.350
>> My parting shot is that
you can get better with time,

591
00:34:20.350 --> 00:34:23.120
if you're interested in
learning more about this.

592
00:34:23.120 --> 00:34:27.930
Databases are important, whether or not
you're gonna be the one working with them.

593
00:34:27.930 --> 00:34:30.605
But you need to understand
the principle behind the database.

594
00:34:30.605 --> 00:34:34.115
Because we manipulate data,
we need to make decisions and

595
00:34:34.115 --> 00:34:36.095
decisions are based on data.

596
00:34:36.095 --> 00:34:40.425
And we can rely on other people to build
these databases, but it is important for

597
00:34:40.425 --> 00:34:45.140
us to appreciate the foundation and
the concept around the database.

598
00:34:45.140 --> 00:34:49.500
As you build your competence on
the database, you can become very useful.

599
00:34:49.500 --> 00:34:53.550
There are people who create
specializations in database and, you know,

600
00:34:53.550 --> 00:34:55.350
they provide that kind of a service.

601
00:34:55.350 --> 00:35:01.570
They can create very complex queries, very
complex inner reports, very interesting

602
00:35:01.570 --> 00:35:06.190
forms, and they solve a lot of problems
you know, by clicking a button you have so

603
00:35:06.190 --> 00:35:09.840
much information, you can pull
different kind of things together.

604
00:35:09.840 --> 00:35:11.530
This is an important resource.

605
00:35:11.530 --> 00:35:14.220
It is a very, very important resource.

606
00:35:14.220 --> 00:35:19.750
So now this has brought us to a close,
because we can't spend all the time here.

607
00:35:19.750 --> 00:35:21.550
We only have so much time.

608
00:35:21.550 --> 00:35:25.100
We hope that we've given
a glimpse about databases and

609
00:35:25.100 --> 00:35:29.500
you're gonna spend your own time
trying to practice, understand.

610
00:35:29.500 --> 00:35:32.925
There are more things that are in there
that we didn't get to talk about.

611
00:35:32.925 --> 00:35:36.460
You can flip between,
you have literature that you can read,

612
00:35:36.460 --> 00:35:40.540
there's some material available free
online that you can study about databases,

613
00:35:40.540 --> 00:35:44.390
you appreciate the concepts even more and
then you try to practice

614
00:35:44.390 --> 00:35:49.000
using the tools that are available,
in this case Microsoft Access 2010.

615
00:35:49.000 --> 00:35:54.410
So for me I think it's been great,
it's been real, I don't know about Ronnie.

616
00:35:54.410 --> 00:35:57.510
>> It has been a fun time
getting to review the idea and

617
00:35:57.510 --> 00:36:00.570
concepts here in Microsoft Access 2010.

618
00:36:00.570 --> 00:36:02.150
So do take everything in mind here.

619
00:36:02.150 --> 00:36:04.400
If you're actually working
with databases and

620
00:36:04.400 --> 00:36:08.070
you're having to actually learn it, this
is a great fundamental place to begin.

621
00:36:08.070 --> 00:36:11.820
But remember that just about everything
you see that has some type of information

622
00:36:11.820 --> 00:36:15.580
on it that you've asked for has probably
been run from a database as well,

623
00:36:15.580 --> 00:36:18.510
and that helps make that connection
the way that we want to.

624
00:36:18.510 --> 00:36:21.500
But it's a great place for
us to also end this episode, then.

625
00:36:21.500 --> 00:36:26.070
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

626
00:36:26.070 --> 00:36:26.925
>> And my name is Dr.

627
00:36:26.925 --> 00:36:30.330
Tony Amanza, enjoying learning
together about databases.

628
00:36:30.330 --> 00:36:35.319
>> All right, stay tuned right here for
more computing fundamentals.

629
00:36:35.319 --> 00:36:43.500
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonney Omwansa introduce us to the most intuitive of programs in the Microsoft Office Suite 2010, Powerpoint.  They help get the user started with using power point by showing the interface and the layout users will encounter.  They spend time describing how to enter objects and text into the presentation.  Also how to format that presentation using the individual tools and using themes that have been provided with Powerpoint.
episodes.title: Introduction to Microsoft PowerPoint
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.929 --> 00:00:14.549
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.549 --> 00:00:19.256
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and you're
watching the Computing Fundamentals IC3.

4
00:00:19.256 --> 00:00:22.908
Now we're about to get into,
well, Microsoft PowerPoint.

5
00:00:22.908 --> 00:00:25.680
We've been taking a look at the Office
suite, and we've covered some

6
00:00:25.680 --> 00:00:29.066
of the different products, and we're now
moving in to the realm of PowerPoint here.

7
00:00:29.066 --> 00:00:32.825
And who better to help us out than Dr.
Tonny Omwansa.

8
00:00:32.825 --> 00:00:35.149
Dr. Omwansa, welcome back to our studios.

9
00:00:35.149 --> 00:00:36.020
>> Thank you very much.

10
00:00:36.020 --> 00:00:38.060
I'm enjoying myself here.

11
00:00:38.060 --> 00:00:41.575
We are now, we want to immerse ourself
to another level thinking about

12
00:00:41.575 --> 00:00:44.200
how do we present that
which we have built?

13
00:00:44.200 --> 00:00:48.990
We've used Excel, we've used Microsoft
Word, we have, tables here and there,

14
00:00:48.990 --> 00:00:52.960
now we're gonna make a presentation to
somebody and how do we organize ourselves?

15
00:00:52.960 --> 00:00:54.960
That's the power of PowerPoint.

16
00:00:54.960 --> 00:00:58.941
>> So when we start seeing the idea of
using PowerPoint, we have to understand

17
00:00:58.941 --> 00:01:02.858
that the whole idea behind this, right,
is to create a presentation that

18
00:01:02.858 --> 00:01:06.987
we are going to, well, probably present
to an audience that we have on hand.

19
00:01:06.987 --> 00:01:09.442
And the idea here is not
simply as to speaking, but

20
00:01:09.442 --> 00:01:13.534
being able to make our point not only with
words, but also graphically as well, and

21
00:01:13.534 --> 00:01:16.310
PowerPoint is one of those
tools to help us out.

22
00:01:16.310 --> 00:01:20.688
So where are we gonna being with
this particular tool, Dr. Omwasa?

23
00:01:20.688 --> 00:01:22.150
>> All right.

24
00:01:22.150 --> 00:01:25.390
We're gonna spend some time
thinking about a number of things

25
00:01:25.390 --> 00:01:26.610
in the context of PowerPoint.

26
00:01:26.610 --> 00:01:30.483
One is that I want us to understand
the basic PowerPoint presentation.

27
00:01:30.483 --> 00:01:34.520
Let's understand how it's organized.

28
00:01:34.520 --> 00:01:36.200
What is the format of the presentation?

29
00:01:36.200 --> 00:01:39.220
How does should the format
presentation get to look like?

30
00:01:39.220 --> 00:01:43.460
We'll think about,
how do we create different slides,

31
00:01:43.460 --> 00:01:46.930
different types of slides so
that when we put it all together,

32
00:01:46.930 --> 00:01:51.260
it's interesting to watch and
also used to present.

33
00:01:51.260 --> 00:01:53.550
We'll also try to apply
a bit of transitions.

34
00:01:53.550 --> 00:01:57.500
When you move normally from one slide
to another, there's a transition,

35
00:01:57.500 --> 00:02:02.040
so when text moves or when images move,
they are transitioned.

36
00:02:02.040 --> 00:02:05.594
How do we organize those transitions and
create some animation effect so

37
00:02:05.594 --> 00:02:07.875
that it is interesting
to see how things move?

38
00:02:07.875 --> 00:02:12.735
And finally, we'll try to create a simple
presentation that you could easily see on

39
00:02:12.735 --> 00:02:17.160
a computer as though you are actually
even watching a television.

40
00:02:17.160 --> 00:02:19.430
That's basically the outline
of what we will cover.

41
00:02:19.430 --> 00:02:22.970
And so,
I'll quickly move into getting started.

42
00:02:22.970 --> 00:02:28.360
So on my computer,
I've basically opened a PowerPoint page.

43
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:29.710
So there we go.

44
00:02:29.710 --> 00:02:31.470
So I have a PowerPoint page,

45
00:02:31.470 --> 00:02:37.360
which is typically the first page you
would get whenever you open PowerPoint.

46
00:02:37.360 --> 00:02:43.220
And as you can tell, right up here,
the layout is similar to what we

47
00:02:43.220 --> 00:02:49.580
were going through when we were dealing
with, Excel and Microsoft Word.

48
00:02:49.580 --> 00:02:53.879
Of course, there are new things,
as you can see, for example,

49
00:02:53.879 --> 00:02:57.143
there are transitions
which were not there, but

50
00:02:57.143 --> 00:03:01.377
when you think about Review,
View, Design, Insert, Home.

51
00:03:01.377 --> 00:03:07.120
The layout is generic, and at the bottom
here, of course, we have the status bar.

52
00:03:07.120 --> 00:03:08.480
It's the same, all right?

53
00:03:08.480 --> 00:03:13.080
So this is the same experience
as we've had before.

54
00:03:13.080 --> 00:03:15.600
Now every time you start
this PowerPoint slide,

55
00:03:15.600 --> 00:03:20.090
you have this space that gives you
an opportunity to do a number of things.

56
00:03:20.090 --> 00:03:22.230
On the extreme left, so

57
00:03:22.230 --> 00:03:25.840
if I open this it will give you
an idea of how that layout looks like.

58
00:03:25.840 --> 00:03:29.590
All right, so this is some,
already some slides have been put here.

59
00:03:29.590 --> 00:03:35.814
And you can see over here there is a set
of slides, so a presentation can have

60
00:03:35.814 --> 00:03:41.420
1 slide, 2 slides, 100 slides,
all depends on what you're doing.

61
00:03:41.420 --> 00:03:43.893
So you'll see a set of
slides on your left,

62
00:03:43.893 --> 00:03:47.328
and now this is the slide that
you may be working on, so it's

63
00:03:47.328 --> 00:03:52.233
called a slide pin where you focus on that
particular slide that you're working on.

64
00:03:52.233 --> 00:03:56.465
And then down here there is a set of
notes that you can actually put for

65
00:03:56.465 --> 00:03:58.030
a particular slide.

66
00:03:58.030 --> 00:04:01.447
It can remind you later what were you
working on on that particular slide.

67
00:04:01.447 --> 00:04:04.270
And then at the bottom of the status bar,

68
00:04:04.270 --> 00:04:07.872
there's an opportunity to play around
with how you want to view the slides.

69
00:04:07.872 --> 00:04:12.630
You may want to see all the slides in one
go, or you want to see one at a time, or

70
00:04:12.630 --> 00:04:15.610
you want to see a slide show,
or whatever that may be.

71
00:04:15.610 --> 00:04:16.677
So that's the layout,

72
00:04:16.677 --> 00:04:20.830
now just to show you how could I add
a slide here, there are two ways.

73
00:04:20.830 --> 00:04:24.309
I can come here and
right click and insert a slide.

74
00:04:24.309 --> 00:04:27.460
So automatically we have two
slides in my presentation.

75
00:04:27.460 --> 00:04:32.440
Or I can simply go up here, New Slide,
and now I have three slides.

76
00:04:32.440 --> 00:04:37.320
And then you look,
the first slide has a slightly different

77
00:04:37.320 --> 00:04:42.750
design from the second one, in terms
of the template that has been created.

78
00:04:42.750 --> 00:04:46.670
So right here, it's assuming that you're
going to start with some kind of a title.

79
00:04:47.910 --> 00:04:50.830
And then,
there will be some kind of a subtitle.

80
00:04:50.830 --> 00:04:56.360
So that's a generic design, you don't
have to use that, you can always modify.

81
00:04:56.360 --> 00:04:59.810
And then the second and third slide,
they have a similar design.

82
00:04:59.810 --> 00:05:02.900
It's assumed that somewhere here
you're gonna put in a title.

83
00:05:02.900 --> 00:05:05.910
And probably you're going to
put some text here, all right?

84
00:05:05.910 --> 00:05:10.670
And then as you can see, also there is
some buttons put right at the center here,

85
00:05:10.670 --> 00:05:11.600
some kind of images.

86
00:05:11.600 --> 00:05:14.440
It tells you that you can
insert something like an image,

87
00:05:14.440 --> 00:05:17.265
you can insert a chart,
you can insert a graph,

88
00:05:17.265 --> 00:05:22.345
you can insert a video actually, you can
insert an image, or whatever it may be.

89
00:05:22.345 --> 00:05:23.925
So this is a general layout,

90
00:05:23.925 --> 00:05:28.750
this is what you kind of expect when you
open up a Microsoft PowerPoint image.

91
00:05:28.750 --> 00:05:32.630
I really want to believe that it's
nothing too new, it's similar, and

92
00:05:32.630 --> 00:05:36.548
maybe you may have some thoughts
along the same thinking.

93
00:05:36.548 --> 00:05:39.590
>> Yeah, there's no doubt if one of
the tools you actually use to make

94
00:05:39.590 --> 00:05:40.650
the point that you need,

95
00:05:40.650 --> 00:05:45.340
the most intuitive one in the Office Suite
is going to be PowerPoint presentation.

96
00:05:45.340 --> 00:05:48.752
As you take a look at it, unlike Word,
right, when it normally opens up,

97
00:05:48.752 --> 00:05:50.954
it gives us a document
that we are looking at, or

98
00:05:50.954 --> 00:05:53.440
it may offer us the ability
to do a template.

99
00:05:53.440 --> 00:05:57.480
And Excel normally opens up to maybe
that worksheet that we have, and

100
00:05:57.480 --> 00:05:59.370
really doesn't guide us
in what we want to do.

101
00:05:59.370 --> 00:06:03.190
But by default, when PowerPoint opens up,
it automatically gives you,

102
00:06:03.190 --> 00:06:04.800
I don't wanna say it's a command.

103
00:06:04.800 --> 00:06:07.910
But it says,
this is where you type information in.

104
00:06:07.910 --> 00:06:10.960
So it's already telling you what to
do at the very beginning when you

105
00:06:10.960 --> 00:06:12.620
first open it up.

106
00:06:12.620 --> 00:06:14.160
And the goal here, right,

107
00:06:14.160 --> 00:06:19.020
is for you to understand that this is
not a difficult tool for us to use.

108
00:06:19.020 --> 00:06:22.780
But it does require us to think
a little bit more in the idea of

109
00:06:22.780 --> 00:06:28.030
what points do I really need to make when
I'm actually making my presentation?

110
00:06:28.030 --> 00:06:32.030
And the layout that we saw right there
allows us to be able to see, well,

111
00:06:32.030 --> 00:06:36.100
not only the number of slides that we
can create that we are gonna display.

112
00:06:36.100 --> 00:06:38.850
But also gives the presenter
the ability to add in

113
00:06:38.850 --> 00:06:41.735
additional notes that won't show
up during the presentation.

114
00:06:41.735 --> 00:06:45.110
But will allow you to have them either
on the screen or printed out, and

115
00:06:45.110 --> 00:06:48.860
that way you can also use that along
with your presentation as well.

116
00:06:48.860 --> 00:06:52.920
To be able to have a guide for
you to follow, or even notes for

117
00:06:52.920 --> 00:06:56.952
somebody else to take as they're using
this particular type of demonstration.

118
00:06:56.952 --> 00:07:01.330
Now, PowerPoint is one of those tools that
you'd normally see inside of, well, a lot

119
00:07:01.330 --> 00:07:06.520
of times, right, at the idea of a school
or a university level, where somebody's

120
00:07:06.520 --> 00:07:10.980
actually lecturing a lot of times, and
it takes a little bit of time to create.

121
00:07:10.980 --> 00:07:12.170
But because it's so intuitive,

122
00:07:12.170 --> 00:07:16.000
most people can pick this
particular skill up fairly easily.

123
00:07:16.000 --> 00:07:17.173
The views that Dr.

124
00:07:17.173 --> 00:07:21.510
Omwansa was talking about also help you
out in the more slides that you get.

125
00:07:21.510 --> 00:07:25.380
You can actually turn it to a view
that shows you every single slide.

126
00:07:25.380 --> 00:07:29.000
And that allows you to lay it out like you
would lay out different index cards onto

127
00:07:29.000 --> 00:07:29.890
a table.

128
00:07:29.890 --> 00:07:33.960
Then you can rearrange the orders, as if
they're actually laid out on a table,

129
00:07:33.960 --> 00:07:37.186
than you can put them in a proper
logical order that you want to.

130
00:07:37.186 --> 00:07:41.290
This tool itself, right, gives you a lot
of function and doesn't take a lot for

131
00:07:41.290 --> 00:07:43.030
you to actually figure out how it works.

132
00:07:43.030 --> 00:07:45.337
There's not a lot of formulas
that you have to worry about.

133
00:07:45.337 --> 00:07:49.497
There's not even a lot of formatting,
unless you choose to make it that way,

134
00:07:49.497 --> 00:07:53.273
that you have to do, because PowerPoint
is designed for you to be up and

135
00:07:53.273 --> 00:07:57.251
getting ready to go, probably within 10 or
15 minutes if you need to.

136
00:07:57.251 --> 00:07:59.151
To make the points that
you need to as well.

137
00:07:59.151 --> 00:08:02.222
So there is a lot of information
right here that we've

138
00:08:02.222 --> 00:08:06.870
just done really in the first five or
ten minutes of this bigger episode.

139
00:08:06.870 --> 00:08:09.770
Because once you learn those
basic skills a lot of this

140
00:08:09.770 --> 00:08:12.630
at this point is really
about your creativity and

141
00:08:12.630 --> 00:08:15.300
about making sure you understand what
your point is that you want to make.

142
00:08:16.850 --> 00:08:21.444
>> So we'll spend a few more
minutes just to help our

143
00:08:21.444 --> 00:08:24.850
self to get familiar
with that environment.

144
00:08:24.850 --> 00:08:29.390
Some of the things that we can possibly
do, insert a slide, remove a slide.

145
00:08:29.390 --> 00:08:33.006
Change the design of the layout for
that model.

146
00:08:33.006 --> 00:08:36.860
So that's what we're gonna do for the next
few minutes, and if you have your computer

147
00:08:36.860 --> 00:08:39.850
there of course you will be
able to do it yourself as well.

148
00:08:39.850 --> 00:08:44.820
So, as you can see here there is a set of,
slides that I introduced.

149
00:08:44.820 --> 00:08:48.570
And like I said I can right click here and
I can add a new slide.

150
00:08:49.570 --> 00:08:51.340
I can scroll between slides and

151
00:08:51.340 --> 00:08:56.350
get to see if I want to change the way
the layout of a particular slide looks.

152

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonney Omwansa continue to show how to get started with  Microsoft Office Powerpoint 2010.  They begin with introducing the need of using smart art in a presentation and how to create them for making logical connection with information.  Dr. Omwansa also introduce the use of animations in powerpoint presentation and gives a warning to use them sparingly.  Lastly, they talk about the idea that powerpoint shouldn’t be the focus of the presentation but a complement to the presentation.  Dr. Omwansa provides a few points to help the beginning presenter become a more effective presenter.
episodes.title: Introduction to Microsoft PowerPoint Part 2

If I don't want it to appear here,

00:14:50.600 --> 00:14:53.590

00:15:13.940 --> 00:15:17.945

00:15:21.075 --> 00:15:23.785

If you're doing this for children,

00:16:08.447 --> 00:16:11.230

00:16:21.030 --> 00:16:26.030
But, no matter what, this is a useful tool

267
00:16:26.030 --> 00:16:29.500
or why you wanna use it,
it can really, really be interesting.

268
00:16:29.500 --> 00:16:32.250
>> Even in an instructional environment,
Dr. Almonda,

269
00:16:32.250 --> 00:16:37.345
this is one of the things that do us
in presentations so that, if I don't

00:16:37.345 --> 00:16:41.720
wanna reveal too much of what I'm about
to talk about, then I can focus in, and

271
00:16:41.720 --> 00:16:47.070
I can just have my particular main point
Slide right in, or transition into that.

272
00:16:47.070 --> 00:16:52.070
And make sure that I lecture, or I teach,
or I instruct on that particular point.

273
00:16:52.070 --> 00:16:55.080
And then, I can say, all right,
now let's move on to point two.

274
00:16:55.080 --> 00:16:58.630
Have that one fade out in the background,
and have the other one come up.

275
00:16:58.630 --> 00:17:00.380
So that way, I'm literally directing it,

00:17:00.380 --> 00:17:05.250
instead of somebody trying to race through

00:17:05.250 --> 00:17:08.253
Using the transitions,
just like Dr. Almonda said,

00:17:08.253 --> 00:17:12.650
it can be powerful if you use it in

00:17:12.650 --> 00:17:16.420
But it can be so distracting when

00:17:16.420 --> 00:17:18.360

00:17:18.360 --> 00:17:22.330
So, the whole goal behind this is what

Are you trying to make

00:17:24.710 --> 00:17:27.000
Well, if you are you can do

But if you are trying to make a point by

At the beginning.

And then, I show point number two.

But if this is for something fun, or

00:18:10.420 --> 00:18:13.800
a lot of times, the more animation,

00:18:16.890 --> 00:18:19.960

00:18:22.580 --> 00:18:26.860
So, you can see where this can be very

00:18:30.760 --> 00:18:32.920

But this is the idea.

The more time that you spend with it, the

00:18:43.580 --> 00:18:45.020
Animations can really help you do that.

00:18:46.330 --> 00:18:47.050
>> Great.

Next, is you want to make a presentation.

It take you a couple hours to put together

00:22:06.780 --> 00:22:09.730

00:22:12.390 --> 00:22:14.595
And then,

>> There is no doubt that I've actually

00:22:17.880 --> 00:22:21.411

00:22:23.800 --> 00:22:27.200
The neat thing about doing these
presentations is even if you,

00:22:27.200 --> 00:22:30.050

00:22:30.050 --> 00:22:33.635
and all of a sudden they say, well, Dr.
Almondza, you only have five minutes.

00:22:33.635 --> 00:22:39.000
Well, you can quickly go back in and

You don't have to create

You can simply hide them, and then hit

00:22:52.810 --> 00:22:54.590
So, they try and

00:22:54.590 --> 00:22:57.130
the benefit that you

Whether you actually present everything

00:23:00.130 --> 00:23:02.150

00:23:02.150 --> 00:23:04.100
You can actually do things like that.

00:23:04.100 --> 00:23:07.790
And so, having these PowerPoint

00:23:07.790 --> 00:23:09.340
the ability for you to do that.

00:23:09.340 --> 00:23:13.619
The neatest thing I like about

00:23:13.619 --> 00:23:17.490
Hooking up that projector and

00:23:17.490 --> 00:23:19.520

00:23:19.520 --> 00:23:21.970
It's a great feeling because you

00:23:21.970 --> 00:23:23.560

00:23:23.560 --> 00:23:27.230
>> But the other thing about it is that
you can package up that PowerPoint

presentation and save it either on to one

405
00:23:32.200 --> 00:23:36.820
have, the USB thumb drives, or

00:23:36.820 --> 00:23:38.990
And that way, you can send it to somebody,

00:23:38.990 --> 00:23:40.550
and all they have to do

00:23:40.550 --> 00:23:44.290
It will make them install a small

00:23:44.290 --> 00:23:46.710
And then,
they can watch that presentation.

00:23:46.710 --> 00:23:49.410
And you don't have to actually make

411
00:23:49.410 --> 00:23:50.410

It is a very powerful way for you to

00:23:54.968 --> 00:23:58.294

And this is what I did when I

00:24:01.757 --> 00:24:04.953
that really first month that

00:24:04.953 --> 00:24:08.238

But I wanted to share that with her

00:24:13.220 --> 00:24:13.820
At that point,

they didn't have PowerPoint, so I was

00:24:17.580 --> 00:24:22.520

00:24:22.520 --> 00:24:23.690
And it was amazing for

All of that was before I really had

But now that I've been teaching it for

years, I see the benefit of that,

00:24:36.220 --> 00:24:40.180

00:24:40.180 --> 00:24:44.410
I now know that that presentation can

00:24:44.410 --> 00:24:46.035
even if they don't have
