00:24:46.035 --> 00:24:46.990
>> Mm-hm.

430
00:24:46.990 --> 00:24:51.060
So now we're talking about the experience
of making the presentation.

431
00:24:51.060 --> 00:24:53.810
Now the very fact that you
can type things out and

432
00:24:53.810 --> 00:24:59.270
paste them here doesn't necessarily
mean you will have a great presentation.

433
00:24:59.270 --> 00:25:01.970
You also have to prepare
yourself to present and

434
00:25:01.970 --> 00:25:06.090
some of the guidelines that we can
give in preparing presentations.

435
00:25:06.090 --> 00:25:07.730
One, don't put too much text.

436
00:25:09.080 --> 00:25:12.410
When you're having a presentation
to enlarge your dias, for example,

437
00:25:12.410 --> 00:25:16.920
people really don't have the time to read,
they want to listen to you.

438
00:25:16.920 --> 00:25:20.280
They want to hear the story, so
the presentation becomes a guide.

439
00:25:21.360 --> 00:25:23.110
If you want to put
things in bullet points,

440
00:25:23.110 --> 00:25:27.470
that can be very helpful as opposing
to putting them in paragraph form.

441
00:25:27.470 --> 00:25:30.310
Otherwise, people are tempted to start
reading and if they're going to read,

442
00:25:30.310 --> 00:25:34.360
then you may as well have given them
the book so they can go and read.

443
00:25:34.360 --> 00:25:39.780
They are relying on you to make a summary,
to make key highlights.

444
00:25:39.780 --> 00:25:43.310
Think about your own audience, especially
when you're having a lot of text.

445
00:25:43.310 --> 00:25:48.450
How do you organize it so that the focus
does not go into reading the presentation

446
00:25:48.450 --> 00:25:51.974
and trying to figure out what's
the connection between different things,

447
00:25:51.974 --> 00:25:53.760
so they can spend more
time listening to you.

448
00:25:53.760 --> 00:25:56.390
If they must turn their head
go look at the presentation,

449
00:25:56.390 --> 00:25:59.570
they can see the key bullet points and
then you tell the story.

450
00:25:59.570 --> 00:26:03.560
The other thing I think you should
think about is not too many colors.

451
00:26:03.560 --> 00:26:06.850
You see the opportunity to
do colors here is there.

452
00:26:06.850 --> 00:26:09.780
The space is there,
you can explore your creativity.

453
00:26:09.780 --> 00:26:14.445
But the way the human mind
processes information is

454
00:26:14.445 --> 00:26:19.325
we have to moderate how much color you do,
especially if you're doing it for adults.

455
00:26:19.325 --> 00:26:23.645
For children, I think color is of
interest and sound is of interest, and

456
00:26:23.645 --> 00:26:26.805
you can play with a lot of colors and
that's okay.

457
00:26:26.805 --> 00:26:31.085
But for grownups, I think you want
to minimize the number of colors and

458
00:26:31.085 --> 00:26:34.750
then how related are those
colors as you put them together.

459
00:26:35.830 --> 00:26:41.070
Also, if you're gonna make this
presentation to somebody, you

460
00:26:41.070 --> 00:26:46.670
know that the audience is looking at the
screen, they're looking at the projection.

461
00:26:46.670 --> 00:26:51.415
Now you also want to make sure
you look at the audience.

462
00:26:51.415 --> 00:26:53.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because you can [LAUGH] make

463
00:26:53.940 --> 00:26:56.640
a presentation and
you find yourself turning and

464
00:26:56.640 --> 00:27:02.090
reading what's on the presentation and so
you're giving your audience your back.

465
00:27:03.140 --> 00:27:06.610
Ideally, that's not a good way to present.

466
00:27:06.610 --> 00:27:08.630
You want to try as much as possible,

467
00:27:10.560 --> 00:27:14.690
understand the material and
use this to present and

468
00:27:14.690 --> 00:27:19.150
summarize, and show relationship,
and put life into the presentation.

469
00:27:19.150 --> 00:27:24.990
So that it's not, you are reading one line
at a time and trying to demonstrate that

470
00:27:24.990 --> 00:27:29.840
you know what's written up there.

471
00:27:29.840 --> 00:27:35.250
No, you don't even have to read all
the words up there, because your audience

472
00:27:35.250 --> 00:27:41.120
can read that presentation, so you can
focus on explaining the story behind it,

473
00:27:41.120 --> 00:27:45.400
the material behind it,
the logic behind it, and things like that.

474
00:27:45.400 --> 00:27:50.310
I think there are many other things
we can talk about, but one more thing

475
00:27:50.310 --> 00:27:54.830
that I think I want to emphasize on making
presentations is time is important.

476
00:27:54.830 --> 00:27:55.860
In most cases,

477
00:27:55.860 --> 00:28:00.020
when we're given an opportunity to make a
presentation, the time will be predefined.

478
00:28:00.020 --> 00:28:04.180
You'll probably have seven minutes,
five minutes, or whatever it may be.

479
00:28:04.180 --> 00:28:07.990
You want to think about the key messages
that you want to pass during that

480
00:28:07.990 --> 00:28:09.180
period of time.

481
00:28:09.180 --> 00:28:15.010
And experiences, as we've done these
presentations before, every time you

482
00:28:15.010 --> 00:28:20.770
go beyond the time allocated, your
audience starts becoming uncomfortable.

483
00:28:20.770 --> 00:28:25.250
Even the moderator, in such a case,
doesn't get an easy, and

484
00:28:25.250 --> 00:28:30.798
then the focus shifts from the actual
presentation into the time mismanagement.

485
00:28:30.798 --> 00:28:36.810
Then people even begin to focus on
something else that is negative,

486
00:28:36.810 --> 00:28:39.250
yet you've already done a very
beautiful presentation.

487
00:28:39.250 --> 00:28:43.820
It's always a good habit to finish
your presentations on time and

488
00:28:43.820 --> 00:28:46.280
ensure that people can remember.

489
00:28:46.280 --> 00:28:49.190
People value time, I mean,
time is so valuable.

490
00:28:49.190 --> 00:28:53.790
You don't want to feel like you
are overusing people's time when they

491
00:28:53.790 --> 00:28:55.560
could have done something else or

492
00:28:55.560 --> 00:28:58.540
you're using someone else's time who
should have done a presentation.

493
00:28:58.540 --> 00:29:00.890
So manage yourself within the time.

494
00:29:00.890 --> 00:29:03.270
That means,
whatever number of slides you have,

495
00:29:03.270 --> 00:29:06.040
make sure you've thought about
how much time will you need for

496
00:29:06.040 --> 00:29:10.290
each of those slides, so that you're able
to finish within the time allocated.

497
00:29:10.290 --> 00:29:13.090
As it is right now,
our time is coming up and so

498
00:29:13.090 --> 00:29:15.630
we also can't go on with presentations.

499
00:29:15.630 --> 00:29:20.380
I guess my colleague here may have
some final comments as we close.

500
00:29:20.380 --> 00:29:24.340
>> All of everything that Dr.
says is pretty much the key.

501
00:29:24.340 --> 00:29:28.360
Use it as an enhancement to the point
that you're trying to make.

502
00:29:28.360 --> 00:29:31.440
Do not make the PowerPoint
presentation itself

503
00:29:31.440 --> 00:29:34.430
the central point that
actually is to be made here.

504
00:29:34.430 --> 00:29:39.180
When you do that, again, you're actually
increasing your skills as a presenter and

505
00:29:39.180 --> 00:29:42.760
hopefully, also increasing your
confidence as a presenter as well.

506
00:29:42.760 --> 00:29:45.720
Being able to do that is the difference
between somebody that really knows their

507
00:29:45.720 --> 00:29:49.150
material well and
somebody that just created a PowerPoint.

508
00:29:49.150 --> 00:29:50.890
What we want to be known as, of course,

509
00:29:50.890 --> 00:29:53.770
is the person that can
create the PowerPoint, but

510
00:29:53.770 --> 00:29:57.610
also be able to present the information,
and that is our task and our duty.

511
00:29:57.610 --> 00:30:01.280
Sometimes it may just fall on to us to
just create what somebody else gave us.

512
00:30:01.280 --> 00:30:05.720
That's perfectly fine, but it may fall
to you when they say, what else can I

513
00:30:05.720 --> 00:30:11.060
add in here to add that spark that I need
or to add that emphasis that I need?

514
00:30:11.060 --> 00:30:14.160
You're the person that's going to need
to know how to do that and hopefully,

515
00:30:14.160 --> 00:30:17.960
what you've seen here, of course,
during these episodes is understanding,

516
00:30:17.960 --> 00:30:21.260
here's some key elements we can
do to help us to do that, and

517
00:30:21.260 --> 00:30:24.384
to help us to make the point
that needs to be made.

518
00:30:24.384 --> 00:30:28.440
Dr. thank you again for helping us to
understand Microsoft PowerPoint and

519
00:30:28.440 --> 00:30:31.935
getting started with it, and
thank you also for watching, but

520
00:30:31.935 --> 00:30:35.035
that's a great place for
us to end this episode as well.

521
00:30:35.035 --> 00:30:38.835
Signing off for
ITProTV I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

522
00:30:38.835 --> 00:30:42.357
>> And my name is Dr.
Tony learning together.

523
00:30:42.357 --> 00:30:49.461
Stay tuned right here, for
more Computing Fundamentals.

524
00:30:49.461 --> 00:30:52.041
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa describe basic networking concepts and explain different network terminology.  They discuss the classification of networks by geography and type.  They also talk about the basic networking hardware and some of the different technologies used to connect to the internet.  Dr. Omwansa also points out that connectivity issues may also exist but users can use some simple troubleshooting methods.
episodes.title: Network and Internet Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.306 --> 00:00:14.942
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.942 --> 00:00:16.624
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:16.624 --> 00:00:20.631
And you're watching the Computing
Fundamentals IC3 show where we are now

5
00:00:20.631 --> 00:00:24.258
taking a look into the world of
networking and networking basics and

6
00:00:24.258 --> 00:00:26.900
learning a little bit more about that.

7
00:00:26.900 --> 00:00:29.926
And here to help us out to understand
a little bit more is gonna

8
00:00:29.926 --> 00:00:31.335
be Dr Tonny Omwansa.

9
00:00:31.335 --> 00:00:33.080
Dr Tonny, welcome back to our studios.

10
00:00:33.080 --> 00:00:34.080
>> Thank you very much.

11
00:00:34.080 --> 00:00:38.086
It's great always being here and learning
together on the fundamentals of computing.

12
00:00:38.086 --> 00:00:42.880
>> All right, so Doctor Tonny, if I am
just working with an individual computer

13
00:00:42.880 --> 00:00:46.807
by itself, that should be all I
need to be able to access and do.

14
00:00:46.807 --> 00:00:51.130
Why is it so important that I know
a little bit about networking?

15
00:00:51.130 --> 00:00:53.400
>> It's a very, very,
very important question.

16
00:00:53.400 --> 00:00:56.540
Look, we spend a lot of time
talking about computer.

17
00:00:56.540 --> 00:00:59.700
We've talked about hardware,
we've talked about software and somehow,

18
00:00:59.700 --> 00:01:02.150
you can actually get to do
what you need to do with

19
00:01:02.150 --> 00:01:04.747
just a computer that is not
connected to any other.

20
00:01:04.747 --> 00:01:09.270
But in reality,
we need to work with others.

21
00:01:09.270 --> 00:01:13.470
And the beauty about computers is they've
now been developed to enable us to

22
00:01:13.470 --> 00:01:18.550
communicate with other people,
send documents across wide geographical

23
00:01:18.550 --> 00:01:23.360
areas in a matter of seconds,
chat with other people, send emails.

24
00:01:23.360 --> 00:01:27.560
So it's gonna be necessary for us to
appreciate how do computers communicate

25
00:01:27.560 --> 00:01:30.669
across and how do we possibly
use some of those features.

26
00:01:30.669 --> 00:01:31.549
>> All right, so Dr.

27
00:01:31.549 --> 00:01:35.571
Omwansa, if we're just really beginning
this after understanding just the basics,

28
00:01:35.571 --> 00:01:38.782
where is our starting point when
we start talking about networking?

29
00:01:38.782 --> 00:01:42.097
Cuz it seems like I really may
not have actually used a computer

30
00:01:42.097 --> 00:01:44.540
network before and
now I need to get started.

31
00:01:44.540 --> 00:01:46.990
Is there a lot of technicality
that I need to go into?

32
00:01:48.610 --> 00:01:53.010
>> Well, yes and no, depends on the depth
you really want to go into this.

33
00:01:53.010 --> 00:01:56.216
For purposes of introduction,
we're gonna appreciate a few things.

34
00:01:56.216 --> 00:01:59.920
One is how does communication
really take place and

35
00:01:59.920 --> 00:02:02.770
how do the computers borrow
from real life communication?

36
00:02:02.770 --> 00:02:04.150
You and I are talking right now, yeah?

37
00:02:04.150 --> 00:02:04.690
>> Right.
>> And

38
00:02:04.690 --> 00:02:07.110
so I hope that computers
would talk like that, right?

39
00:02:07.110 --> 00:02:08.250
>> Hopefully, all right,

40
00:02:08.250 --> 00:02:11.440
then we'll try to distinguish
the various types of computer networks.

41
00:02:11.440 --> 00:02:15.730
We'll think about the hardware devices
that enable computers to communicate.

42
00:02:15.730 --> 00:02:17.930
Then we'll try to figure
out what do you choose,

43
00:02:17.930 --> 00:02:20.770
which kind of communication
technique do you choose?

44
00:02:20.770 --> 00:02:23.470
And finally,
we'll try to appreciate the Internet,

45
00:02:23.470 --> 00:02:27.910
the power of Internet connectivity,
before we go into troubleshooting.

46
00:02:27.910 --> 00:02:29.080
>> It sounds like a great idea.

47
00:02:29.080 --> 00:02:32.240
So when we start talking
about the idea of networking,

48
00:02:32.240 --> 00:02:36.070
most of us don't seem to believe that
we might have used a network before.

49
00:02:36.070 --> 00:02:40.880
But you probably have, at least, if you've
actually picked up a telephone before and

50
00:02:40.880 --> 00:02:42.190
called somebody else.

51
00:02:42.190 --> 00:02:43.670
You're not using your own network,

52
00:02:43.670 --> 00:02:46.830
but you're actually using that
telephone company's network as well.

53
00:02:46.830 --> 00:02:50.000
And so a lot of times we can get
established in our regular daily lives by

54
00:02:50.000 --> 00:02:52.230
taking a look at those examples,
right, Dr. Tonny?

55
00:02:52.230 --> 00:02:53.070
That's correct.

56
00:02:53.070 --> 00:02:56.990
I mean, we've made a phone call before,
probably, probably not, but

57
00:02:56.990 --> 00:02:58.896
that's a very common technology
that has been around.

58
00:03:00.190 --> 00:03:03.990
The computer communication kind of
borders a little bit from that concept.

59
00:03:03.990 --> 00:03:07.890
But the difference is that it uses
what we call packet suite to network.

60
00:03:07.890 --> 00:03:11.700
In a sense,
the data tends to move in form of packets.

61
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:15.380
So it's converted, we'll not go
into a lot of technical details but

62
00:03:15.380 --> 00:03:19.500
at least, you'll appreciate
that data moves in packets and

63
00:03:19.500 --> 00:03:24.130
packets of data seem to have a sense
of a source and a destination address.

64
00:03:24.130 --> 00:03:25.510
Which means if you have so

65
00:03:25.510 --> 00:03:29.480
many computers connected, whenever
a packet is going to leave a computer,

66
00:03:29.480 --> 00:03:33.680
it needs to know where it's going to go,
otherwise it's huge mesh of network.

67
00:03:33.680 --> 00:03:36.460
All right, so
that forms a foundation in thinking about

68
00:03:36.460 --> 00:03:39.760
what is the philosophy of
communication of computer networks.

69
00:03:39.760 --> 00:03:42.686
>> So when we start seeing
that idea of interconnection,

70
00:03:42.686 --> 00:03:44.975
that idea the telephone call, of course,

71
00:03:44.975 --> 00:03:48.979
is kind of the first link that we have
where we might dial from one computer or

72
00:03:48.979 --> 00:03:53.463
from one telephone handset to another one
which gives us a source and destination.

73
00:03:53.463 --> 00:03:56.605
But when we are connected to
a network by itself, there

74
00:03:56.605 --> 00:04:01.544
may be many destinations that are possible
and they're all using that same network.

75
00:04:01.544 --> 00:04:05.907
And so instead what we rely on is that
packet switch network that Dr Tonny was

76
00:04:05.907 --> 00:04:09.924
talking about that allows us to be
able to move from different types of

77
00:04:09.924 --> 00:04:14.370
nodes to its ultimate destination
that it needs to be able to go to.

78
00:04:14.370 --> 00:04:17.040
So in that type of network,
it doesn't matter where it travels,

79
00:04:17.040 --> 00:04:19.030
as long as it actually
gets to the other end.

80
00:04:19.030 --> 00:04:20.886
Whereas, in a telephone call,

81
00:04:20.886 --> 00:04:25.508
you're really only taking one path to be
able to get from there to the other end.

82
00:04:25.508 --> 00:04:28.126
Now Dr. Tonny,
what about the idea of the Internet?

83
00:04:28.126 --> 00:04:30.550
What is that concept really all about and

84
00:04:30.550 --> 00:04:34.970
why is it important to me if I'm
working in the business world?

85
00:04:34.970 --> 00:04:36.540
>> All right, that's a great question.

86
00:04:36.540 --> 00:04:38.180
Let's start, let me think about it.

87
00:04:38.180 --> 00:04:39.730
Do you have one computer?

88
00:04:39.730 --> 00:04:41.020
It can be connected to two,

89
00:04:41.020 --> 00:04:44.780
three other computers that creates
a small network, all right.

90
00:04:44.780 --> 00:04:49.720
Now it is now possible to have all
computers across the world be connected.

91
00:04:49.720 --> 00:04:53.410
They may not all be connected at one point
in time but that possibility exists.

92
00:04:53.410 --> 00:04:58.040
So the Internet is really
the largest computer network that

93
00:04:58.040 --> 00:05:00.430
we have which is
a collection of computers.

94
00:05:00.430 --> 00:05:04.306
And not only computers, but there
are other devices also connected in there,

95
00:05:04.306 --> 00:05:08.066
which therefore means you have the power
to communicate with a computer that

96
00:05:08.066 --> 00:05:09.790
is far, far, far away out there.

97
00:05:09.790 --> 00:05:11.370
Somewhere you can't even imagine.

98
00:05:11.370 --> 00:05:13.500
You don't even need to know
the physical location.

99
00:05:13.500 --> 00:05:15.140
It's possible to communicate.

100
00:05:15.140 --> 00:05:18.670
Now that communication is gonna
only happen as a result of some

101
00:05:18.670 --> 00:05:23.136
set of rules that have been created to
govern how communication is gonna happen.

102
00:05:23.136 --> 00:05:26.350
You just don't wake up and just call,
I wanna talk to that computer.

103
00:05:26.350 --> 00:05:27.540
Not necessarily.

104
00:05:27.540 --> 00:05:30.230
There are certain rules and
they're called protocols.

105
00:05:30.230 --> 00:05:31.620
And there are many protocols.

106
00:05:31.620 --> 00:05:34.760
There is an opportunity to immerse
ourselves into protocols but

107
00:05:34.760 --> 00:05:39.100
there's a set of rules that govern
how communication takes place.

108
00:05:39.100 --> 00:05:40.990
And there you go.

109
00:05:40.990 --> 00:05:43.510
Maybe you wanna talk about one protocol?

110
00:05:43.510 --> 00:05:47.170
>> Sure, when we start taking a look
at the idea of the Internet, the basic

111
00:05:47.170 --> 00:05:52.328
protocol that actually underlies the
Internet is the one that's called TCP/IP.

112
00:05:52.328 --> 00:05:56.199
And it is just that set of rules that
if you're gonna use that network, for

113
00:05:56.199 --> 00:05:58.822
those devices that
are directly connected to it,

114
00:05:58.822 --> 00:06:02.962
every single device needs to able to at
least talk in those types of protocols.

115
00:06:02.962 --> 00:06:05.515
If they do not,
they won't be able to communicate.

116
00:06:05.515 --> 00:06:09.636
So underlying all the physical
technology that keeps us connected is

117
00:06:09.636 --> 00:06:13.900
a software technology that allows
us to be able to communicate.

118
00:06:13.900 --> 00:06:17.554
And so every node that's connected to
the Internet speaks that language or

119
00:06:17.554 --> 00:06:21.040
uses that protocol, or
it wouldn't be able to communicate.

120
00:06:21.040 --> 00:06:25.340
So that is one of the important features
because a lot of companies are directly

121
00:06:25.340 --> 00:06:26.940
connected to the Internet.

122
00:06:26.940 --> 00:06:31.721
It also means, of course, then we might
have to be able to connect to that,

123
00:06:31.721 --> 00:06:35.470
to actually get access maybe
to a customer resource or

124
00:06:35.470 --> 00:06:38.900
to buy something or
to send information across that,

125
00:06:38.900 --> 00:06:42.750
because I don't have a network built
between me and whoever that is.

126
00:06:42.750 --> 00:06:45.770
But when I hear about
the idea of the Internet,

127
00:06:45.770 --> 00:06:48.740
we know these are multiple
companies that are connected.

128
00:06:48.740 --> 00:06:51.400
But there's also what we call
private networks too, right?

129
00:06:51.400 --> 00:06:52.210
>> That's correct.

130
00:06:52.210 --> 00:06:54.910
We've got actually different types of

131
00:06:55.950 --> 00:06:59.040
ability to communicate
between computer networks.

132
00:06:59.040 --> 00:07:02.362
We've got private networks which
are secure because Internet is not

133
00:07:02.362 --> 00:07:03.455
necessarily secure.

134
00:07:03.455 --> 00:07:07.817
So if you really want to operate in
a secure environment whenever you transmit

135
00:07:07.817 --> 00:07:12.393
data, you're sure that it can't be
intercepted., we use private networks.

136
00:07:12.393 --> 00:07:17.136
Then we've got satellite technology
that enables computers to

137
00:07:17.136 --> 00:07:20.220
communicate from a remote location.

138
00:07:20.220 --> 00:07:25.360
We've got a cellular network, you probably
know about a company that provides

139
00:07:25.360 --> 00:07:28.950
that kind of connectivity for
cellular cellphones.

140
00:07:28.950 --> 00:07:31.720
And then even using that
cellular technology,

141
00:07:31.720 --> 00:07:36.590
it is possible to connect to your
computer using tethering technology and

142
00:07:36.590 --> 00:07:38.480
then it enables computers to communicate.

143
00:07:38.480 --> 00:07:42.792
So all those options exist and as you
interact with computers depending on where

144
00:07:42.792 --> 00:07:46.779
you are based, you might, and
depending on what need you actually have,

145
00:07:46.779 --> 00:07:49.860
you might end up using
a virtual private network.

146
00:07:49.860 --> 00:07:52.190
Or you might end up using
satellite technology.

147
00:07:52.190 --> 00:07:53.860
Or cellular technology.

148
00:07:53.860 --> 00:07:56.681
>> Yeah.
In terms of accessing networks, right.

149
00:07:56.681 --> 00:08:01.932
The idea of satellite networks really help
when you do not have a physical line.

150
00:08:01.932 --> 00:08:06.141
That brings you that connectivity for
your internet connection.

151
00:08:06.141 --> 00:08:09.929
So instead they set up a nice little
satellite dish in your yard, and

152
00:08:09.929 --> 00:08:11.927
you have a receiver box at your end.

153
00:08:11.927 --> 00:08:15.440
And it shoots a signal up
into a satellite in the sky.

154
00:08:15.440 --> 00:08:18.701
And then you are connected
using that form of technology.

155
00:08:18.701 --> 00:08:22.242
And of course the idea of private
networks have always existed.

156
00:08:22.242 --> 00:08:26.948
Beside the idea of the Internet, we can
actually go to those companies and say,

157
00:08:26.948 --> 00:08:31.035
I need to establish a private direct
connection to another company.

158
00:08:31.035 --> 00:08:35.865
Or even to, let's say, my branch office
that exist in some other location inside

159
00:08:35.865 --> 00:08:38.397
of the city or
maybe inside of the country.

160
00:08:38.397 --> 00:08:42.319
And they can go ahead and run that as
a private line for us, so that our traffic

161

00:35:41.452 --> 00:35:50.190

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa talk about the basic functionality used on the internet.  Even though the internet provide the media and servers for the internet, Dr. Omwansa describes some of the most common forms of communication on the internet.  They describe communication in two broad categories: Asynchronous Communications and Synchronous (Near Synchronous) communication.  Email, social networking, forums and blogs are considered asynchronous communications; VoIP, Instant Messaging and Video conferencing would be considered synchronous or near synchronous communications, according to the team.  They also talk about using appropriate communication in a business setting and personal setting. They end the episode by taking a brief look at using an email application.
episodes.title: Online Communication

out that will allow you set

And so you do have this technology that's

00:24:40.440 --> 00:24:45.830

When you need to send an email, you'll

00:24:49.030 --> 00:24:50.260
it makes sense.

When you receive an email,

00:24:55.720 --> 00:24:57.310
It's not very technical for

But besides that though, learning about

>> Exactly and that's a very great parting

So there's normally an option for

But when you put the subject,

I need to read it and I need to

00:27:06.500 --> 00:27:08.790
Then you can compose,

it's always a good idea to always

00:27:12.200 --> 00:27:16.940
You can say, dear so and so, I think

479
00:27:16.940 --> 00:27:18.380

00:27:18.380 --> 00:27:20.120

00:27:25.550 --> 00:27:30.470
Like simply say sincerely, kindly,

00:27:30.470 --> 00:27:32.040
It's always a good habit to end email.

So that's we will talk a little

00:27:34.710 --> 00:27:38.030

that because you are introducing

00:27:48.110 --> 00:27:52.690

People are giving you their

00:27:57.940 --> 00:28:01.160

492
00:28:03.978 --> 00:28:06.670

Well, taking a look at the idea of some of

Very important task and very important

Any last parting words here on emails or

You can actually store email.

Or you can actually

So you can actually create,

Or you're currently working somewhere and

508

So you can create an auto response kind

00:29:03.930 --> 00:29:07.420
but Is gonna be between this time and
this time and

then after that maybe I can

00:29:10.460 --> 00:29:13.034
So I think it's worth spending time,

00:29:13.034 --> 00:29:17.942

I think it is one tool that we all need

517
00:29:34.470 --> 00:29:37.830
Cuz we rely on others,
we depend on one another, so

518
00:29:37.830 --> 00:29:39.960
we have to keep communicating, so.

00:29:39.960 --> 00:29:44.120
Mastering this tool and
strengthening our capacity to use it, not

520
00:29:45.270 --> 00:29:50.720
only does it make us more employable,

521
00:29:50.720 --> 00:29:53.920
And then to a large extent, we get to do

522

00:29:58.880 --> 00:30:00.871
>> Excellent, well, thank you again Dr.

Tony for helping understand a little

Great place for

00:30:22.263 --> 00:30:30.570
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa discuss the foundation of the world wide web: They describe where web information is stored, how to access it and what is normally retrieved when viewing a web page.  They describe the components used:  Web servers, Web browsers and Web pages.  Also, they show to access a web page by using a browser and knowing the URL (Uniform Resource Locator) and IP address.   Dr. Omwansa also demonstrates how to use a search engine’s power to find web pages that you do not know the exact URL to locate it.
episodes.title: Web Basics

>> Yeah, so we spent a little time

Now remember, we're talking about

But the other part of it normally is

It's normally where we go to

00:03:14.620 --> 00:03:18.040
And they call it the World Wide Web

like a spider web is interconnected,

Many points to be able

That's a specialized

The second thing that you want to

And the third thing is the web pages.

00:05:08.170 --> 00:05:10.230
So it means you actually have so

97
00:05:18.110 --> 00:05:22.522
That means you're simply connected to so

98
00:05:22.522 --> 00:05:25.240
>> There is no doubt that these
are the basic components that we

99
00:05:25.240 --> 00:05:26.350

100
00:05:26.350 --> 00:05:28.860
There's gonna be a web

us those web pages that is

102
00:05:33.310 --> 00:05:38.400
And even though you might go to a single
web server for that page, those

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Dr. Tonny Omwansa discuss some of the fundamental security goals, concerns and methods that computer users must be aware of in a computer based job.  Dr. Omwansa describes the most common terminology and concepts.  They also discuss some of the most common threats and attacks used against computer systems that can affect a user.  They also shed some light into securing data and even strategies about making our computing safer.

seem to function very well.

484
00:29:08.430 --> 00:29:11.170
And then when legitimate
users come after that,

485
00:29:11.170 --> 00:29:13.350
they're struggling to access the system.

486
00:29:13.350 --> 00:29:18.040
So denial of status can happen
deliberately, where people

487
00:29:18.040 --> 00:29:22.500
create software and probably that software
spreads itself all over the internet, and

488
00:29:22.500 --> 00:29:27.080
then at some point in time, these all
triggered from a different location to

489
00:29:27.080 --> 00:29:31.530
access that particular website,
and then it starts to shut down.

490
00:29:31.530 --> 00:29:34.940
It could be a website, it could be
a server, it could be a computer.

491
00:29:34.940 --> 00:29:38.950
People can just start to utilize
the resources on your own computer

492
00:29:38.950 --> 00:29:42.390
where the applications that are making

493
00:29:42.390 --> 00:29:45.770
all of a sudden the computer starts

494
00:29:45.770 --> 00:29:48.880
that's denial of service and
it comes in different form.

495
00:29:48.880 --> 00:29:54.140
By the way it could be that people
are genuinely accessing your website

496
00:29:54.140 --> 00:29:58.380
because of demand that has been generated
and then all of a sudden new people who

497
00:29:58.380 --> 00:30:03.100
are trying to access that same website or
resource can't seem to access it anymore.

498
00:30:03.100 --> 00:30:08.010
That's a form of denial of service so,
it can happen.

499
00:30:08.010 --> 00:30:08.580
>> Yeah.

500
00:30:08.580 --> 00:30:11.730
When we start taking a look at that
denial of service, the legitimate versus

501
00:30:11.730 --> 00:30:17.310
the illegitimate denial of service, both
of them are bad for your computer systems.

502
00:30:17.310 --> 00:30:20.900
It can actually happen because let's
say Dr. got on national TV and

503
00:30:20.900 --> 00:30:25.860
said I want you to go to my website right
now, and everybody for one reason or

504
00:30:25.860 --> 00:30:30.557
another at the very exact same moment,
do this and they go, and now they're all

505
00:30:30.557 --> 00:30:35.090
trying to connect to Doctor server at
the same time, and now a new person says,

506
00:30:35.090 --> 00:30:38.800
I'm a little bit late, I'm five seconds
late, and he can't gain access anymore.

507
00:30:38.800 --> 00:30:41.770
Well, that's a denial service
of that new person, but

508
00:30:41.770 --> 00:30:44.715
the malicious ones are the ones
we also worry about as well,

509
00:30:44.715 --> 00:30:47.858
in which somebody says,
I'm going to do this on purpose.

510
00:30:47.858 --> 00:30:52.340
So that Dr. Amwaza can't get his
information out that he needs to and

511
00:30:52.340 --> 00:30:54.280
he instead, makes thousands,

512
00:30:54.280 --> 00:30:58.340
if not hundreds of thousands of
illegitimate requests to the website.

513
00:30:58.340 --> 00:31:00.930
And even though,
they're making that connection,

514
00:31:00.930 --> 00:31:04.410
it denies everybody else the resources
to get access to it, and

515
00:31:04.410 --> 00:31:08.380
sometimes they do this by taking over
other computers on the internet.

516
00:31:08.380 --> 00:31:11.320
And when you hear that,
that term is what we call a Zombie or

517
00:31:11.320 --> 00:31:14.670
a, and what we also call a botnet,
as well.

518
00:31:14.670 --> 00:31:17.500
So when somebody else takes over the
computer and they use it for their purpose

519
00:31:17.500 --> 00:31:21.340
and I do not know about it if you
take over my computer, it's a zombie.

520
00:31:21.340 --> 00:31:23.790
But then when we act
together in conjunction, and

521
00:31:23.790 --> 00:31:28.430
let's say that that attacker
uses multiple zombies then,

522
00:31:28.430 --> 00:31:31.620
they consider that what
they call a botnet, also.

523
00:31:31.620 --> 00:31:33.960
So we do have to worry about that as well.

524
00:31:33.960 --> 00:31:38.976
Now one of the other favorite attacks of
people that are trying to gain access,

525
00:31:38.976 --> 00:31:41.485
unauthorized access to your network is

to also take a look at the wireless

00:31:46.440 --> 00:31:49.718
And this is actually a fairly

00:31:55.972 --> 00:31:59.002
So Dr. Owansa,
what do we need to know here?

531
00:31:59.002 --> 00:32:01.944
>> In that case, as ordinary users, we,

you don't need to know that not all
WiFi signals that we easily access

our computers are necessarily safe.

Just now displayed something on my screen
that, you know, gives you an indication of

So, yes, WiFi has been created, and

Your names are in there, you know,

names for

00:32:34.650 --> 00:32:36.070
That's fine.

And some of them are available to

You will see an exclamation

That gives you a sense

They are secure.

But then if you get one that is not,
and you see.

It's easily to access,
you know, I can connect and

I can send my details, I can access,

547
00:33:01.610 --> 00:33:04.430
There you are,
you are inviting potential trouble.

So, not always all open signals are safe.

00:33:08.380 --> 00:33:13.320
Some of them, actually, sincerely are

00:33:13.320 --> 00:33:18.800

00:33:18.800 --> 00:33:20.680
>> Yeah, when we start taking

there's many different things that can go

The problem is, even though you might

So you can set up some basic security

00:33:43.370 --> 00:33:44.610
out, to do so.

Now, we're not getting into the standards

If you have old computers that

But if they need to gain access you

So you want to make sure that you

569

And give them the access that they need.

Now, Dr. Owansa, I'm starting to actually

There are laws in different

Because they occupy,

Every so often, you should form

So like, form strong habits and try to

Every time you get out of your computer,

00:36:41.210 --> 00:36:45.800
And always make sure that

Every so often, your operating

You want to make sure that your

So we'll give you this as an opportunity

All right, Dr. Owansa.

Looks like we didn't really need a part

You have to always guard yourself and

The idea of making sure

Making sure, of course, that you are not

Making sure, of course, that you are being

A lot of times, when you're inside of a

you, but there are gonna be things

And you're going to be part of that team,

And so you'll get instructions

So make sure you do pay attention.

Well, that's a great place for

There's some different terminology in

So what are some of the legal
issues in computing that we have

37

38
00:02:04.020 --> 00:02:06.940
>> I think a great starting point when
we think about the legal issues and

39
00:02:06.940 --> 00:02:10.310
some of the terminologies is one
is intellectual property and

40
00:02:10.310 --> 00:02:12.910
I think the other one is copyright.

41
00:02:12.910 --> 00:02:16.290
So when we think about intellectual
property we're thinking about exclusive

42
00:02:16.290 --> 00:02:20.940
rights that someone has
in terms of ownership for

43
00:02:20.940 --> 00:02:25.090
something that they possibly created or
produced.

44
00:02:25.090 --> 00:02:27.600
So if I create a software,
if you create a software,

45
00:02:27.600 --> 00:02:30.742
if someone else creates a software,
they own the intellectual property,

46
00:02:30.742 --> 00:02:34.150
they own the rights to use that content.

47
00:02:34.150 --> 00:02:40.580
And that means we must respect that
intellectual property rights because if

48
00:02:41.870 --> 00:02:47.750
we try to take away those rights from
other people who already have them,

49
00:02:47.750 --> 00:02:51.480
then it has significant consequences.

50
00:02:51.480 --> 00:02:56.860
And the fact that people have
intellectual property rights on something

00:02:56.860 --> 00:03:03.370
means they're entitled to the benefit

52
00:03:03.370 --> 00:03:09.260
And if they have registered it, they can
use that kind of rights to commercialize,

53
00:03:09.260 --> 00:03:12.820
and therefore they will be paid for
their thoughts, for

54
00:03:12.820 --> 00:03:17.900
their hard work, and for
the usage of whatever comes out of it.

55
00:03:17.900 --> 00:03:22.730
So that's one thing that we must
strongly learn to respect, and

56
00:03:22.730 --> 00:03:26.720
also if we have intellectual
property rights on something,

57
00:03:26.720 --> 00:03:30.019
then it's an opportunity to
figure out how do we possibly

58
00:03:31.050 --> 00:03:34.860

that we can benefit out of it.

59
00:03:34.860 --> 00:03:38.170
So you may have studied
fundamentals of computing, but

60
00:03:38.170 --> 00:03:42.110
that doesn't mean you're always going
to be just a user, you can create.

61
00:03:42.110 --> 00:03:46.720
>> No doubt, so Dr. Omwansa, help us
to contrast the idea that intellectual

62
00:03:46.720 --> 00:03:49.720
property then, with that copyright.

00:03:49.720 --> 00:03:55.360
One of course is saying that I actually
have the exclusive ownership of this,

64
00:03:55.360 --> 00:03:59.220

00:31:05.053 --> 00:31:09.591

can manage ourselves in this case.

508
00:31:09.591 --> 00:31:13.780
There's so many things you can do, because

00:31:13.780 --> 00:31:17.760
Now, not all of us get to

510
00:31:17.760 --> 00:31:20.570

looking at a screen for a long time.

00:31:20.570 --> 00:31:22.630
There are people who've

00:31:22.630 --> 00:31:27.110

00:31:27.110 --> 00:31:29.480
But, it's good to take precaution.

00:31:30.480 --> 00:31:32.770
The kind of screen you use can determine.

515
00:31:33.790 --> 00:31:38.430
LCDs are better than the cathode
ray tube kind of technology.

00:31:38.430 --> 00:31:43.870
And if you can avoid, if you can

00:31:43.870 --> 00:31:48.790
How close you are to computer screens

00:31:48.790 --> 00:31:51.934

00:31:51.934 --> 00:31:54.005
Form a habit of taking some

00:31:54.005 --> 00:31:58.427
When you watch your screen for some time,

00:31:58.427 --> 00:32:01.712

00:32:01.712 --> 00:32:03.046

00:32:03.046 --> 00:32:05.211
There are many other things we can do.

00:32:05.211 --> 00:32:08.179

00:32:08.179 --> 00:32:09.296

00:32:09.296 --> 00:32:11.451
>> The idea here, especially on eyes,

00:32:11.451 --> 00:32:15.310
right, is to make sure that you
do take those breaks and refocus.

00:32:15.310 --> 00:32:19.140

00:32:19.140 --> 00:32:21.030

The problem that you and

00:32:23.380 --> 00:32:26.700

00:32:26.700 --> 00:32:30.060
And, you're not rubbing them, the reason

00:32:30.060 --> 00:32:30.700

00:32:30.700 --> 00:32:33.930
It's because your eye muscles

00:32:33.930 --> 00:32:38.000
So, always take breaks when you can,

The other thing that I also do is keep

00:32:41.610 --> 00:32:47.100

00:32:47.100 --> 00:32:50.710
And I'll also use those in

00:32:50.710 --> 00:32:52.810

00:32:52.810 --> 00:32:54.820
In a lot of these environments
that computers are in,

00:32:54.820 --> 00:32:58.140
there is a lot of air conditioning and

00:32:58.140 --> 00:33:02.770
So I use those in combination again with

00:33:02.770 --> 00:33:03.580
Now, Dr. Omwansa,

there's also the issue of posture when

>> Posture is a big deal
because you're gonna sit for

Computer systems,
